					<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading mw-first-heading"><i>The Art of War</i></h1>
							
<div id="p-lang-btn" class="vector-dropdown mw-portlet mw-portlet-lang"  >
	<input type="checkbox" id="p-lang-btn-checkbox" role="button" aria-haspopup="true" data-event-name="ui.dropdown-p-lang-btn" class="vector-dropdown-checkbox mw-interlanguage-selector" aria-label="Go to an article in another language. Available in 102 languages"   >

					<div id="mw-content-text" class="mw-body-content"><div class="mw-subjectpageheader">
</div><div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" lang="en" dir="ltr"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">5th century BC Chinese military treatise</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1320445320">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}@media print{body.ns-0 .mw-parser-output .hatnote{display:none!important}}</style><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">For other uses, see <a href="/wiki/The_Art_of_War_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="The Art of War (disambiguation)">The Art of War (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">"Know thy enemy" redirects here. For the episode of <i>The Vampire Diaries</i>, see <a href="/wiki/Know_Thy_Enemy" title="Know Thy Enemy">Know Thy Enemy</a>. For other uses, see <a href="/wiki/Know_Your_Enemy_(disambiguation)" class="mw-redirect mw-disambig" title="Know Your Enemy (disambiguation)">Know Your Enemy (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Not to be confused with <a href="/wiki/Sun_Bin%27s_Art_of_War" title="Sun Bin&#39;s Art of War">Sun Bin's Art of War</a>.</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">
</p>

<div class="sidebar-list mw-collapsible mw-collapsed"><div class="sidebar-list-title" style="background:transparent;border-top:1px solid #aaa;;color: var(--color-base)"><a href="/wiki/Military_personnel" title="Military personnel">Personnel</a></div><div class="sidebar-list-content mw-collapsible-content">

<div class="sidebar-list mw-collapsible mw-collapsed"><div class="sidebar-list-title" style="background:transparent;border-top:1px solid #aaa;;color: var(--color-base)"><a href="/wiki/Category:Military_lists" title="Category:Military lists">Lists</a></div><div class="sidebar-list-content mw-collapsible-content">

<li><a href="/wiki/List_of_military_writers" title="List of military writers">Writers</a></li></ul></div></div></td>
</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-navbar"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1129693374" /><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1239400231" /><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:War" title="Template:War"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:War" title="Template talk:War"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a href="/wiki/Special:EditPage/Template:War" title="Special:EditPage/Template:War"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><i><b>The Art of War</b></i> is an ancient <a href="/wiki/List_of_Chinese_military_texts" title="List of Chinese military texts">Chinese military treatise</a> dating from the late <a href="/wiki/Spring_and_Autumn_period" title="Spring and Autumn period">Spring and Autumn period</a> (roughly 5th century BC). The work, which is attributed to the ancient Chinese military strategist <a href="/wiki/Sun_Tzu" title="Sun Tzu">Sun Tzu</a> ("Master Sun"), is composed of 13 chapters. Each chapter is devoted to a different set of skills or <a href="/wiki/Art_(skill)" class="mw-redirect" title="Art (skill)">arts</a> related to warfare, finance and how they apply to <a href="/wiki/Military_strategy" title="Military strategy">military strategy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Military_tactics" title="Military tactics">tactics</a>. For almost 1,500 years, it was the lead text in an anthology that was formalized as the <a href="/wiki/Seven_Military_Classics" title="Seven Military Classics">Seven Military Classics</a> by <a href="/wiki/Emperor_Shenzong_of_Song" title="Emperor Shenzong of Song">Emperor Shenzong of Song</a> in 1080. <i>The Art of War</i> remains one of the most influential works on strategy of all time<sup id="cite&#95;ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>1<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and has shaped both East Asian and Western military theory and thinking.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTESmith1999216&#95;2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESmith1999216-2"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>2<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> 
</p><p>The book contains a detailed explanation and analysis of the 5th-century BC Chinese military, from weapons, environmental conditions, financial logistics and strategy to morale, rank and discipline. Sun viewed war as a costly, destructive last resort; a prolonged warfare erodes the state faster than the enemy ever could. Sun used diplomacy and economic principles in explaining how to keep war brief, contained, controlled, and as cheap as possible by minimizing financial exposure. Sun also stressed the importance of intelligence operatives and espionage to both the war effort and the prevention of war. Considered one of history's finest military tacticians and analysts, his teachings and strategies formed the basis of advanced military training throughout the world.
</p><p>The text was first translated into a European language in 1772, when the French Jesuit priest <a href="/wiki/Jean_Joseph_Marie_Amiot" title="Jean Joseph Marie Amiot">Jean Joseph Marie Amiot</a> produced a French version. The first annotated English translation was published in 1910 by the British scholar <a href="/wiki/Lionel_Giles" title="Lionel Giles">Lionel Giles</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Lionel&#95;Giles&#95;2007.&#95;p.&#95;62&#95;3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lionel_Giles_2007._p._62-3"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>3<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Military and political leaders such as the Chinese communist revolutionary <a href="/wiki/Mao_Zedong" title="Mao Zedong">Mao Zedong</a>, Japanese <span title="Japanese-language romanization"><i lang="ja-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Daimy%C5%8D" class="mw-redirect" title="Daimyō">daimyō</a></i></span> <a href="/wiki/Takeda_Shingen" title="Takeda Shingen">Takeda Shingen</a>, Vietnamese general <a href="/wiki/V%C3%B5_Nguy%C3%AAn_Gi%C3%A1p" title="Võ Nguyên Giáp">Võ Nguyên Giáp</a>, and American generals <a href="/wiki/Douglas_MacArthur" title="Douglas MacArthur">Douglas MacArthur</a> and <a href="/wiki/Norman_Schwarzkopf_Jr." title="Norman Schwarzkopf Jr.">Norman Schwarzkopf Jr.</a> are all cited as having drawn inspiration from the book.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>4<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> 
</p>
<meta property="mw:PageProp/toc" />
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="History">History</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Art_of_War&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: History"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Text_and_commentaries">Text and commentaries</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Art_of_War&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Text and commentaries"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p><i>The Art of War</i> is traditionally attributed to an ancient Chinese military general known as <a href="/wiki/Sun_Tzu" title="Sun Tzu">Sun Tzu</a> (<a href="/wiki/Pinyin" title="Pinyin">pinyin</a>: <span title="Chinese-language romanization"><i lang="zh-Latn">Sūnzǐ</i></span>), meaning 'Master Sun'. Sun Tzu is said to have lived in the 6th century BC, but the earliest parts of <i>The Art of War</i> probably date to at least 100 years later.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTELewis1999604&#95;5-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewis1999604-5"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>5<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Sima_Qian" title="Sima Qian">Sima Qian</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Shiji" title="Shiji">Shiji</a></i>, the first of China's <i><a href="/wiki/Twenty-Four_Histories" title="Twenty-Four Histories">Twenty-Four Histories</a></i>, records an early Chinese tradition that a text on military matters was written by one Sun Wu (<span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh">孫武</span></span>) from the <a href="/wiki/State_of_Qi" class="mw-redirect" title="State of Qi">state of Qi</a>, and that this text had been read and studied by <a href="/wiki/King_Hel%C3%BC_of_Wu" class="mw-redirect" title="King Helü of Wu">King Helü of Wu</a> (<span style="white-space:nowrap;"><abbr title="reigned">r.</abbr>&#8201;514–495&#160;BC</span>).<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTEGawlikowskiLoewe1993447&#95;6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGawlikowskiLoewe1993447-6"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>6<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> This text was traditionally identified with the received <i>Master Sun's Art of War</i>. The conventional view was that Sun Wu was a military theorist from the end of the <a href="/wiki/Spring_and_Autumn_period" title="Spring and Autumn period">Spring and Autumn period</a> (776–471&#160;BC) who fled Qi to the southeastern <a href="/wiki/State_of_Wu" class="mw-redirect" title="State of Wu">state of Wu</a>, where he is said to have impressed the king with his ability to quickly train officials, including court women, in military discipline—and to have made Wu's armies powerful enough to challenge the rival <a href="/wiki/State_of_Chu" class="mw-redirect" title="State of Chu">state of Chu</a> to Wu's west. This view is still widely held in China.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTEMair200712–13&#95;7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMair200712–13-7"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>7<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The strategist and warlord <a href="/wiki/Cao_Cao" title="Cao Cao">Cao Cao</a> in the early 3rd century AD authored the earliest known commentary on the <i>Art of War</i>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTEGawlikowskiLoewe1993447&#95;6-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGawlikowskiLoewe1993447-6"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>6<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Cao's preface makes clear that he edited the text and removed certain passages, but the extent of his changes were unclear historically.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTEGawlikowskiLoewe1993447&#95;6-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGawlikowskiLoewe1993447-6"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>6<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <i>The Art of War</i> appears throughout the bibliographical catalogs of the Chinese dynastic histories, but listings of its divisions and size varied widely.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTEGawlikowskiLoewe1993447&#95;6-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGawlikowskiLoewe1993447-6"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>6<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Authorship">Authorship</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Art_of_War&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Authorship"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Inscribed_bamboo-slips_of_Art_of_War.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Inscribed_bamboo-slips_of_Art_of_War.jpg/330px-Inscribed_bamboo-slips_of_Art_of_War.jpg" decoding="async" width="300" height="200" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Inscribed_bamboo-slips_of_Art_of_War.jpg/500px-Inscribed_bamboo-slips_of_Art_of_War.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Inscribed_bamboo-slips_of_Art_of_War.jpg/960px-Inscribed_bamboo-slips_of_Art_of_War.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2400" data-file-height="1600" /></a><figcaption>Fragments of <i>The Art of War</i> discovered as a part of the <a href="/wiki/Yinqueshan_Han_Slips" title="Yinqueshan Han Slips">Yinqueshan Han Slips</a>, showing the version of <i>The Art of War</i> that was popular in <a href="/wiki/Han_dynasty" title="Han dynasty">Han dynasty</a> (206&#160;BC&#160;– 220 AD)</figcaption></figure>
<p>Beginning around the 12th century, Chinese scholars began to question Sun Tzu's historical existence. Their primary ground was that the historical classic <i><a href="/wiki/Zuo_Zhuan" title="Zuo Zhuan">Zuo Zhuan</a></i>, which mentions most of the notable figures from the Spring and Autumn period, does not mention Sun Tzu at all.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTEGawlikowskiLoewe1993447&#95;6-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGawlikowskiLoewe1993447-6"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>6<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The name "Sun Wu" (<span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh">孫武</span></span>) does not appear in any text prior to the <i>Records of the Grand Historian</i>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTEMair20079&#95;8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMair20079-8"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>8<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Some scholars have suspected it is a made-up descriptive <a href="/wiki/Cognomen" title="Cognomen">cognomen</a> meaning "the fugitive warrior", glossing the surname "Sun" as the related term "fugitive" (<span title="Chinese-language romanization"><i lang="zh-Latn">xùn</i></span> <span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh">遜</span></span>), while "Wu" (<span title="Chinese-language romanization"><i lang="zh-Latn">wǔ</i></span> <span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh">武</span></span>) is (1) the ancient Chinese virtue of "martial, valiant" and (2) a <a href="/wiki/Jianghuai" title="Jianghuai">Jianghuai</a> dialectal synonym of <span lang="zh">士</span>; <i><span lang="zh-Latn">shì</span></i> "<a href="/wiki/Scholar-official#Origins_of_Shi_(士)_and_Da_fu_(大夫)" title="Scholar-official">knight</a>",<sup id="cite&#95;ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>9<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>10<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> which corresponds to Sunzi's role as the hero's <a href="/wiki/Doppelg%C3%A4nger" title="Doppelgänger">doppelgänger</a> in the story of <a href="/wiki/Wu_Zixu" title="Wu Zixu">Wu Zixu</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTEMair200710&#95;11-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMair200710-11"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>11<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In the early 20th century, the Chinese writer and reformer <a href="/wiki/Liang_Qichao" title="Liang Qichao">Liang Qichao</a> theorized that the text was actually written in the 4th century BC by Sun Tzu's purported descendant <a href="/wiki/Sun_Bin" title="Sun Bin">Sun Bin</a>, as several historical sources mention a military treatise he wrote.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTEGawlikowskiLoewe1993447&#95;6-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGawlikowskiLoewe1993447-6"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>6<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In 1972, the <a href="/wiki/Yinqueshan_Han_slips" class="mw-redirect" title="Yinqueshan Han slips">Yinqueshan Han slips</a> were discovered in two <a href="/wiki/Han_dynasty" title="Han dynasty">Han dynasty</a> (206&#160;BC&#160;– 220 AD) tombs near the city of <a href="/wiki/Linyi" title="Linyi">Linyi</a> in <a href="/wiki/Shandong" title="Shandong">Shandong</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTEGawlikowskiLoewe1993448&#95;12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGawlikowskiLoewe1993448-12"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>12<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Among the many <a href="/wiki/Bamboo_and_wooden_slips" title="Bamboo and wooden slips">bamboo slip</a> writings contained in the tombs, which had been sealed between 134 and 118 BC, were two separate texts: one attributed to "Sun Tzu", corresponding to the received text, and another attributed to Sun Bin, which explains and expands upon the earlier <i>The Art of War</i> by Sunzi.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTEGawlikowskiLoewe1993449&#95;13-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGawlikowskiLoewe1993449-13"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>13<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The Sun Bin text's material overlaps with much of the "Sun Tzu" text. The two may be "a single, continuously developing intellectual tradition united under the Sun name".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>14<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> This discovery showed that much of the historical confusion was due to the fact that there were two texts that could have been referred to as "Master Sun's Art of War", not one.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTEGawlikowskiLoewe1993449&#95;13-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGawlikowskiLoewe1993449-13"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>13<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The content of the earlier text is about one-third of the chapters of the modern <i>The Art of War</i>, and their text matches very closely.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTEGawlikowskiLoewe1993448&#95;12-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGawlikowskiLoewe1993448-12"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>12<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It is now generally accepted that the earlier <i>The Art of War</i> was completed sometime between 500 and 430&#160;BC.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTEGawlikowskiLoewe1993449&#95;13-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGawlikowskiLoewe1993449-13"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>13<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Chapters">Chapters</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Art_of_War&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Chapters"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p><i>The Art of War</i> is divided into 13 chapters (or <span title="Chinese-language romanization"><i lang="zh-Latn">piān</i></span>); the collection is referred to as being one <span title="Chinese-language romanization"><i lang="zh-Latn">zhuàn</i></span> ("whole" or alternatively "chronicle").
</p>
<table class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;">
<caption><i>The Art of War</i> chapter names and contents
</caption>
<tbody><tr>
<th>Chapter
</th>
<th><a href="/wiki/Lionel_Giles" title="Lionel Giles">Lionel Giles</a> (1910)<sup id="cite&#95;ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>15<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</th>
<th>R. L. Wing (1988)
</th>
<th>Ralph D. Sawyer (1996)
</th>
<th>Chow-Hou Wee (2003)
</th>
<th><a href="/wiki/Michael_Nylan" title="Michael Nylan">Michael Nylan</a> (2020)
</th></tr>
<tr>
<th colspan="6">Contents
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td>I
</td>
<td>Laying Plans
</td>
<td>The Calculations
</td>
<td>Initial Estimations
</td>
<td>Detail Assessment and Planning<br />(<a href="/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters" title="Traditional Chinese characters">Chinese</a>&#58; <span lang="zh-Hant">始計</span>; <a href="/wiki/Pinyin" title="Pinyin">pinyin</a>&#58; <i><span lang="zh-Latn">shîjì</span></i>)
</td>
<td>First Calculations
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="6" style="text-align:left;">Explores the five fundamental factors (the Way, seasons, terrain, leadership, and management) and seven elements (which of the two sovereigns is imbued with the way or moral law, which side's general is more capable, which side has superior in right time and right place, which side's laws and regulations can be enforced more strictly, which side has more resources, better equipment and stronger army, which side's officers and men are more well-trained and more capable of fighting, which side's rewards and punishments are more fair and clear) that determine the outcomes of military engagements. By thinking, assessing and comparing these points, a commander can calculate his chances of victory. Habitual deviation from these calculations will ensure failure via improper action. The text stresses that war is a very grave matter for the state and must not be commenced without due consideration.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>II
</td>
<td>Waging War
</td>
<td>The Challenge
</td>
<td>Waging War
</td>
<td>Waging War<br />(<span lang="zh-Hant">作戰</span>; <i><span lang="zh-Latn">zuòzhàn</span></i>)
</td>
<td>Initiating Battle
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="6" style="text-align:left;">Explains how to understand the economy of warfare and how success requires winning decisive engagements quickly. This section advises that successful military campaigns require limiting the cost of competition and conflict.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>III
</td>
<td>Attack by Stratagem
</td>
<td>The Plan of Attack
</td>
<td>Planning Offensives
</td>
<td>Strategic Attack<br />(<span lang="zh-Hant">謀攻</span>)
</td>
<td>Planning an Attack
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="6" style="text-align:left;">Defines the source of strength as unity, not size, and discusses the five factors that are needed to succeed in any war. In order of importance, these critical factors are: Attack, Strategy, Alliances, Army and Cities.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>IV
</td>
<td>Tactical Dispositions
</td>
<td>Positioning
</td>
<td>Military Disposition
</td>
<td>Disposition of the Army<br />(<span lang="zh-Hant">軍形</span>)
</td>
<td>Forms to Perceive
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="6" style="text-align:left;">Explains the importance of defending existing positions until a commander is capable of advancing from those positions in safety. It teaches commanders the importance of recognizing strategic opportunities, and teaches not to create opportunities for the enemy.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>V
</td>
<td>Use of Energy
</td>
<td>Directing
</td>
<td>Strategic Military Power
</td>
<td>Forces<br />(<span lang="zh-Hant">兵勢</span>)
</td>
<td>The Disposition of Power
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="6" style="text-align:left;">Explains the use of creativity and timing in building an army's momentum.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>VI
</td>
<td>Weak Points and Strong
</td>
<td>Illusion and Reality
</td>
<td>Vacuity and Substance
</td>
<td>Weaknesses and Strengths<br />(<span lang="zh-Hant">虛實</span>)
</td>
<td>Weak and Strong
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="6" style="text-align:left;">Explains how an army's opportunities come from the openings in the environment caused by the relative weakness of the enemy and how to respond to changes in the fluid battlefield over a given area.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>VII
</td>
<td>Maneuvering an Army
</td>
<td>Engaging The Force
</td>
<td>Military Combat
</td>
<td>Military Maneuvers<br />(<span lang="zh-Hant">軍爭</span>)
</td>
<td>Contending Armies
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="6" style="text-align:left;">Explains the dangers of direct conflict and how to win those confrontations when they are forced upon the commander.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>VIII
</td>
<td>Variation of Tactics
</td>
<td>The Nine Variations
</td>
<td>Nine Changes
</td>
<td>Variations and Adaptability<br />(<span lang="zh-Hant">九變</span>)
</td>
<td>Nine Contingencies
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="6" style="text-align:left;">Focuses on the need for flexibility in an army's responses. It explains how to respond to shifting circumstances successfully.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>IX
</td>
<td>The Army on the March
</td>
<td>Moving The Force
</td>
<td>Maneuvering the Army
</td>
<td>Movement and Development of Troops<br />(<span lang="zh-Hant">行軍</span>)
</td>
<td>Fielding the Army
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="6" style="text-align:left;">Describes the different situations in which an army finds itself as it moves through new enemy territories, and how to respond to these situations. Much of this section focuses on evaluating the intentions of others.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>X
</td>
<td>Classification of Terrain
</td>
<td>Situational Positioning
</td>
<td>Configurations of Terrain
</td>
<td>Terrain<br />(<span lang="zh-Hant">地形</span>)
</td>
<td>Conformations of the Lands
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="6" style="text-align:left;">Looks at the three general areas of resistance (distance, dangers and barriers) and the six types of ground positions that arise from them. Each of these six field positions offers certain advantages and disadvantages.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>XI
</td>
<td>The Nine Situations
</td>
<td>The Nine Situations
</td>
<td>Nine Terrains
</td>
<td>The Nine Battlegrounds<br />(<span lang="zh-Hant">九地</span>)
</td>
<td>Nine Kinds of Ground
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="6" style="text-align:left;">Describes the nine common situations (or stages) in a campaign, from scattering to deadly, and the specific focus that a commander will need in order to successfully navigate them.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>XII
</td>
<td>Attack by Fire
</td>
<td>The Fiery Attack
</td>
<td>Incendiary Attacks
</td>
<td>Attacking with Fire<br />(<span lang="zh-Hant">火攻</span>)
</td>
<td>Attacks with Fire
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="6" style="text-align:left;">Explains the general use of weapons and the specific use of the environment as a weapon. This section examines the five targets for attack, the five types of environmental attack and the appropriate responses to such attacks.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>XIII
</td>
<td>Use of Spies
</td>
<td>The Use of Intelligence
</td>
<td>Employing Spies
</td>
<td>Intelligence and Espionage<br />(<span lang="zh-Hant">用間</span>)
</td>
<td>Using Spies
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="6" style="text-align:left;">Focuses on the importance of developing good information sources, and specifies the five types of intelligence sources and how to best manage each of them.
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Cultural_influence">Cultural influence</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Art_of_War&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Cultural influence"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Bamboo_book_-_binding_-_UCR.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Bamboo_book_-_binding_-_UCR.jpg/250px-Bamboo_book_-_binding_-_UCR.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="289" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Bamboo_book_-_binding_-_UCR.jpg/500px-Bamboo_book_-_binding_-_UCR.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="1866" data-file-height="2160" /></a><figcaption>The beginning of <i>The Art of War</i> in a classical <a href="/wiki/Bamboo_and_wooden_slips" title="Bamboo and wooden slips">bamboo book</a> from the reign of the <a href="/wiki/Qianlong_Emperor" title="Qianlong Emperor">Qianlong Emperor</a></figcaption></figure>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Military_and_intelligence_applications">Military and intelligence applications</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Art_of_War&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Military and intelligence applications"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Wen_and_wu" title="Wen and wu">Wen and wu</a></div>
<p>Across <a href="/wiki/East_Asia" title="East Asia">East Asia</a>, <i>The Art of War</i> was part of the syllabus for potential candidates of military service examinations.
</p><p>During the <a href="/wiki/Sengoku_period" title="Sengoku period">Sengoku period</a> (<abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;">&#8201;1467–1568</span>), the Japanese <span title="Japanese-language romanization"><i lang="ja-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Daimy%C5%8D" class="mw-redirect" title="Daimyō">daimyō</a></i></span> <a href="/wiki/Takeda_Shingen" title="Takeda Shingen">Takeda Shingen</a> (1521–1573) is said to have become almost invincible in all battles without relying on <a href="/wiki/Gun" title="Gun">guns</a>, because he studied <i>The Art of War</i>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Griffith&#95;2007.&#95;p.150&#95;16-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Griffith_2007._p.150-16"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>16<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The book even gave him the inspiration for his famous battle standard <span title="Japanese-language romanization"><i lang="ja-Latn">"<a href="/wiki/F%C5%ABrinkazan" title="Fūrinkazan">Fūrinkazan</a>"</i></span> (Wind, Forest, Fire and Mountain), meaning fast as the wind, silent as a forest, ferocious as fire and immovable as a mountain.
</p><p>The translator <a href="/wiki/Samuel_B._Griffith" title="Samuel B. Griffith">Samuel B. Griffith</a> offers a chapter on "Sun Tzu and Mao Tse-Tung" where <i>The Art of War</i> is cited as influencing Mao's <i><a href="/wiki/On_Guerrilla_Warfare" class="mw-redirect" title="On Guerrilla Warfare">On Guerrilla Warfare</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/On_Protracted_War" title="On Protracted War">On the Protracted War</a></i> and <i>Strategic Problems of China's Revolutionary War</i>, and includes Mao's quote: "We must not belittle the saying in the book of Sun Wu Tzu, the great military expert of ancient China, 'Know your enemy and know yourself and you can fight a thousand battles without disaster.'"<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Griffith&#95;2007.&#95;p.150&#95;16-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Griffith_2007._p.150-16"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>16<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>During the <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_War" title="Vietnam War">Vietnam War</a>, some <a href="/wiki/Viet_Cong" title="Viet Cong">Viet Cong</a> officers extensively studied <i>The Art of War</i> and reportedly could recite entire passages from memory. General <a href="/wiki/V%C3%B5_Nguy%C3%AAn_Gi%C3%A1p" title="Võ Nguyên Giáp">Võ Nguyên Giáp</a> successfully implemented tactics described in <i>The Art of War</i> during the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Dien_Bien_Phu" title="Battle of Dien Bien Phu">Battle of Dien Bien Phu</a> ending major French involvement in Indochina and leading to the accords which partitioned Vietnam into North and South. General Giáp, later the main PVA military commander in the Vietnam War, was an avid student and practitioner of Sun Tzu's ideas.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-findarticles.com&#95;17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-findarticles.com-17"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>17<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Outside_East_Asia">Outside East Asia</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Art_of_War&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Outside East Asia"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>The United States' defeat in the Vietnam War, more than any other event, brought Sun Tzu to the attention of leaders of U.S. military theory.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-findarticles.com&#95;17-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-findarticles.com-17"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>17<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>18<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>19<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Department_of_the_Army" class="mw-redirect" title="Department of the Army">Department of the Army</a> in the United States, through its <a href="/wiki/United_States_Army_Command_and_General_Staff_College" title="United States Army Command and General Staff College">Command and General Staff College</a>, lists <i>The Art of War</i> as one example of a book that may be kept at a military unit's library.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>20<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <i>The Art of War</i> is listed on the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Marine_Corps" title="United States Marine Corps">US Marine Corps</a> Professional Reading Program (formerly known as the Commandant's Reading List). It is recommended reading for all United States Military Intelligence personnel.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>21<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <i>The Art of War</i> is also used as instructional material at the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Military_Academy" title="United States Military Academy">United States Military Academy</a> (commonly known as West Point), in the course Military Strategy (470).<sup id="cite&#95;ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>22<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It is also recommended reading for Officer cadets at the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Military_Academy,_Sandhurst" class="mw-redirect" title="Royal Military Academy, Sandhurst">Royal Military Academy, Sandhurst</a>. Some notable military leaders have stated the following about Sun Tzu and <i>The Art of War</i>:
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1244412712">.mw-parser-output .templatequote{overflow:hidden;margin:1em 0;padding:0 32px}.mw-parser-output .templatequotecite{line-height:1.5em;text-align:left;margin-top:0}@media(min-width:500px){.mw-parser-output .templatequotecite{padding-left:1.6em}}</style><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>I always kept a copy of The Art of War on my desk.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>23<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> – General <a href="/wiki/Douglas_MacArthur" title="Douglas MacArthur">Douglas MacArthur</a>, <a href="/wiki/General_of_the_Army_(United_States)" title="General of the Army (United States)">5 Star General</a> and <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Commander_for_the_Allied_Powers" title="Supreme Commander for the Allied Powers">Supreme Commander for the Allied Powers</a>.</p></blockquote>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1244412712" /><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>I have read The Art of War by Sun Tzu. He continues to influence both soldiers &amp; politicians.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>24<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> – General <a href="/wiki/Colin_Powell" title="Colin Powell">Colin Powell</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chairman_of_the_Joint_Chiefs_of_Staff" title="Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff">Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff</a>, <a href="/wiki/National_Security_Advisor_(United_States)" title="National Security Advisor (United States)">National Security Advisor</a>, and <a href="/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_State" title="United States Secretary of State">Secretary of State</a>.</p></blockquote>
<p>According to some authors, the strategy of <a href="/wiki/Disinformation" title="Disinformation">deception</a> from <i>The Art of War</i> was studied and widely used by the <a href="/wiki/KGB" title="KGB">KGB</a>: "I will force the enemy to take our strength for weakness, and our weakness for strength, and thus will turn his strength into weakness".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Albats&#95;25-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Albats-25"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>25<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Application_outside_the_military">Application outside the military</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Art_of_War&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Application outside the military"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>Some of the book's admirers claim that it has a variety of applications in a myriad of competitive non-military endeavors across the modern world including espionage, culture, politics, business, and sports.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>26<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-wp&#95;27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wp-27"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>27<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-UPI&#95;28-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UPI-28"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>28<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Business&#95;29-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Business-29"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>29<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Football&#95;30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Football-30"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>30<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Some business books have claimed to see metaphorical parallels from The Art of War to <a href="/wiki/Office_politics" class="mw-redirect" title="Office politics">office politics</a> and corporate business strategy.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>31<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>32<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>33<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Some Japanese companies make the book required reading for their key <a href="/wiki/Corporate_officer" class="mw-redirect" title="Corporate officer">executives</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>34<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Entrepreneurs and corporate executives have turned to it for inspiration and advice on how to succeed in competitive business situations. The book has also been applied to the field of education.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>35<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p><i>The Art of War</i> has been the subject of legal books<sup id="cite&#95;ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>36<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and legal articles on the trial process, including negotiation tactics and trial strategy.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>37<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>38<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>39<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>40<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The book <i><a href="/wiki/The_48_Laws_of_Power" title="The 48 Laws of Power">The 48 Laws of Power</a></i> by <a href="/wiki/Robert_Greene_(American_author)" title="Robert Greene (American author)">Robert Greene</a> has many quotations from <i>The Art of War</i>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>41<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p><i>The Art of War</i> has also been applied in sports. <a href="/wiki/National_Football_League" title="National Football League">National Football League</a> coach <a href="/wiki/Bill_Belichick" title="Bill Belichick">Bill Belichick</a>, record holder of the most <a href="/wiki/Super_Bowl" title="Super Bowl">Super Bowl</a> wins in history, has stated on multiple occasions his admiration for <i>The Art of War</i>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>42<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>43<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazilian</a> <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">association football</a> coach <a href="/wiki/Luiz_Felipe_Scolari" title="Luiz Felipe Scolari">Luiz Felipe Scolari</a> actively used <i>The Art of War</i> for Brazil's successful <a href="/wiki/2002_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2002 FIFA World Cup">2002 World Cup</a> campaign. During the tournament Scolari put passages of <i>The Art of War</i> underneath his players' doors at night.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>44<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>45<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p><i>Playing To Win</i> by <a href="/wiki/David_Sirlin" title="David Sirlin">David Sirlin</a> analyses applications of the ideas from <i>The Art of War</i> in modern esports.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>46<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <i>The Art of War</i> was released in 2014 as an <a href="/wiki/E-book" class="mw-redirect" title="E-book">e-book</a> companion alongside the Art of War <a href="/wiki/Downloadable_content" title="Downloadable content">DLC</a> for <a href="/wiki/Europa_Universalis_IV" title="Europa Universalis IV">Europa Universalis IV</a>, a PC strategy game by <a href="/wiki/Paradox_Development_Studios" class="mw-redirect" title="Paradox Development Studios">Paradox Development Studios</a>, with a foreword by Thomas Johansson.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Film_and_television">Film and television</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Art_of_War&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: Film and television"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p><i>The Art of War</i> and Sun Tzu have been referenced and quoted in many movies and television shows, including in the 1987 movie <i><a href="/wiki/Wall_Street_(1987_film)" title="Wall Street (1987 film)">Wall Street</a></i>, in which <a href="/wiki/Gordon_Gekko" title="Gordon Gekko">Gordon Gekko</a> (<a href="/wiki/Michael_Douglas" title="Michael Douglas">Michael Douglas</a>) frequently references it, and commends his protege, Bud Fox, for being able to quote a relevant passage from memory.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>47<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The 20th <i><a href="/wiki/James_Bond" title="James Bond">James Bond</a></i> film, <i><a href="/wiki/Die_Another_Day" title="Die Another Day">Die Another Day</a></i> (2002) also references <i>The Art of War</i> as the spiritual guide shared by Colonel Moon and his father.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>48<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In <i><a href="/wiki/The_Sopranos" title="The Sopranos">The Sopranos</a></i>, season 3, episode 8 ("He Is Risen"), <a href="/wiki/Jennifer_Melfi" title="Jennifer Melfi">Dr. Melfi</a> suggests to <a href="/wiki/Tony_Soprano" title="Tony Soprano">Tony Soprano</a> that he read the book.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>49<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In the <i><a href="/wiki/Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation" title="Star Trek: The Next Generation">Star Trek: The Next Generation</a></i> first-season episode "The Last Outpost", first officer <a href="/wiki/William_Riker" title="William Riker">William Riker</a> quotes <i>The Art of War</i>: "Fear is the true enemy, the only enemy". <a href="/wiki/Jean-Luc_Picard" title="Jean-Luc Picard">Captain Picard</a> expressed pleasure that Sun Tzu was still taught at <a href="/wiki/Starfleet_Academy" class="mw-redirect" title="Starfleet Academy">Starfleet Academy</a>. Later in the episode, a survivor from a long-dead nonhuman empire noted common aspects between his own people's wisdom and <i>The Art of War</i> with regard to knowing when and when not to fight.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>50<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p><i><a href="/wiki/The_Art_of_War_(film)" title="The Art of War (film)">The Art of War</a></i> is a 2000 action spy film directed by <a href="/wiki/Christian_Duguay_(director)" title="Christian Duguay (director)">Christian Duguay</a> and starring <a href="/wiki/Wesley_Snipes" title="Wesley Snipes">Wesley Snipes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Michael_Biehn" title="Michael Biehn">Michael Biehn</a>, <a href="/wiki/Anne_Archer" title="Anne Archer">Anne Archer</a> and <a href="/wiki/Donald_Sutherland" title="Donald Sutherland">Donald Sutherland</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>51<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Notable_translations">Notable translations</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Art_of_War&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: Notable translations"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<figure typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:The_Art_of_War_Running_Press.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/The_Art_of_War_Running_Press.jpg/250px-The_Art_of_War_Running_Press.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="176" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/The_Art_of_War_Running_Press.jpg/330px-The_Art_of_War_Running_Press.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/The_Art_of_War_Running_Press.jpg/490px-The_Art_of_War_Running_Press.jpg 2x" data-file-width="490" data-file-height="430" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Running_Press" title="Running Press">Running Press</a> <a href="/wiki/Miniature_book" title="Miniature book">miniature edition</a> of the 1994 Ralph D. Sawyer translation, printed in 2003</figcaption></figure>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="See_also">See also</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Art_of_War&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: See also"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1266661725">.mw-parser-output .portalbox{padding:0;margin:0.5em 0;display:table;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:175px;list-style:none}.mw-parser-output .portalborder{border:1px solid var(--border-color-base,#a2a9b1);padding:0.1em;background:var(--background-color-neutral-subtle,#f8f9fa)}.mw-parser-output .portalbox-entry{display:table-row;font-size:85%;line-height:110%;height:1.9em;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold}.mw-parser-output .portalbox-image{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em;vertical-align:middle;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .portalbox-link{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em 0.2em 0.2em 0.3em;vertical-align:middle}@media(min-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .portalleft{margin:0.5em 1em 0.5em 0}.mw-parser-output .portalright{clear:right;float:right;margin:0.5em 0 0.5em 1em}}</style><ul role="navigation" aria-label="Portals" class="noprint portalbox portalborder portalright">
<li class="portalbox-entry"><span class="portalbox-image"><span class="mw-image-border noviewer" typeof="mw:File"><span><img alt="flag" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Flag_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China.svg/40px-Flag_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China.svg.png" decoding="async" width="32" height="21" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Flag_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China.svg/60px-Flag_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Flag_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China.svg/120px-Flag_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="900" data-file-height="600" <li id="cite&#95;note-9"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-9">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Liu_An" title="Liu An">Liu An</a> (original compiler), <a href="/wiki/Xu_Shen" title="Xu Shen">Xu Shen</a> (annotator). <i><a href="/wiki/Huainanzi" title="Huainanzi">Huainan Honglie</a> (Annotated)</i>, "Survey Obscurities". Main text: 「夫死生同域，不可脅陵，勇<b>武</b>一人，為三軍雄。」; Major et al.'s (2010) translation: "One for whom death and life are the same territory, who cannot be threatened, such a single brave <b>warrior</b> is the hero of the Three Armies."; <a href="/wiki/Siku_Quanshu" title="Siku Quanshu">Siku Quanshu</a> version. vols. 4-7, <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://ctext.org/library.pl?if=en&amp;file=67848&amp;page=96#%E6%AD%A6%E5%A3%AB%E4%B9%9F%E6%B1%9F%E6%B7%AE%E9%96%93%E8%AC%82%E5%A3%AB%E7%99%BD%E6%AD%A6">p. 96 of 160</a> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20230415095028/https://ctext.org/library.pl?if=en&amp;file=67848&amp;page=96#%E6%AD%A6%E5%A3%AB%E4%B9%9F%E6%B1%9F%E6%B7%AE%E9%96%93%E8%AC%82%E5%A3%AB%E7%99%BD%E6%AD%A6">Archived</a> 15 April 2023 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a>; Annotation: 「<b>武</b>士也；江淮間謂士曰<b>武</b>。」</span>

					<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading mw-first-heading"><i>Romance of the Three Kingdoms</i></h1>
							
<div id="p-lang-btn" class="vector-dropdown mw-portlet mw-portlet-lang"  >
	<input type="checkbox" id="p-lang-btn-checkbox" role="button" aria-haspopup="true" data-event-name="ui.dropdown-p-lang-btn" class="vector-dropdown-checkbox mw-interlanguage-selector" aria-label="Go to an article in another language. Available in 59 languages"   >
	<label id="p-lang-btn-label" for="p-lang-btn-checkbox" class="vector-dropdown-label cdx-button cdx-button--fake-button cdx-button--fake-button--enabled cdx-button--weight-quiet cdx-button--action-progressive mw-portlet-lang-heading-59" aria-hidden="true"  ><span class="vector-icon mw-ui-icon-language-progressive mw-ui-icon-wikimedia-language-progressive"></span>

<span class="vector-dropdown-label-text">59 languages</span>
	</label>
	<div class="vector-dropdown-content">

		<div class="vector-menu-content">
			
			<ul class="vector-menu-content-list">
				
				<li class="interlanguage-link interwiki-af mw-list-item"><a href="https://af.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roman_van_die_drie_koninkryke" title="Roman van die drie koninkryke – Afrikaans" lang="af" class="interlanguage-link interwiki-ar mw-list-item"><a href="https://ar.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D8%B1%D9%88%D9%85%D8%A7%D9%86%D8%B3%D9%8A%D8%A9_%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D9%85%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%83_%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AB%D9%84%D8%A7%D8%AB_(%D8%B1%D9%88%D8%A7%D9%8A%D8%A9)" title="رومانسية الممالك الثلاث (رواية) – Arabic" lang="ar" hreflang="ar" data-title="رومانسية الممالك الثلاث (رواية)" data-language-autonym="العربية" data-language-local-name="Arabic" class="interlanguage-link-target"><span>العربية</span></a></li><li class="interlanguage-link interwiki-ast mw-list-item"><a href="https://ast.wikipedia.org/wiki/Romance_de_los_Tr%C3%A9s_Reinos" title="Romance de los Trés Reinos – Asturian" lang="ast" hreflang="ast" data-title="Romance de los Trés Reinos" data-language-autonym="Asturianu" data-language-local-name="Asturian" class="interlanguage-link-target"><span>Asturianu</span></a></li><li class="interlanguage-link interwiki-zh-min-nan mw-list-item"><a href="https://zh-min-nan.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sam-kok_I%C3%A1n-g%C4%AB" title="Sam-kok Ián-gī – Minnan" lang="nan" hreflang="nan" data-title="Sam-kok Ián-gī" data-language-autonym="閩南語 / Bân-lâm-gí" 					<div id="mw-content-text" class="mw-body-content"><div class="mw-subjectpageheader">
</div><div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" lang="en" dir="ltr"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">14th-century Chinese historical novel</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1320445320">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}@media print{body.ns-0 .mw-parser-output .hatnote{display:none!important}}</style><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">This article is about the historical novel. For other uses, see <a href="/wiki/Romance_of_the_Three_Kingdoms_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="Romance of the Three Kingdoms (disambiguation)">Romance of the Three Kingdoms (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">

</p>

src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/%E6%96%B0%E5%88%8A%E6%A0%A1%E6%AD%A3%E5%8F%A4%E6%9C%AC%E5%A4%A7%E5%AD%97%E9%9F%B3%E9%87%8A%E4%B8%89%E5%9B%BD%E5%BF%97%E9%80%9A%E4%BF%97%E6%BC%94%E4%B9%89_%E6%98%8E%E4%B8%87%E5%8E%86%E5%8D%81%E4%B9%9D%E5%B9%B4%E4%B9%A6%E6%9E%97%E5%91%A8%E6%9B%B0%E6%A0%A1%E5%88%8A%E6%9C%AC_002.jpg/330px-%E6%96%B0%E5%88%8A%E6%A0%A1%E6%AD%A3%E5%8F%A4%E6%9C%AC%E5%A4%A7%E5%AD%97%E9%9F%B3%E9%87%8A%E4%B8%89%E5%9B%BD%E5%BF%97%E9%80%9A%E4%BF%97%E6%BC%94%E4%B9%89_%E6%98%8E%E4%B8%87%E5%8E%86%E5%8D%81%E4%B9%9D%E5%B9%B4%E4%B9%A6%E6%9E%97%E5%91%A8%E6%9B%B0%E6%A0%A1%E5%88%8A%E6%9C%AC_002.jpg" decoding="async" width="292" height="271" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/%E6%96%B0%E5%88%8A%E6%A0%A1%E6%AD%A3%E5%8F%A4%E6%9C%AC%E5%A4%A7%E5%AD%97%E9%9F%B3%E9%87%8A%E4%B8%89%E5%9B%BD%E5%BF%97%E9%80%9A%E4%BF%97%E6%BC%94%E4%B9%89_%E6%98%8E%E4%B8%87%E5%8E%86%E5%8D%81%E4%B9%9D%E5%B9%B4%E4%B9%A6%E6%9E%97%E5%91%A8%E6%9B%B0%E6%A0%A1%E5%88%8A%E6%9C%AC_002.jpg/500px-%E6%96%B0%E5%88%8A%E6%A0%A1%E6%AD%A3%E5%8F%A4%E6%9C%AC%E5%A4%A7%E5%AD%97%E9%9F%B3%E9%87%8A%E4%B8%89%E5%9B%BD%E5%BF%97%E9%80%9A%E4%BF%97%E6%BC%94%E4%B9%89_%E6%98%8E%E4%B8%87%E5%8E%86%E5%8D%81%E4%B9%9D%E5%B9%B4%E4%B9%A6%E6%9E%97%E5%91%A8%E6%9B%B0%E6%A0%A1%E5%88%8A%E6%9C%AC_002.jpg iè-nyî</span></span></td></tr><tr><th colspan="2" class="infobox-header" style="color: #202122;background-color: #dcffc9;"><a href="/wiki/Cantonese" title="Cantonese">Yue: lang="nan-Latn">Sam-kok ián-gī</span></span></td></tr></tbody></table></td><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1316064257" /></tr><tr style="display:none"><td colspan="2">
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><i><b>Romance of the Three Kingdoms</b></i> (<a href="/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters" title="Traditional Chinese characters">traditional Chinese</a>&#58; <span lang="zh-Hant">三國演義</span>; <a href="/wiki/Simplified_Chinese_characters" title="Simplified Chinese characters">simplified Chinese</a>&#58; <span lang="zh-Hans">三国演义</span>; <a href="/wiki/Pinyin" title="Pinyin">pinyin</a>&#58; <i><span lang="zh-Latn">Sānguó Yǎnyì</span></i>) is a 14th-century <a href="/wiki/Historical_novel" class="mw-redirect" title="Historical novel">historical novel</a> attributed to <a href="/wiki/Luo_Guanzhong" title="Luo Guanzhong">Luo Guanzhong</a>. It is set in the turbulent years towards the <a href="/wiki/End_of_the_Han_dynasty" title="End of the Han dynasty">end of the Han dynasty</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Three_kingdoms_(China)" class="mw-redirect" title="Three kingdoms (China)">Three Kingdoms</a> period in <a href="/wiki/History_of_China" title="History of China">Chinese history</a>, starting in 184 CE and ending with the reunification of the <a href="/wiki/China_proper" title="China proper">land</a> in 280 by the <a href="/wiki/Jin_dynasty_(266%E2%80%93420)" title="Jin dynasty (266–420)">Western Jin</a>. The novel is based primarily on the <i><a href="/wiki/Records_of_the_Three_Kingdoms" title="Records of the Three Kingdoms">Records of the Three Kingdoms</a></i>, written by <a href="/wiki/Chen_Shou" title="Chen Shou">Chen Shou</a> in the 3rd century.
</p><p>The story–part historical and part fictional–romanticises and dramatises the lives of lords and their retainers, who tried to supplant the dwindling <a href="/wiki/Han_dynasty" title="Han dynasty">Han dynasty</a> or restore it. While the novel follows hundreds of characters, the focus is mainly on the three power blocs that emerged from the remnants of the Han dynasty, and would eventually form the three states of <a href="/wiki/Cao_Wei" title="Cao Wei">Cao Wei</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shu_Han" title="Shu Han">Shu Han</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Wu" title="Eastern Wu">Eastern Wu</a>. The novel deals with the plots, personal and military battles, intrigues, and struggles of these states to achieve dominance for almost 100 years.
</p><p><i>Romance of the Three Kingdoms</i> is acclaimed as one of the <a href="/wiki/Classic_Chinese_Novels" title="Classic Chinese Novels">Four Great Classic Novels</a> of <a href="/wiki/Chinese_literature" title="Chinese literature">Chinese literature</a>; it has a total of 800,000 words and nearly a thousand dramatic characters (mostly historical) in 120 chapters.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-roberts940&#95;1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-roberts940-1"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>1<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The novel is among the most beloved works of literature in <a href="/wiki/East_Asia" title="East Asia">East Asia</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>2<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and its literary influence in the region has been compared to that of the works of <a href="/wiki/William_Shakespeare" title="William Shakespeare">Shakespeare</a> on <a href="/wiki/English_literature" title="English literature">English literature</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>3<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Its impact is also extensive in <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a>, with many of its characters becoming household names there.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>4<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>5<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>6<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It is arguably the most widely read historical novel in late imperial and modern China.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>7<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Herbert_Giles" title="Herbert Giles">Herbert Giles</a> stated that among the Chinese themselves, this is regarded as the greatest of all their novels.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>8<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<meta property="mw:PageProp/toc" />
