<figure typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/w/index.php?title=File:NAJDA-%E9%99%84001-0008_%E6%96%B0%E5%88%8A%E6%A0%A1%E6%AD%A3%E5%8F%A4%E6%9C%AC%E5%A4%A7%E5%AD%97%E9%9F%B3%E9%87%88%E4%B8%89%E5%9B%BD%E5%BF%97%E9%80%9A%E4%BF%97%E6%BC%94%E7%BE%A95.pdf&amp;page=30" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/NAJDA-%E9%99%84001-0008_%E6%96%B0%E5%88%8A%E6%A0%A1%E6%AD%A3%E5%8F%A4%E6%9C%AC%E5%A4%A7%E5%AD%97%E9%9F%B3%E9%87%88%E4%B8%89%E5%9B%BD%E5%BF%97%E9%80%9A%E4%BF%97%E6%BC%94%E7%BE%A95.pdf/page30-272px-NAJDA-%E9%99%84001-0008_%E6%96%B0%E5%88%8A%E6%A0%A1%E6%AD%A3%E5%8F%A4%E6%9C%AC%E5%A4%A7%E5%AD%97%E9%9F%B3%E9%87%88%E4%B8%89%E5%9B%BD%E5%BF%97%E9%80%9A%E4%BF%97%E6%BC%94%E7%BE%A95.pdf.jpg" decoding="async" width="272" height="215" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/NAJDA-%E9%99%84001-0008_%E6%96%B0%E5%88%8A%E6%A0%A1%E6%AD%A3%E5%8F%A4%E6%9C%AC%E5%A4%A7%E5%AD%97%E9%9F%B3%E9%87%88%E4%B8%89%E5%9B%BD%E5%BF%97%E9%80%9A%E4%BF%97%E6%BC%94%E7%BE%A95.pdf/page30-408px-NAJDA-%E9%99%84001-0008_%E6%96%B0%E5%88%8A%E6%A0%A1%E6%AD%A3%E5%8F%A4%E6%9C%AC%E5%A4%A7%E5%AD%97%E9%9F%B3%E9%87%88%E4%B8%89%E5%9B%BD%E5%BF%97%E9%80%9A%E4%BF%97%E6%BC%94%E7%BE%A95.pdf.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/NAJDA-%E9%99%84001-0008_%E6%96%B0%E5%88%8A%E6%A0%A1%E6%AD%A3%E5%8F%A4%E6%9C%AC%E5%A4%A7%E5%AD%97%E9%9F%B3%E9%87%88%E4%B8%89%E5%9B%BD%E5%BF%97%E9%80%9A%E4%BF%97%E6%BC%94%E7%BE%A95.pdf/page30-544px-NAJDA-%E9%99%84001-0008_%E6%96%B0%E5%88%8A%E6%A0%A1%E6%AD%A3%E5%8F%A4%E6%9C%AC%E5%A4%A7%E5%AD%97%E9%9F%B3%E9%87%88%E4%B8%89%E5%9B%BD%E5%BF%97%E9%80%9A%E4%BF%97%E6%BC%94%E7%BE%A95.pdf.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2325" data-file-height="1837" /></a><figcaption>Pages from a printed edition of the novel, volume five</figcaption></figure>
<figure typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/w/index.php?title=File:WUL-he21_03536_%E6%9D%8E%E5%8D%93%E5%90%BE%E5%85%88%E7%94%9F%E6%89%B9%E8%A9%95%E4%B8%89%E5%9C%8B%E5%BF%97_01.pdf&amp;page=32" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/WUL-he21_03536_%E6%9D%8E%E5%8D%93%E5%90%BE%E5%85%88%E7%94%9F%E6%89%B9%E8%A9%95%E4%B8%89%E5%9C%8B%E5%BF%97_01.pdf/page32-272px-WUL-he21_03536_%E6%9D%8E%E5%8D%93%E5%90%BE%E5%85%88%E7%94%9F%E6%89%B9%E8%A9%95%E4%B8%89%E5%9C%8B%E5%BF%97_01.pdf.jpg" decoding="async" width="272" height="181" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/WUL-he21_03536_%E6%9D%8E%E5%8D%93%E5%90%BE%E5%85%88%E7%94%9F%E6%89%B9%E8%A9%95%E4%B8%89%E5%9C%8B%E5%BF%97_01.pdf/page32-408px-WUL-he21_03536_%E6%9D%8E%E5%8D%93%E5%90%BE%E5%85%88%E7%94%9F%E6%89%B9%E8%A9%95%E4%B8%89%E5%9C%8B%E5%BF%97_01.pdf.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/WUL-he21_03536_%E6%9D%8E%E5%8D%93%E5%90%BE%E5%85%88%E7%94%9F%E6%89%B9%E8%A9%95%E4%B8%89%E5%9C%8B%E5%BF%97_01.pdf/page32-544px-WUL-he21_03536_%E6%9D%8E%E5%8D%93%E5%90%BE%E5%85%88%E7%94%9F%E6%89%B9%E8%A9%95%E4%B8%89%E5%9C%8B%E5%BF%97_01.pdf.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5400" data-file-height="3600" /></a><figcaption>The beginning chapter lists from  Li Zhuowu's commentary edition (late Ming dynasty) of the novel, volume one</figcaption></figure>
<p>Stories about the heroes of the Three Kingdoms were the basis of entertainment dating back to the <a href="/wiki/Sui_dynasty" title="Sui dynasty">Sui</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tang_dynasty" title="Tang dynasty">Tang dynasty</a> (6th–10th centuries). By the <a href="/wiki/Song_dynasty" title="Song dynasty">Song dynasty</a> (10th–13th centuries), records mention professional <a href="/wiki/Oral_storytelling" title="Oral storytelling">oral storytellers</a> who specialized in tales of the Three Kingdoms heroes.  The earliest written work to combine these stories was a <a href="/wiki/Pinghua_(storytelling)" class="mw-redirect" title="Pinghua (storytelling)"><i>pinghua</i></a> named <i><a href="/wiki/Sanguozhi_Pinghua" title="Sanguozhi Pinghua">Sanguozhi Pinghua</a></i> published sometime between 1321 and 1323.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Plaks&#95;9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Plaks-9"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>9<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Expansion_of_the_history">Expansion of the history</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_of_the_Three_Kingdoms&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Expansion of the history"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p><i>Romance of the Three Kingdoms</i> is traditionally attributed to <a href="/wiki/Luo_Guanzhong" title="Luo Guanzhong">Luo Guanzhong</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-taylor1998&#95;10-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-taylor1998-10"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>10<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> a playwright who lived sometime between 1315 and 1400 (late <a href="/wiki/Yuan_dynasty" title="Yuan dynasty">Yuan</a> to early <a href="/wiki/Ming_dynasty" title="Ming dynasty">Ming</a> period) known for compiling historical plays in styles which were prevalent during the Yuan period.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-:0&#95;11-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-11"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>11<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It was first printed in 1522<sup id="cite&#95;ref-:0&#95;11-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-11"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>11<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> as <i>Sanguozhi Tongsu Yanyi</i> (<span lang="zh-Hant">三國志通俗演義</span>, <i>Popular Romance of the Records of the Three Kingdoms</i>) in an edition which bore a preface dated 1494.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-AfterwordRoberts&#95;12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AfterwordRoberts-12"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>12<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The text may well have circulated before either date in handwritten manuscripts.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-AfterwordRoberts&#95;12-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AfterwordRoberts-12"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>12<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Regardless of when it was written or whether Luo was the writer, the author made use of several available historical records, primarily the <i><a href="/wiki/Records_of_the_Three_Kingdoms" title="Records of the Three Kingdoms">Records of the Three Kingdoms</a></i> compiled by <a href="/wiki/Chen_Shou" title="Chen Shou">Chen Shou</a> in the 3rd century. The <i>Records of the Three Kingdoms</i> covered events ranging from the <a href="/wiki/Yellow_Turban_Rebellion" title="Yellow Turban Rebellion">Yellow Turban Rebellion</a> in 184 to the unification of the Three Kingdoms under the <a href="/wiki/Jin_dynasty_(265-420)" class="mw-redirect" title="Jin dynasty (265-420)">Jin dynasty</a> in 280. The novel also includes material from <a href="/wiki/Tang_dynasty" title="Tang dynasty">Tang dynasty</a> poetic works, Yuan dynasty operas and his own personal interpretation of elements such as virtue and legitimacy. The author combined this historical knowledge with his own storytelling skills to create a rich tapestry of personalities.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>13<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Recensions_and_standardised_text">Recensions and standardised text</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_of_the_Three_Kingdoms&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Recensions and standardised text"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>Luo Guanzhong's version in 24 volumes, known as the <i>Sanguozhi Tongsu Yanyi</i>, is now held in the <a href="/wiki/Shanghai_Library" title="Shanghai Library">Shanghai Library</a> in China, <a href="/wiki/Tenri_Central_Library" title="Tenri Central Library">Tenri Central Library</a> in Japan, and several other major libraries. Various 10-volume, 12-volume and 20-volume <a href="/wiki/Recension" title="Recension">recensions</a> of Luo's text, made between 1522 and 1690, are also held at libraries around the world. However, the standard text familiar to general readers is a recension by Mao Lun and his son <a href="/wiki/Mao_Zonggang" title="Mao Zonggang">Mao Zonggang</a>.
</p><p>At the end of the Ming dynasty, "Li Zhuowu" added commentary to the Luo version, which expanded its circulation and influence.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Jin&#95;Hui-jing&#95;14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jin_Hui-jing-14"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>14<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> 
While Li Zhuowu was the art name of <a href="/wiki/Li_Zhi_(philosopher)" title="Li Zhi (philosopher)">Li Zhi</a>, the commentary was likely written by an imposter (Ye Zhou).<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Hegel&#95;15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hegel-15"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>15<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 194">&#58;&#8202;194&#8202;</span></sup>
Nevertheless, it is consistent with the anti-authoritarian views of the historical Li Shi. The persona of Li Zhuowu "is presented as a reader who appreciates the text, an interpreter and appropriate model for readers unfamiliar with the form".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Hegel&#95;15-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hegel-15"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>15<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Pages: 189, 194">&#58;&#8202;189,&#8202;194&#8202;</span></sup>
</p><p>In addition to <i>quandian</i> (圈點; placement of small circles and dots to the right of the text to indicate emphasis), Li Zhuowu included interlineal comments and comments at the end of chapters. The interlineal comments, written with smaller characters alongside the novel text, were typically short exclamations.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Hegel&#95;15-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hegel-15"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>15<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Pages: 189">&#58;&#8202;189&#8202;</span></sup> For example, when Liu Bei is described in the novel text as not fond of reading, Li exclaims: "Taking no joy in reading is the mark of a hero".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Hegel&#95;15-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hegel-15"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>15<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Pages: 195">&#58;&#8202;195&#8202;</span></sup> The comments at the end of chapters were longer and were often ironic and conversational. For example, there is a comment in one of the later chapters about the relevance of the novel as follows: “Since [similar events] were narrated previously, this does nothing more than change the names to pad out the narrative. How irritating! This is why it is an ‘elaboration’ [yanyi] of the <i>Chronicles of the Three Kingdoms</i> [Sanguo zhi]. Laughable!”. However, another comment emphasizes the need for elaboration: "Even so, this is a 'popular romance' and not official history. If it were not so [embellished], then how could it be 'popular'? ".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Hegel&#95;15-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hegel-15"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>15<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Pages: 196–197">&#58;&#8202;196–197&#8202;</span></sup>
</p><p>This version of the novel contained numerous illustrations of scenes depicted in the text. Illustrations were a near ubiquitous feature of late Ming dynasty books. The flourishing of book illustrations at the time apparently resulted from increased prosperity of the elite which allowed them greater opportunity to read for fun.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Hegel-book&#95;illustrations&#95;16-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hegel-book_illustrations-16"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>16<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 291">&#58;&#8202;291&#8202;</span></sup>
</p><p>In 1591, Zhou Yue, owner of the Wanjuanlou Bookshop, published his edited version of the novel with the title, <i>A Newly Proofed Edition of the Romance of the Three Kingdoms</i>. It contained 250 chapters in 12 volumes and included 240 2-page illustrations. Each illustration is flanked by couplets, each line with 11 characters. These were composed by literati and described the scene in a poetic manner.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Digital&#95;Taiwan&#95;17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Digital_Taiwan-17"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>17<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> For example, the illustration "Guan Yu traveled one thousand <i>li</i> alone." depicts Guan Yu as he begins a journey to rejoin his sworn brother, Liu Bei. It includes the couplet (loose translation), "Loyal and righteous, he returned to his former master alone with a single sword; the hero, moved by his loyalty, was willing to travel to his beloved master a thousand li away."<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Collectors&#95;Association&#95;18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Collectors_Association-18"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>18<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Zheng_Zhenduo" title="Zheng Zhenduo">Zheng Zhenduo</a> commented that the prints are bold and vigorous, and while somewhat crude, they are ultimately far superior to the 'delicate' prints in other works.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Collectors&#95;Association&#95;18-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Collectors_Association-18"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>18<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> A modern reviewer noted that "the lines of the illustrations are energetic, the characters clearly outlined, with vivid and dynamic depictions of action, especially for those climatic chapters".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Digital&#95;Taiwan&#95;17-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Digital_Taiwan-17"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>17<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> However, the illustrations appear to function more for decoration than to advance the plot.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Hegel-book&#95;illustrations&#95;16-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hegel-book_illustrations-16"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>16<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 184">&#58;&#8202;184&#8202;</span></sup>
</p><p>At the time it was published, the Zhou Yue illustrated edition was the most popular version of the novel.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Digital&#95;Taiwan&#95;17-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Digital_Taiwan-17"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>17<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> However, the standard text currently familiar to general readers is a recension by Mao Lun and his son Mao Zonggang. Historical editions of the Mao version vary with respect to the illustrations included and these are typically omitted from modern translations. The 1802 edition at the Harvard-Yenching Library, available online, has 12 portrait-style illustrations  at the commencement of Volume 1.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>19<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
The 1888 edition, <i>Mao Shenshang's Critique of the Romance of the Three Kingdoms/ Most Brilliant Writing of Talent and Taste/ Saoye shanfang edition</i>, National Palace Museum collection, has 40 such illustrations. These depict the main characters together with text highlighting their role in the narrative.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Digital&#95;Taiwan&#95;17-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Digital_Taiwan-17"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>17<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> These editions were variations of the work first published in the 17th century.
</p><p>In the 1660s, during the reign of the <a href="/wiki/Kangxi_Emperor" title="Kangxi Emperor">Kangxi Emperor</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Qing_dynasty" title="Qing dynasty">Qing dynasty</a>, Mao Lun and Mao Zonggang significantly edited the text, fitting it into 120 chapters and abbreviating the title to <i>Sanguozhi Yanyi</i>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-roberts980&#95;20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-roberts980-20"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>20<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The text was reduced from 900,000 to 750,000 characters; significant editing was done for narrative flow; use of third-party poems was reduced and shifted from conventional verse to finer pieces; and most passages praising <a href="/wiki/Cao_Cao" title="Cao Cao">Cao Cao</a>'s advisers and generals were removed.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-roberts965&#95;21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-roberts965-21"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>21<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Scholars have long debated whether the Maos' viewpoint was anti-Qing (identifying <a href="/wiki/Southern_Ming" title="Southern Ming">Southern Ming</a> remnants with <a href="/wiki/Shu-Han" class="mw-redirect" title="Shu-Han">Shu-Han</a>) or pro-Qing.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-roberts967&#95;71&#95;22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-roberts967_71-22"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>22<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Commentary is estimated to be almost two-thirds as large as the bulk of the text.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-How&#95;to&#95;Read&#95;23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-How_to_Read-23"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>23<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 151">&#58;&#8202;151&#8202;</span></sup> The Mao introductory essay titled "How to Read <i>The Romance of the Three Kingdoms</i>" begins:
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1244412712">.mw-parser-output .templatequote{overflow:hidden;margin:1em 0;padding:0 32px}.mw-parser-output .templatequotecite{line-height:1.5em;text-align:left;margin-top:0}@media(min-width:500px){.mw-parser-output .templatequotecite{padding-left:1.6em}}</style><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>Readers of the <i>Chronicle of the Three Kingdoms</i> should be aware of the distinction between states that rule by legitimate succession, those that rule during an intercalary period, and those that rule illegitimately. ... Why should the state of Wei [established by Cao Cao] not be accorded legitimacy? According to territorial criteria, control of the Central Plain might be sufficient to establish legitimacy; but according to the criterion of principle, legitimacy should be accorded to the Liu clan [the ruling house of the Han dynasty, 202 B.C.-220 A.D.]. The criterion of principle ought to take precedence over territorial consideration.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-How&#95;to&#95;Read&#95;23-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-How_to_Read-23"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>23<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 152">&#58;&#8202;152&#8202;</span></sup></p></blockquote>
<p>The famous opening lines of the novel, "<a href="/wiki/Tianxia" title="Tianxia">The empire</a>, long divided, must unite; long united, must divide. Thus it has ever been" (<span lang="zh-Hant">話說天下大勢．分久必合，合久必分</span>),<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTELuo19915&#95;24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELuo19915-24"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>24<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> long understood to be Luo's introduction and cyclical philosophy, were actually added by the Maos in their substantially revised edition of 1679.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>25<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> None of the earlier editions contained this phrase. In addition, Mao also added <a href="/wiki/Yang_Shen" title="Yang Shen">Yang Shen</a>'s <i><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.vincentpoon.com/the-immortals-by-the-river-----------------.html">The Immortals by the River</a></i> as the famous introductory poem (which began with "The gushing waters of the <a href="/wiki/Yangzi_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Yangzi River">Yangzi River</a> pour and disappear into the East", <span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh-Hant">滾滾長江東逝水</span></span>) to the novel.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>26<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The earlier editions, moreover, spend less time on the process of division, which they found painful, and far more time on the process of reunification and the struggles of the heroes who sacrificed for it.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>27<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<ul class="gallery mw-gallery-packed">
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 187.33333333333px">
			<div class="thumb" style="width: 185.33333333333px;"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Three_Kingdoms_Li_Zhuowu_edition_-_example_commentary.jpg" class="mw-file-description" title="Pages from chapter one of Li Zhuowu&#39;s (late Ming dynasty) commentary edition of the novel, which includes Li&#39;s comments describing Liu Bei, e.g. &quot;He is a hero in the world&quot;"><img alt="Pages from chapter one of Li Zhuowu&#39;s (late Ming dynasty) commentary edition of the novel, which includes Li&#39;s comments describing Liu Bei, e.g. &quot;He is a hero in the world&quot;" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Three_Kingdoms_Li_Zhuowu_edition_-_example_commentary.jpg/330px-Three_Kingdoms_Li_Zhuowu_edition_-_example_commentary.jpg" decoding="async" width="186" height="159" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Three_Kingdoms_Li_Zhuowu_edition_-_example_commentary.jpg/500px-Three_Kingdoms_Li_Zhuowu_edition_-_example_commentary.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Three_Kingdoms_Li_Zhuowu_edition_-_example_commentary.jpg/960px-Three_Kingdoms_Li_Zhuowu_edition_-_example_commentary.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1695" data-file-height="1452" /></a></span></div>
			<div class="gallerytext">Pages from chapter one of Li Zhuowu's (late Ming dynasty) commentary edition of the novel, which includes Li's comments describing Liu Bei, e.g. "He is a hero in the world"</div>
		</li>
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 188px">
			<div class="thumb" style="width: 186px;"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Three_Kingdoms_Li_Zhuowu_edition_%E2%80%93_two_illustrations.jpg" class="mw-file-description" title="Illustrations from Li Zhuowu&#39;s commentary edition: &quot;Dong Zhuo burns the Changle Palace [in Luoyang]&quot; (left) and &quot;Three heroes [Liu Bei, Guan Yu, and Zhang Fei] fight Lü Bu&quot; (right)"><img alt="Illustrations from Li Zhuowu&#39;s commentary edition: &quot;Dong Zhuo burns the Changle Palace [in Luoyang]&quot; (left) and &quot;Three heroes [Liu Bei, Guan Yu, and Zhang Fei] fight Lü Bu&quot; (right)" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Three_Kingdoms_Li_Zhuowu_edition_%E2%80%93_two_illustrations.jpg/330px-Three_Kingdoms_Li_Zhuowu_edition_%E2%80%93_two_illustrations.jpg" decoding="async" width="186" height="159" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Three_Kingdoms_Li_Zhuowu_edition_%E2%80%93_two_illustrations.jpg/500px-Three_Kingdoms_Li_Zhuowu_edition_%E2%80%93_two_illustrations.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Three_Kingdoms_Li_Zhuowu_edition_%E2%80%93_two_illustrations.jpg/960px-Three_Kingdoms_Li_Zhuowu_edition_%E2%80%93_two_illustrations.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1713" data-file-height="1464" /></a></span></div>
			<div class="gallerytext">Illustrations from Li Zhuowu's commentary edition: "Dong Zhuo burns the Changle Palace [in Luoyang]" (left) and "Three heroes [Liu Bei, Guan Yu, and Zhang Fei] fight Lü Bu" (right)</div>
		</li>
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 172.66666666667px">
			<div class="thumb" style="width: 170.66666666667px;"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:%E6%96%B0%E5%88%8A%E6%A0%A1%E6%AD%A3%E5%8F%A4%E6%9C%AC%E5%A4%A7%E5%AD%97%E9%9F%B3%E9%87%8A%E4%B8%89%E5%9B%BD%E5%BF%97%E9%80%9A%E4%BF%97%E6%BC%94%E4%B9%89_%E6%98%8E%E4%B8%87%E5%8E%86%E5%8D%81%E4%B9%9D%E5%B9%B4%E4%B9%A6%E6%9E%97%E5%91%A8%E6%9B%B0%E6%A0%A1%E5%88%8A%E6%9C%AC_055.jpg" class="mw-file-description" title="A 2-page illustration from Zhou Yue&#39;s 1591 edition: &quot;Guan Yu Traveled One Thousand Li Alone&quot;. Guan Yu is depicted on his horse Red Hare" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/%E6%96%B0%E5%88%8A%E6%A0%A1%E6%AD%A3%E5%8F%A4%E6%9C%AC%E5%A4%A7%E5%AD%97%E9%9F%B3%E9%87%8A%E4%B8%89%E5%9B%BD%E5%BF%97%E9%80%9A%E4%BF%97%E6%BC%94%E4%B9%89_%E6%98%8E%E4%B8%87%E5%8E%86%E5%8D%81%E4%B9%9D%E5%B9%B4%E4%B9%A6%E6%9E%97%E5%91%A8%E6%9B%B0%E6%A0%A1%E5%88%8A%E6%9C%AC_055.jpg/330px-%E6%96%B0%E5%88%8A%E6%A0%A1%E6%AD%A3%E5%8F%A4%E6%9C%AC%E5%A4%A7%E5%AD%97%E9%9F%B3%E9%87%8A%E4%B8%89%E5%9B%BD%E5%BF%97%E9%80%9A%E4%BF%97%E6%BC%94%E4%B9%89_%E6%98%8E%E4%B8%87%E5%8E%86%E5%8D%81%E4%B9%9D%E5%B9%B4%E4%B9%A6%E6%9E%97%E5%91%A8%E6%9B%B0%E6%A0%A1%E5%88%8A%E6%9C%AC_055.jpg" decoding="async" width="171" height="159" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/%E6%96%B0%E5%88%8A%E6%A0%A1%E6%AD%A3%E5%8F%A4%E6%9C%AC%E5%A4%A7%E5%AD%97%E9%9F%B3%E9%87%8A%E4%B8%89%E5%9B%BD%E5%BF%97%E9%80%9A%E4%BF%97%E6%BC%94%E4%B9%89_%E6%98%8E%E4%B8%87%E5%8E%86%E5%8D%81%E4%B9%9D%E5%B9%B4%E4%B9%A6%E6%9E%97%E5%91%A8%E6%9B%B0%E6%A0%A1%E5%88%8A%E6%9C%AC_055.jpg/500px-%E6%96%B0%E5%88%8A%E6%A0%A1%E6%AD%A3%E5%8F%A4%E6%9C%AC%E5%A4%A7%E5%AD%97%E9%9F%B3%E9%87%8A%E4%B8%89%E5%9B%BD%E5%BF%97%E9%80%9A%E4%BF%97%E6%BC%94%E4%B9%89_%E6%98%8E%E4%B8%87%E5%8E%86%E5%8D%81%E4%B9%9D%E5%B9%B4%E4%B9%A6%E6%9E%97%E5%91%A8%E6%9B%B0%E6%A0%A1%E5%88%8A%E6%9C%AC_055.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/%E6%96%B0%E5%88%8A%E6%A0%A1%E6%AD%A3%E5%8F%A4%E6%9C%AC%E5%A4%A7%E5%AD%97%E9%9F%B3%E9%87%8A%E4%B8%89%E5%9B%BD%E5%BF%97%E9%80%9A%E4%BF%97%E6%BC%94%E4%B9%89_%E6%98%8E%E4%B8%87%E5%8E%86%E5%8D%81%E4%B9%9D%E5%B9%B4%E4%B9%A6%E6%9E%97%E5%91%A8%E6%9B%B0%E6%A0%A1%E5%88%8A%E6%9C%AC_055.jpg/960px-%E6%96%B0%E5%88%8A%E6%A0%A1%E6%AD%A3%E5%8F%A4%E6%9C%AC%E5%A4%A7%E5%AD%97%E9%9F%B3%E9%87%8A%E4%B8%89%E5%9B%BD%E5%BF%97%E9%80%9A%E4%BF%97%E6%BC%94%E4%B9%89_%E6%98%8E%E4%B8%87%E5%8E%86%E5%8D%81%E4%B9%9D%E5%B9%B4%E4%B9%A6%E6%9E%97%E5%91%A8%E6%9B%B0%E6%A0%A1%E5%88%8A%E6%9C%AC_055.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3200" data-file-height="2970" /></a></span></div>
			<div class="gallerytext">A 2-page illustration from Zhou Yue's 1591 edition: "Guan Yu Traveled One Thousand Li Alone". Guan Yu is depicted on his horse <a href="/wiki/Red_Hare" title="Red Hare">Red Hare</a></div>
		</li>
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 156.66666666667px">
			<div class="thumb" style="width: 154.66666666667px;"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Three_Kingdoms_Mao_version_-_Zhuge_Liang_and_Zhang_Fei.jpg" class="mw-file-description" title="Illustrations from Romance of the Three Kingdoms, an 1802 edition of the Mao version: Facing pages: Zhuge Liang (left) and Zhang Fei (right)"><img alt="Illustrations from Romance of the Three Kingdoms, an 1802 edition of the Mao version: Facing pages: Zhuge Liang (left) and Zhang Fei (right)" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Three_Kingdoms_Mao_version_-_Zhuge_Liang_and_Zhang_Fei.jpg/250px-Three_Kingdoms_Mao_version_-_Zhuge_Liang_and_Zhang_Fei.jpg" decoding="async" width="155" height="159" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Three_Kingdoms_Mao_version_-_Zhuge_Liang_and_Zhang_Fei.jpg/500px-Three_Kingdoms_Mao_version_-_Zhuge_Liang_and_Zhang_Fei.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="1158" data-file-height="1186" /></a></span></div>

		</li>
</ul>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Plot">Plot</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_of_the_Three_Kingdoms&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Plot"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<figure typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Three_Brothers_(Bei,_Yu,_Fei).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Three_Brothers_%28Bei%2C_Yu%2C_Fei%29.jpg/250px-Three_Brothers_%28Bei%2C_Yu%2C_Fei%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="311" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Three_Brothers_%28Bei%2C_Yu%2C_Fei%29.jpg/330px-Three_Brothers_%28Bei%2C_Yu%2C_Fei%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Three_Brothers_%28Bei%2C_Yu%2C_Fei%29.jpg/422px-Three_Brothers_%28Bei%2C_Yu%2C_Fei%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="422" data-file-height="656" /></a><figcaption><i>Three Heroes of Three Kingdoms</i>, silk painting by Sekkan Sakurai (1715–1790), depicting Liu Bei, Guan Yu and Zhang Fei.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The following is a summary of the central plot and some well-known highlights in the novel.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Yellow_Turban_Rebellion_and_the_Ten_Attendants">Yellow Turban Rebellion and the Ten Attendants</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_of_the_Three_Kingdoms&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Yellow Turban Rebellion and the Ten Attendants"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>In the late second century, towards the <a href="/wiki/End_of_the_Han_dynasty" title="End of the Han dynasty">end</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Han_dynasty" title="Han dynasty">Han dynasty</a> in China, corruption was rampant on all levels throughout the government, with treacherous <a href="/wiki/Eunuch" title="Eunuch">eunuchs</a> and villainous officials deceiving the emperor and persecuting those who stood up to them. The Han Empire gradually deteriorated and became increasingly fragmented, with many regional officials being <a href="/wiki/Warlord" title="Warlord">warlords</a> with their own armies. In the meantime, the common people suffered, and the <a href="/wiki/Yellow_Turban_Rebellion" title="Yellow Turban Rebellion">Yellow Turban Rebellion</a> (led by <a href="/wiki/Zhang_Jue" title="Zhang Jue">Zhang Jiao</a> and his brothers) eventually broke out during the reign of <a href="/wiki/Emperor_Ling_of_Han" title="Emperor Ling of Han">Emperor Ling</a>.
</p><p>The rebellion was barely suppressed by imperial forces commanded by the general <a href="/wiki/He_Jin" title="He Jin">He Jin</a>. Shortly after Emperor Ling's death, He Jin installed the young <a href="/wiki/Liu_Bian" title="Liu Bian">Emperor Shao</a> on the throne and took control of the central government. The <a href="/wiki/Ten_Attendants" title="Ten Attendants">Ten Attendants</a>, a group of influential court eunuchs, feared that He Jin was growing too powerful, so they lured him into the palace and assassinated him. In revenge, He Jin's followers broke into the palace and indiscriminately slaughtered any person who looked like a eunuch. In the ensuing chaos, Emperor Shao and his younger half-brother, the <a href="/wiki/Emperor_Xian_of_Han" title="Emperor Xian of Han">Prince of Chenliu</a>, disappeared from the palace.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Dong_Zhuo's_tyranny"><span id="Dong_Zhuo.27s_tyranny"></span>Dong Zhuo's tyranny</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_of_the_Three_Kingdoms&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Dong Zhuo&#039;s tyranny"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Fengyi_Pavilion,_L%C3%BC_bu,_Daochan-Three_Kingdoms-Zhou_Yuejiao_edition.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Fengyi_Pavilion%2C_L%C3%BC_bu%2C_Daochan-Three_Kingdoms-Zhou_Yuejiao_edition.jpg/250px-Fengyi_Pavilion%2C_L%C3%BC_bu%2C_Daochan-Three_Kingdoms-Zhou_Yuejiao_edition.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="236" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Fengyi_Pavilion%2C_L%C3%BC_bu%2C_Daochan-Three_Kingdoms-Zhou_Yuejiao_edition.jpg/500px-Fengyi_Pavilion%2C_L%C3%BC_bu%2C_Daochan-Three_Kingdoms-Zhou_Yuejiao_edition.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="1029" data-file-height="972" /></a><figcaption>Illustration from  a 1591 edition of the novel: "Fengyi Pavilion, Lü Bu, Diaochan". Diaochan flirts with Lü Bu as Dong Zhuo watches from behind a tree</figcaption></figure>
<p>The missing emperor and prince were found by soldiers of the warlord <a href="/wiki/Dong_Zhuo" title="Dong Zhuo">Dong Zhuo</a>, who escorted them back to the palace and used the opportunity to seize control of the imperial capital, <a href="/wiki/Luoyang" title="Luoyang">Luoyang</a>, under the pretext of protecting the emperor. Dong Zhuo later deposed Emperor Shao and replaced him with the Prince of Chenliu (<a href="/wiki/Emperor_Xian_of_Han" title="Emperor Xian of Han">Emperor Xian</a>), who was merely a figurehead under his control. Dong Zhuo monopolised state power, persecuted his political opponents, and oppressed the common people for his personal gain. During this time, there were two attempts on his life: the first was by a military officer Wu Fu (<span lang="zh">伍孚</span>), who failed and died a gruesome death; the second was by <a href="/wiki/Cao_Cao" title="Cao Cao">Cao Cao</a>, who was also unsuccessful but managed to escape.
</p><p>Cao Cao fled from Luoyang, returned to his home <a href="/wiki/Commandery_(China)" title="Commandery (China)">commandery</a>, and sent out a fake imperial edict to various warlords, calling them to rise up against Dong Zhuo. Under <a href="/wiki/Yuan_Shao" title="Yuan Shao">Yuan Shao</a>'s leadership, eighteen warlords formed a coalition and launched a punitive <a href="/wiki/Campaign_against_Dong_Zhuo" title="Campaign against Dong Zhuo">campaign against Dong Zhuo</a>. After Dong Zhuo lost the battles of Sishui Pass and <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Hulao_Pass" class="mw-redirect" title="Battle of Hulao Pass">Hulao Pass</a>, he forced the citizens of Luoyang to relocate to <a href="/wiki/Chang%27an" title="Chang&#39;an">Chang'an</a> with him and burnt down Luoyang. The coalition ultimately broke up due to indecisive leadership and conflicting interests among its members. Meanwhile, in Chang'an, Dong Zhuo was betrayed and murdered by his foster son <a href="/wiki/L%C3%BC_Bu" title="Lü Bu">Lü Bu</a> in a dispute over the maiden <a href="/wiki/Diaochan" title="Diaochan">Diaochan</a> as part of a plot orchestrated by the minister <a href="/wiki/Wang_Yun_(Han_dynasty)" title="Wang Yun (Han dynasty)">Wang Yun</a>.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Conflict_among_the_various_warlords_and_nobles">Conflict among the various warlords and nobles</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_of_the_Three_Kingdoms&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Conflict among the various warlords and nobles"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>In the meantime, the Han Empire was already disintegrating into civil war as warlords fought for territories and power. <a href="/wiki/Sun_Jian" title="Sun Jian">Sun Jian</a> found the <a href="/wiki/Imperial_Seal_of_China" class="mw-redirect" title="Imperial Seal of China">Imperial Seal</a> in the ruins of Luoyang and secretly kept it for himself. When Yuan Shao confronted him, he refused to hand over the Imperial Seal and left, but was attacked by <a href="/wiki/Liu_Biao" title="Liu Biao">Liu Biao</a> (acting on Yuan Shao's instruction) on the way back to his base. At the same time, Yuan Shao waged war against <a href="/wiki/Gongsun_Zan" title="Gongsun Zan">Gongsun Zan</a> to consolidate his power in northern China. Other warlords such as Cao Cao and <a href="/wiki/Liu_Bei" title="Liu Bei">Liu Bei</a>, who initially had no titles or land, were also gradually forming their own armies and taking control of territories. During those times of upheaval, Cao Cao saved Emperor Xian from Dong Zhuo's followers, established the new imperial capital in <a href="/wiki/Xuchang" title="Xuchang">Xu</a>, and became the new head of the central government. He also defeated rival warlords such as <a href="/wiki/L%C3%BC_Bu" title="Lü Bu">Lü Bu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yuan_Shu" title="Yuan Shu">Yuan Shu</a> and <a href="/wiki/Zhang_Xiu_(warlord)" title="Zhang Xiu (warlord)">Zhang Xiu</a> in a series of wars and gained control over much of central China.
</p><p>Meanwhile, Sun Jian was killed in an ambush by Liu Biao's forces. His eldest son, <a href="/wiki/Sun_Ce" title="Sun Ce">Sun Ce</a>, delivered the Imperial Seal as a tribute to the warlord <a href="/wiki/Yuan_Shu" title="Yuan Shu">Yuan Shu</a>, a rising <a href="/wiki/Pretender" title="Pretender">pretender</a> to the throne, in exchange for troops and horses. Sun Ce then secured himself a power base in the rich riverlands of <a href="/wiki/Jiangnan" title="Jiangnan">Jiangdong</a> (<a href="/wiki/Wu_(region)" class="mw-redirect" title="Wu (region)">Wu</a>), on which the state of <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Wu" title="Eastern Wu">Eastern Wu</a> was founded later. Tragically, Sun Ce also died at the pinnacle of his career from illness under stress of his terrifying encounter with the ghost of <a href="/wiki/Gan_Ji" title="Gan Ji">Yu Ji</a>, a venerable magician whom he had falsely accused of heresy and executed in jealousy. <a href="/wiki/Sun_Quan" title="Sun Quan">Sun Quan</a>, his younger brother and successor, proved to be a capable and charismatic ruler. With assistance from <a href="/wiki/Zhou_Yu" title="Zhou Yu">Zhou Yu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zhang_Zhao_(Eastern_Wu)" title="Zhang Zhao (Eastern Wu)">Zhang Zhao</a> and others, Sun Quan found hidden talents such as <a href="/wiki/Lu_Su" title="Lu Su">Lu Su</a> to serve him, built up his military forces, and maintained stability in Jiangdong.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Liu_Bei's_ambition"><span id="Liu_Bei.27s_ambition"></span>Liu Bei's ambition</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_of_the_Three_Kingdoms&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Liu Bei&#039;s ambition"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<figure typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Dai_Jin-Looking_Three_Times_at_the_Thatched_Hut.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Dai_Jin-Looking_Three_Times_at_the_Thatched_Hut.jpg/250px-Dai_Jin-Looking_Three_Times_at_the_Thatched_Hut.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="326" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Dai_Jin-Looking_Three_Times_at_the_Thatched_Hut.jpg/330px-Dai_Jin-Looking_Three_Times_at_the_Thatched_Hut.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Dai_Jin-Looking_Three_Times_at_the_Thatched_Hut.jpg/500px-Dai_Jin-Looking_Three_Times_at_the_Thatched_Hut.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1299" data-file-height="2117" /></a><figcaption>Liu Bei recruiting Zhuge Liang, from <i>Visiting the Thatched Hut Three Times</i>, a <a href="/wiki/Ming_dynasty" title="Ming dynasty">Ming dynasty</a> painting by <a href="/wiki/Dai_Jin" title="Dai Jin">Dai Jin</a> (1388–1462).</figcaption></figure>
<p><a href="/wiki/Liu_Bei" title="Liu Bei">Liu Bei</a> and his <a href="/wiki/Blood_brother" title="Blood brother">oath brothers</a> <a href="/wiki/Guan_Yu" title="Guan Yu">Guan Yu</a> and <a href="/wiki/Zhang_Fei" title="Zhang Fei">Zhang Fei</a> swore allegiance to the Han Empire in the <a href="/wiki/Oath_of_the_Peach_Garden" title="Oath of the Peach Garden">Oath of the Peach Garden</a> and pledged to do their best for the people. However, their ambitions were not realised as they did not receive due recognition for helping to suppress the <a href="/wiki/Yellow_Turban_Rebellion" title="Yellow Turban Rebellion">Yellow Turban Rebellion</a> and participating in the <a href="/wiki/Campaign_against_Dong_Zhuo" title="Campaign against Dong Zhuo">campaign against Dong Zhuo</a>. After Liu Bei succeeded <a href="/wiki/Tao_Qian_(Han_dynasty)" title="Tao Qian (Han dynasty)">Tao Qian</a> as the governor of <a href="/wiki/Xu_Province" class="mw-redirect" title="Xu Province">Xu Province</a>, he offered shelter to <a href="/wiki/L%C3%BC_Bu" title="Lü Bu">Lü Bu</a>, who had just been defeated by Cao Cao. However, Lü Bu betrayed his host, seized control of the province and attacked Liu Bei. After combining forces with Cao Cao to defeat Lü Bu at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Xiapi" title="Battle of Xiapi">Battle of Xiapi</a>, Liu Bei followed Cao Cao back to the imperial capital, Xu, where Emperor Xian honoured him as his "Imperial Uncle" upon learning that he was also a descendant of the imperial clan. When Cao Cao showed signs that he wanted to usurp the throne, Emperor Xian wrote a secret decree in blood to his father-in-law, <a href="/wiki/Dong_Cheng_(Han_dynasty)" title="Dong Cheng (Han dynasty)">Dong Cheng</a>, and ordered him to get rid of Cao Cao. Dong Cheng secretly contacted Liu Bei, <a href="/wiki/Ma_Teng" title="Ma Teng">Ma Teng</a> and others, and they planned to assassinate Cao Cao. However, their plans were leaked, and Cao Cao had Dong Cheng and the others arrested and <a href="/wiki/Nine_familial_exterminations" title="Nine familial exterminations">executed along with their families</a>.
</p><p>Liu Bei had already left the imperial capital when the plot was exposed, and he moved on to seize control of Xu Province from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Che_Zhou&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Che Zhou (page does not exist)">Che Zhou</a>, the new governor appointed by Cao Cao. In retaliation, Cao Cao attacked Xu Province and defeated Liu Bei, causing him to be separated from his oath brothers. While Liu Bei briefly joined Yuan Shao after his defeat, Zhang Fei took control of a small city, and Guan Yu temporarily served under Cao Cao and helped him slay two of Yuan Shao's generals in battle. The three oath brothers were eventually reunited and managed to establish a new base in <a href="/wiki/Runan_Commandery" title="Runan Commandery">Runan</a>, but they were defeated by Cao Cao's forces again so they retreated south to <a href="/wiki/Jing_Province" class="mw-redirect" title="Jing Province">Jing Province</a>, where they took shelter under the governor <a href="/wiki/Liu_Biao" title="Liu Biao">Liu Biao</a>.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Battle_of_Guandu">Battle of Guandu</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_of_the_Three_Kingdoms&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: Battle of Guandu"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>After pacifying the nearby provinces, suppressing a rebellion by former Yellow Turbans, and consolidating power in the central government, Cao Cao turned his attention north to Yuan Shao, who had recently eliminated Gongsun Zan and now controlled most of northern China. Yuan Shao amassed a large army and camped along the northern bank of the Yellow River.
</p><p>In the summer of 200, after months of preparations, Cao Cao and Yuan Shao clashed at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Guandu" title="Battle of Guandu">Battle of Guandu</a>. Although Cao Cao was heavily outnumbered by Yuan Shao, he secured a decisive victory over his rival after launching a surprise raid on Yuan Shao's supply train and throwing the enemy into disarray. Yuan Shao retreated north after his defeat, fell ill and died about two years later. Cao Cao took advantage of Yuan Shao's death, which had resulted in internal conflict among his sons who were fighting over their father's territories, and advanced north to attack and seize all of Yuan Shao's lands. By the end of 207, after a <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_White_Wolf_Mountain" title="Battle of White Wolf Mountain">victorious campaign beyond the frontier</a> against the <a href="/wiki/Wuhuan" title="Wuhuan">Wuhuan</a>, Cao Cao achieved complete dominance of northern China. The territories in central and northern China which came under Cao Cao's control became the foundation of the state of <a href="/wiki/Cao_Wei" title="Cao Wei">Cao Wei</a>, which would later be established by Cao Cao's son and successor <a href="/wiki/Cao_Pi" title="Cao Pi">Cao Pi</a>.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Zhuge_Liang_joins_Liu_Bei">Zhuge Liang joins Liu Bei</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_of_the_Three_Kingdoms&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: Zhuge Liang joins Liu Bei"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>In the meantime, Liu Biao had put Liu Bei in charge of <a href="/wiki/Xinye_County" title="Xinye County">Xinye</a>. During this time, Liu Bei visited <a href="/wiki/Zhuge_Liang" title="Zhuge Liang">Zhuge Liang</a> thrice and recruited him. Acting on Zhuge Liang's advice, Liu Bei built up his forces in preparation for war against Cao Cao. Following his unification of central and northern China under his control, Cao Cao, having been appointed <a href="/wiki/Chancellor_(China)" class="mw-redirect" title="Chancellor (China)">Imperial Chancellor</a> by Emperor Xian, led his forces on a southern campaign to eliminate Liu Bei and Sun Quan. By then, Liu Biao had died and his younger son <a href="/wiki/Liu_Cong_(Han_dynasty)" title="Liu Cong (Han dynasty)">Liu Cong</a> decided to surrender control of <a href="/wiki/Jing_Province" class="mw-redirect" title="Jing Province">Jing Province</a> to Cao Cao.
</p><p>In 208, although Liu Bei managed to repel two attacks by Cao Cao at Xinye, he was eventually forced to flee due to the overwhelming strength of the enemy forces. Cao Cao and his cavalry caught up with Liu Bei and his forces at <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Changban" title="Battle of Changban">Changban</a> and defeated them. During the battle, Liu Bei's generals <a href="/wiki/Zhao_Yun" title="Zhao Yun">Zhao Yun</a> and <a href="/wiki/Zhang_Fei" title="Zhang Fei">Zhang Fei</a> displayed heroics: the former fought his way through enemy lines to rescue Liu Bei's infant son <a href="/wiki/Liu_Shan" title="Liu Shan">Liu Shan</a> and deliver him safely back to his father; the latter single-handedly held off enemy forces at a bridge by intimidating and staring them down. Liu Bei and his forces managed to rendezvous with <a href="/wiki/Guan_Yu" title="Guan Yu">Guan Yu</a>, who had left earlier to seek help from Liu Biao's elder son <a href="/wiki/Liu_Qi_(Liu_Biao%27s_son)" title="Liu Qi (Liu Biao&#39;s son)">Liu Qi</a>, and they retreated to <a href="/wiki/Hankou" title="Hankou">Xiakou</a>.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Battle_of_Red_Cliffs">Battle of Red Cliffs</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_of_the_Three_Kingdoms&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: Battle of Red Cliffs"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>In 208, Liu Bei dispatched Zhuge Liang on a diplomatic mission to <a href="/wiki/Jiangnan" title="Jiangnan">Jiangdong</a> to meet Sun Quan and discuss forming a Sun–Liu alliance to counter Cao Cao. Although Sun Quan was initially hesitant due to many of his followers advising him to surrender to Cao Cao, he ultimately made up his mind to ally with Liu Bei, placing <a href="/wiki/Zhou_Yu" title="Zhou Yu">Zhou Yu</a> in command of his forces to prepare for the upcoming war. Zhuge Liang temporarily remained in Jiangdong to assist Zhou Yu, who sensed that Zhuge Liang posed a future threat to his lord. Zhou Yu attempted to outwit and kill Zhuge Liang, but failed and had no choice but to cooperate with the latter. The Sun–Liu forces scored a decisive victory over Cao Cao at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Red_Cliffs" title="Battle of Red Cliffs">Battle of Red Cliffs</a>.
</p>
<figure typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Chibi.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Chibi.jpg/250px-Chibi.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="168" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Chibi.jpg/330px-Chibi.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Chibi.jpg/416px-Chibi.jpg 2x" data-file-width="416" data-file-height="350" /></a><figcaption>Traditional site of the Red Cliffs.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Sun Quan and Liu Bei started vying for control of southern <a href="/wiki/Jing_Province" class="mw-redirect" title="Jing Province">Jing Province</a> after their victory, but Liu Bei won and took over the territories from Cao Cao's general <a href="/wiki/Cao_Ren" title="Cao Ren">Cao Ren</a>. Sun Quan, unhappy over having gained nothing, sent messengers to ask Liu Bei to "return" the territories to him, but Liu Bei dismissed the messenger each time with a different excuse. Sun Quan was unwilling to give up, so he followed Zhou Yu's plan to trick Liu Bei to come to Jiangdong to marry his sister <a href="/wiki/Lady_Sun" title="Lady Sun">Lady Sun</a> and then hold Liu Bei hostage in exchange for Jing Province. However, Zhuge Liang foiled Zhou Yu's plot, and the newlywed couple returned to Jing Province safely. Zhou Yu later died in frustration after Zhuge Liang repeatedly thwarted his moves to take Jing Province.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Liu_Bei's_takeover_of_Yi_Province"><span id="Liu_Bei.27s_takeover_of_Yi_Province"></span>Liu Bei's takeover of Yi Province</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_of_the_Three_Kingdoms&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: Liu Bei&#039;s takeover of Yi Province"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>Relations between Liu Bei and Sun Quan deteriorated after Zhou Yu's death, but not to the point of war. Following Zhuge Liang's <a href="/wiki/Longzhong_Plan" title="Longzhong Plan">Longzhong Plan</a>, Liu Bei led his forces westward into <a href="/wiki/Yi_Province" class="mw-redirect" title="Yi Province">Yi Province</a> and <a href="/wiki/Liu_Bei%27s_takeover_of_Yi_Province" title="Liu Bei&#39;s takeover of Yi Province">seized control of the territories</a> from the governor <a href="/wiki/Liu_Zhang_(warlord)" title="Liu Zhang (warlord)">Liu Zhang</a>. By then, Liu Bei ruled over a vast stretch of land from Yi Province to southern Jing Province; these territories served as the foundation of the state of <a href="/wiki/Shu_Han" title="Shu Han">Shu Han</a> later. Liu Bei declared himself King of Hanzhong after defeating Cao Cao in the <a href="/wiki/Hanzhong_Campaign" title="Hanzhong Campaign">Hanzhong Campaign</a> and capturing Hanzhong Commandery.
</p><p>At the same time, Emperor Xian awarded Cao Cao the title of a <a href="/wiki/Vassal" title="Vassal">vassal</a> king – King of Wei – while Sun Quan was known as the Duke of Wu. In eastern China, Sun Quan and Cao Cao's forces fought in various battles along the <a href="/wiki/Yangtze_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Yangtze River">Yangtze River</a>, including the battles of <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Xiaoyao_Ford" title="Battle of Xiaoyao Ford">Hefei</a> and <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Ruxukou_(217)" class="mw-redirect" title="Battle of Ruxukou (217)">Ruxu</a>, but neither side managed to gain a significant advantage over the other.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Death_of_Guan_Yu">Death of Guan Yu</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_of_the_Three_Kingdoms&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: Death of Guan Yu"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<figure typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Chengdu_2007_360.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Chengdu_2007_360.jpg/250px-Chengdu_2007_360.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="150" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Chengdu_2007_360.jpg/330px-Chengdu_2007_360.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Chengdu_2007_360.jpg/500px-Chengdu_2007_360.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2592" data-file-height="1944" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Shadow_puppet" class="mw-redirect" title="Shadow puppet">Shadow puppets</a> in the Sichuan Provincial Museum depicting <a href="/wiki/Guan_Yu" title="Guan Yu">Guan Yu</a> and <a href="/wiki/Zhang_Fei" title="Zhang Fei">Zhang Fei</a>.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Meanwhile, Sun Quan plotted to take Jing Province after growing tired of Liu Bei's repeated refusals to hand over the territories. He secretly made peace and allied with Cao Cao against Liu Bei. While Guan Yu, who guarded Liu Bei's territories in Jing Province, was away attacking <a href="/wiki/Cao_Ren" title="Cao Ren">Cao Ren</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Fancheng" title="Battle of Fancheng">Battle of Fancheng</a>, Sun Quan sent his general <a href="/wiki/L%C3%BC_Meng" title="Lü Meng">Lü Meng</a> to launch <a href="/wiki/L%C3%BC_Meng%27s_invasion_of_Jing_Province" title="Lü Meng&#39;s invasion of Jing Province">a stealth invasion on Jing Province</a>. Guan Yu was unable to capture Fancheng so he retreated, but was caught off guard by Lü Meng and had already lost Jing Province before he knew it. With his army's morale falling and the troops gradually deserting, Guan Yu and his remaining men withdrew to Maicheng, where they were surrounded by Sun Quan's forces. In desperation, Guan Yu attempted to break out of the siege but failed and was captured in an ambush. Sun Quan had him executed after he refused to surrender.
</p><p>Shortly after Guan Yu's death, Cao Cao died of a brain tumour in Luoyang. His son and successor, <a href="/wiki/Cao_Pi" title="Cao Pi">Cao Pi</a>, forced Emperor Xian to abdicate the throne to him and established the state of <a href="/wiki/Cao_Wei" title="Cao Wei">Cao Wei</a> to replace the Han dynasty. About a year later, Liu Bei declared himself emperor and founded the state of <a href="/wiki/Shu_Han" title="Shu Han">Shu Han</a> as a continuation of the Han dynasty. While Liu Bei was planning to avenge Guan Yu, Zhang Fei was assassinated in his sleep by his subordinates.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Battle_of_Yiling">Battle of Yiling</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_of_the_Three_Kingdoms&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: Battle of Yiling"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>As Liu Bei led a large army to avenge Guan Yu and retake Jing Province, Sun Quan attempted to appease him by offering to return him the territories in southern Jing Province. Liu Bei's subjects urged him to accept Sun Quan's offer but Liu Bei insisted on avenging his oath brother. After initial victories against Sun Quan's forces, a series of strategic mistakes resulted in Sun Quan's general <a href="/wiki/Lu_Xun_(Three_Kingdoms)" class="mw-redirect" title="Lu Xun (Three Kingdoms)">Lu Xun</a> inflicting a calamitous defeat on Liu Bei at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Xiaoting" title="Battle of Xiaoting">Battle of Yiling</a>. Lu Xun initially pursued Liu Bei during his retreat, but gave up after getting trapped inside and barely escaping from Zhuge Liang's <a href="/wiki/Stone_Sentinel_Maze" title="Stone Sentinel Maze">Stone Sentinel Maze</a>.
</p>
<figure class="mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Zhuge_Liang_by_Zhang_Feng.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Zhuge_Liang_by_Zhang_Feng.jpg/250px-Zhuge_Liang_by_Zhang_Feng.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="418" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Zhuge_Liang_by_Zhang_Feng.jpg/330px-Zhuge_Liang_by_Zhang_Feng.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Zhuge_Liang_by_Zhang_Feng.jpg/500px-Zhuge_Liang_by_Zhang_Feng.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1696" data-file-height="3542" /></a><figcaption>An artist's impression of <a href="/wiki/Zhuge_Liang" title="Zhuge Liang">Zhuge Liang</a>.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Liu Bei died in <a href="/wiki/Baidicheng" title="Baidicheng">Baidicheng</a> from illness a few months later. On his deathbed, Liu Bei granted Zhuge Liang permission to take the throne if his son and successor, <a href="/wiki/Liu_Shan" title="Liu Shan">Liu Shan</a>, proved to be an inept ruler. Zhuge Liang firmly refused and swore to remain faithful to the trust Liu Bei had placed in him.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Zhuge_Liang's_campaigns"><span id="Zhuge_Liang.27s_campaigns"></span>Zhuge Liang's campaigns</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_of_the_Three_Kingdoms&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: Zhuge Liang&#039;s campaigns"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>After Liu Bei's death, Cao Pi induced several forces, including Sun Quan, a turncoat Shu general <a href="/wiki/Meng_Da" title="Meng Da">Meng Da</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Nanman" title="Nanman">Nanman</a> and <a href="/wiki/Qiang_(historical_people)" title="Qiang (historical people)">Qiang</a> tribes, to attack Shu, in coordination with a Wei army. However, Zhuge Liang managed to make the five armies retreat without any bloodshed. He also sent <a href="/wiki/Deng_Zhi" title="Deng Zhi">Deng Zhi</a> to make peace with Sun Quan and restore the alliance between Shu and Wu. Zhuge Liang then personally led <a href="/wiki/Zhuge_Liang%27s_Southern_Campaign" title="Zhuge Liang&#39;s Southern Campaign">a southern campaign</a> against the Nanman, defeated them seven times, and won the allegiance of the Nanman king <a href="/wiki/Meng_Huo" title="Meng Huo">Meng Huo</a>.
</p><p>After pacifying the south, Zhuge Liang led the Shu army on <a href="/wiki/Zhuge_Liang%27s_Northern_Expeditions" title="Zhuge Liang&#39;s Northern Expeditions">five military expeditions</a> to attack Wei as part of his mission to restore the Han dynasty. Each time, as Zhuge Liang was on the verge of success, he was recalled due to various unfortunate circumstances, such as Liu Shan listening to rumours spread by eunuchs. Moreover, his days were numbered because he had been suffering from chronic illness and his condition worsened under stress. He died of illness at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Wuzhang_Plains" title="Battle of Wuzhang Plains">Battle of Wuzhang Plains</a> while leading a stalemate battle against the Wei general <a href="/wiki/Sima_Yi" title="Sima Yi">Sima Yi</a>.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="End_of_the_Three_Kingdoms">End of the Three Kingdoms</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_of_the_Three_Kingdoms&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: End of the Three Kingdoms"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>The long years of battle between Shu and Wei saw many changes in the ruling Cao family in Wei. The influence of the Caos weakened after <a href="/wiki/Cao_Rui" title="Cao Rui">Cao Rui</a>'s death and state power eventually fell into the hands of the regent Sima Yi and subsequently to his sons, <a href="/wiki/Sima_Shi" title="Sima Shi">Sima Shi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sima_Zhao" title="Sima Zhao">Sima Zhao</a>.
</p><p>In Shu, <a href="/wiki/Jiang_Wei" title="Jiang Wei">Jiang Wei</a> inherited Zhuge Liang's legacy and continued to lead another <a href="/wiki/Jiang_Wei%27s_Northern_Expeditions" title="Jiang Wei&#39;s Northern Expeditions">nine campaigns</a> against Wei for three decades, but ultimately failed to achieve any significant success. The Shu emperor <a href="/wiki/Liu_Shan" title="Liu Shan">Liu Shan</a> also turned out to be an incompetent ruler who trusted corrupt officials. Shu gradually declined under Liu Shan's rule and was eventually <a href="/wiki/Conquest_of_Shu_by_Wei" title="Conquest of Shu by Wei">conquered by Wei forces</a>. Jiang Wei attempted to restore Shu with the help of <a href="/wiki/Zhong_Hui" title="Zhong Hui">Zhong Hui</a>, a disgruntled Wei general, but their plan failed and Zhong Hui was killed by Wei troops while Jiang Wei died by suicide. Shortly after the fall of Shu, Sima Zhao died and his son, <a href="/wiki/Emperor_Wu_of_Jin" title="Emperor Wu of Jin">Sima Yan</a>, forced the last Wei emperor, <a href="/wiki/Cao_Huan" title="Cao Huan">Cao Huan</a>, to abdicate the throne to him. Sima Yan then established the <a href="/wiki/Jin_dynasty_(265%E2%80%93420)" class="mw-redirect" title="Jin dynasty (265–420)">Jin dynasty</a> to replace the state of Cao Wei.
</p><p>In Wu, there had been internal conflict among the nobles since Sun Quan's death. The regents <a href="/wiki/Zhuge_Ke" title="Zhuge Ke">Zhuge Ke</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sun_Chen" title="Sun Chen">Sun Chen</a> consecutively attempted to usurp the throne but were eventually ousted from power and eliminated in coups. Although stability was temporarily restored in Wu, the last Wu emperor, <a href="/wiki/Sun_Hao" title="Sun Hao">Sun Hao</a>, turned out to be a tyrant. Wu, the last of the Three Kingdoms, was eventually <a href="/wiki/Conquest_of_Wu_by_Jin" title="Conquest of Wu by Jin">conquered by the Jin dynasty</a>. The fall of Wu marked the end of the near century-long era of civil strife historically known as the Three Kingdoms period.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Historical_accuracy">Historical accuracy</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_of_the_Three_Kingdoms&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: Historical accuracy"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_fictitious_stories_in_Romance_of_the_Three_Kingdoms" title="List of fictitious stories in Romance of the Three Kingdoms">List of fictitious stories in Romance of the Three Kingdoms</a></div>
<p>The novel draws from <a href="/wiki/Chen_Shou" title="Chen Shou">Chen Shou</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Records_of_the_Three_Kingdoms" title="Records of the Three Kingdoms">Records of the Three Kingdoms</a></i> as the main historical source. Other major influences include Liu Yiqing's <i><a href="/wiki/A_New_Account_of_the_Tales_of_the_World" title="A New Account of the Tales of the World">A New Account of the Tales of the World</a></i> (<i>Shishuo Xinyu</i>), published in 430,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-roberts981&#95;28-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-roberts981-28"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>28<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and the <i>Sanguozhi Pinghua</i>, a chronological collection of eighty fictional sketches starting with the peach garden oath and ending with Zhuge Liang's death.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-roberts954&#95;29-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-roberts954-29"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>29<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Some 50 or 60 Yuan and early Ming plays about the Three Kingdoms are known to have existed, and their material is almost entirely fictional, based on thin threads of actual history. The novel is thus a return to greater emphasis on history, compared to these dramas.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-roberts958&#95;9&#95;30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-roberts958_9-30"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>30<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The novel also shifted towards better acknowledgement of southern China's historical importance, while still portraying some prejudice against the south.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-roberts959&#95;83&#95;31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-roberts959_83-31"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>31<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The Qing dynasty historian <a href="/wiki/Zhang_Xuecheng" title="Zhang Xuecheng">Zhang Xuecheng</a> famously wrote that the novel was "seven-parts fact and three-parts fiction."<sup id="cite&#95;ref-roberts980&#95;20-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-roberts980-20"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>20<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-:1&#95;32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-32"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>32<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The fictional parts are culled from different sources, including unofficial histories, folk stories, the <i>Sanguozhi Pinghua</i>, and also the author's own imagination. Nonetheless, the description of the social conditions and the logic that the characters use is accurate to the Three Kingdoms period, creating "believable" situations and characters, even if they are not historically accurate.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-guan14&#95;33-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-guan14-33"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>33<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p><i>Romance of the Three Kingdoms</i>, like the dramas and folk stories of its day, features Liu Bei and his associates as the protagonists; hence the depiction of the people in Shu Han was glorified. The antagonists, Cao Cao, Sun Quan and their followers, on the other hand, were often denigrated. This suited the political climate in the Ming dynasty, unlike in the Jin dynasty when Cao Wei was considered the legitimate successor to the Han dynasty.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTEMcLaren201246&#95;34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcLaren201246-34"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>34<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Some non-historical scenes in the novel have become well-known and subsequently became a part of traditional Chinese culture.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Literary_analysis">Literary analysis</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_of_the_Three_Kingdoms&amp;action=edit&amp;section=18" title="Edit section: Literary analysis"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>In a literary analysis of the novel, Yao Yao focuses on the way the Mao edition interlaces the stories told about the three kingdoms in a way designed to highlight the relationships among the story elements. Yao Yao uses the analogy of a rope: "juxtaposed and reasonably developed strands of narrative become interlaced".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Yao&#95;thesis&#95;35-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Yao_thesis-35"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>35<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 87">&#58;&#8202;87&#8202;</span></sup> Maos' invention of literary devices is made evident in numerous comparisons of the Mao edition with Chen Shou's historic account the <i>Records of the Three Kingdoms</i>, which was an important source, as well as the Li Zhuowu edition (also referred to as the Jiajing edition).
</p><p>The title of the Mao edition, <i>San Guo Zhi Tongsu Yan Yi</i> (<i>Popular Romance of the Records of the Three Kingdoms</i> includes the qualifier, "Yan Yi", (conventionally translated as "Romance") to indicate that it is an amplification of the earlier work.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Yao&#95;thesis&#95;35-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Yao_thesis-35"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>35<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 36">&#58;&#8202;36&#8202;</span></sup> The best example of this amplification is the depiction of Zhuge Liang's southern campaign. The campaign was actually a single action which Chen Shou described in a few sentences. The Mao edition greatly expands the action into seven battles in which Meng Huo, the rebel leader, is captured and released seven times. The expanded story (told in chapters 87–89) underscores "Zhuge's endless effort to restore the Han Dynasty".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Yao&#95;thesis&#95;35-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Yao_thesis-35"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>35<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 60">&#58;&#8202;60&#8202;</span></sup> As described by Yao, "The author uses freely the vast store of early tradition, written and oral. He integrates reality and invention (history and fiction) in order to form a single story".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Yao&#95;thesis&#95;35-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Yao_thesis-35"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>35<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 37">&#58;&#8202;37&#8202;</span></sup>
</p><p>The Mao edition and Li Zhuowu editions have similarities and differences with respect to chapter structure. The Li Zhuowu edition has 240 chapters ("hui") each with a single story and title, these were grouped into 120 pairs. Odd-number chapters ended in stock phrases such as "Can he survive?" or "Let's see how he will defeat the enemy?". Even-number chapters often ended with "What's next? We will find out in the following 'hui' ".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Yao&#95;thesis&#95;35-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Yao_thesis-35"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>35<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Pages: 45–46">&#58;&#8202;45–46&#8202;</span></sup> Thus, each pair of chapters presents a story written in chronological order.
</p><p>On the other hand, the Mao edition has 120 chapters, each with two interlaced stories (sometimes with other short stories inserted). The titles are couplets, one line for each of the major stories. The interlacing of the stories (with somewhat less regard to their chronology) illuminates the parallels or contrasts between them which the Maos had carefully highlighted.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Yao&#95;thesis&#95;35-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Yao_thesis-35"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>35<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 52">&#58;&#8202;52&#8202;</span></sup>
</p><p>Prose and poems are also interlaced. The poems typically reaffirm, or question points made by the narrator becoming, in essence, a secondary narrator. Poems are often used to increase the universality of specific points made by the main narrator.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Yao&#95;thesis&#95;35-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Yao_thesis-35"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>35<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 68">&#58;&#8202;68&#8202;</span></sup> Poems were also used to break the narrative flow and are placed at the end of chapters to summarize events and to transition to the next chapters.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Yao&#95;thesis&#95;35-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Yao_thesis-35"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>35<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 60">&#58;&#8202;60&#8202;</span></sup>
</p><p>Yao Yao includes an example from Chapter 79 of the Mao edition which illustrates the interlacing of two plots within a chapter and the interlacing of poetry and prose. Chapter 79 includes two stories one describes Liu Bei's attempt to punish two generals who had refused aid to Guan Yu which led to his death. One of the generals was his adopted son, whom he felt compelled to execute. Soon thereafter, in Chapters 82–84), he gathers all his forces and engages with those of Sun Quan in the Battle of Yiling where he is totally defeated.
</p><p>The other story (which is the first of the two) describes how Cao Pi (Cao Cao's initial successor) attempts to kill his more talented and scholarly younger brother, Cao Zhi, out of fear that Cao Zhi might be a threat to his leadership. He orders Cao Zhi to compose a poem in the time required to take seven steps. If he fails, he will be executed. Cao Zhi successfully composes a poem that "describes two bulls fighting and colliding against each other. One is pushed past the edge and falls into a dry well, where it dies".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Yao&#95;thesis&#95;35-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Yao_thesis-35"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>35<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 56">&#58;&#8202;56&#8202;</span></sup>
</p><p>Cao Pi is not satisfied and requires a second poem. This time Cao Zhi composes the more widely quoted <i><a href="/wiki/Quatrain_of_Seven_Steps" class="mw-redirect" title="Quatrain of Seven Steps">Quatrain of Seven Steps</a></i> which describes cooking beans over a fire built with dry bean stems. The beans exclaim: "Alive we sprouted from a single root—/ What is your rush to cook us on the fire".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Roberts&#95;2004&#95;v2&#95;36-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Roberts_2004_v2-36"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>36<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 599">&#58;&#8202;599&#8202;</span></sup> Cao Pi takes the poem to heart and allows Cao Zhi to go free.
</p><p>The first poem about the bulls foreshadows Liu Bei's downfall; the second, Cao Pei's mistreatment of his brother. The second poem "also reinforces the link between the two halves of this chapter by bringing out the irony: on the one hand, Liu Bei gives up all he has to avenge a sworn brother; on the other hand, Cao Pei will not be satisfied until he can find a way to put his blood brother to death".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Yao&#95;thesis&#95;35-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Yao_thesis-35"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>35<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 56">&#58;&#8202;56&#8202;</span></sup> The chapter concludes with the poem: "The Shrines of Wei were about to be established;/ The land of Han was about to pass into another's hands".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Roberts&#95;2004&#95;v2&#95;36-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Roberts_2004_v2-36"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>36<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 603">&#58;&#8202;603&#8202;</span></sup>
</p><p>The Mao's themselves also comment on the interlacing of the stories in their opening essay as follows (translator annotation omitted and romanizations standardized to <a href="/wiki/Pinyin" title="Pinyin">pinyin</a>):
</p>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1244412712" /><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>Cao Pi's cruel oppression of the living Cao Zhi is a case of conflict between brothers of the same blood, whereas Liu Bei's grievous lamentation over the dead Guan Yu is a case of brotherly love between men of different surnames. [...] Examples such as those enumerated above, some of which are analogous and some of which are contrasting, all parallel each other within a single chapter.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-How&#95;to&#95;Read&#95;23-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-How_to_Read-23"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>23<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 189">&#58;&#8202;189&#8202;</span></sup></p></blockquote>
<p>Elsewhere the Maos comment that such interlacing may occur in a single chapter or in some cases "at a distance across several tens of intervening chapters".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-How&#95;to&#95;Read&#95;23-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-How_to_Read-23"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>23<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 188">&#58;&#8202;188&#8202;</span></sup>
</p><p>Yao Yao goes on to discuss other key components of the work including: the rise and fall of states and individuals in the novel, the lack of continuity between generations, the individual development and complexity of major characters and the interlacing of themes by repetition.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Yao&#95;thesis&#95;35-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Yao_thesis-35"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>35<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Pages: 84–154">&#58;&#8202;84–154&#8202;</span></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Peach_garden_ceremony.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Peach_garden_ceremony.jpg/250px-Peach_garden_ceremony.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="180" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Peach_garden_ceremony.jpg/330px-Peach_garden_ceremony.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Peach_garden_ceremony.jpg/500px-Peach_garden_ceremony.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1215" data-file-height="995" /></a><figcaption>Illustration from a 1591 edition of the novel, "Peach Garden Oath of Brotherhood", depicting the heroes with a black bull and white horse sacrificed in the ceremony.</figcaption></figure>
