<p>In the introduction to the 1959 reprint of the <a href="/wiki/Charles_Henry_Brewitt-Taylor" title="Charles Henry Brewitt-Taylor">Brewitt-Taylor</a> translation, Roy Andrew Miller argues that the novel's chief theme is "the nature of human ambition",<sup id="cite&#95;ref-:1&#95;32-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-32"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>32<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> to which Moody adds the relationship between politics and morality, specifically the conflict between the idealism of <a href="/wiki/Confucianism" title="Confucianism">Confucian</a> political thought and the harsh realism of <a href="/wiki/Legalism_(Chinese_philosophy)" title="Legalism (Chinese philosophy)">Legalism</a>, as a related theme.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-:1&#95;32-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-32"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>32<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Other dominant themes of the novel include: the rise and fall of the ideal liege (Liu Bei); finding the ideal minister (Zhuge Liang); the conflict between the ideal liege (Liu Bei) and the consummate villain (Cao Cao); and the cruelties and injustice of feudal or dynastic government.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-roberts940&#95;1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-roberts940-1"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>1<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The opening lines of the novel, "The empire, long divided, must unite; long united, must divide. Thus it has ever been", added by Mao Lun and <a href="/wiki/Mao_Zonggang" title="Mao Zonggang">Mao Zonggang</a> in their recension,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>37<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTELuo19915&#95;24-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELuo19915-24"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>24<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> epitomise the tragic theme of the novel. One recent critic notes that the novel takes political and moral stands and lets the reader know which of the characters are heroes and which villains, yet the heroes are forced to make a tragic choice between equal values, not merely between good and evil. The heroes know that the end of the empire is ordained by this cosmic cycle of division and unity, yet their choices are moral, based on loyalty, not political.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Tung&#95;38-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tung-38"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>38<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Plaks states the novel deals with the "cyclical theories of dynastic decline," and relates the "breakdown of order" at the end of the Han dynasty to "the improper exercise of imperial authority, the destabilisation influence of special-interest groups (eunuchs, imperial clansmen), the problem of factional and individual idealism carried to the point of civil strife-all of which eventually surface in the body of the narrative."  He goes on to say, the "overlapping claims to legitimacy and multiple spheres of power," give the novel a "sense of epic greatness" with its "combination of grandeur and futility."<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Plaks&#95;9-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Plaks-9"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>9<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 385, 403, 495">&#58;&#8202;385,&#8202;403,&#8202;495&#8202;</span></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Cultural_impact">Cultural impact</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_of_the_Three_Kingdoms&amp;action=edit&amp;section=19" title="Edit section: Cultural impact"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>Besides the famous Peach Garden Oath, many <a href="https://en.wikiquote.org/wiki/Chinese_proverbs" class="extiw" title="wikiquote:Chinese proverbs">Chinese proverbs</a> in use today are derived from the novel:
</p>
<table class="wikitable">

<tbody><tr>
<th width="30%">Translation
</th>
<th width="30%">Chinese
</th>
<th width="40%">Interpretation
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td>Brothers are like limbs, wives and children are like clothing. Torn clothing can be repaired; how can broken limbs be mended?<sup id="cite&#95;ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>39<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</td>
<td><a href="/wiki/Simplified_Chinese_characters" title="Simplified Chinese characters">simplified Chinese</a>&#58; <span lang="zh-Hans">兄弟如手足，妻子如衣服。衣服破，尚可缝； 手足断，安可续？</span>; <a href="/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters" title="Traditional Chinese characters">traditional Chinese</a>&#58; <span lang="zh-Hant">兄弟如手足，妻子如衣服。衣服破，尚可縫； 手足斷，安可續？</span>
</td>
<td>
<p>It means that wives and children, like clothing, are replaceable if lost but the same does not hold true for one's brothers (or friends).
</p>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Liu Bei "borrows" <a href="/wiki/Jingzhou_(ancient_China)" title="Jingzhou (ancient China)">Jing Province</a> – borrowing without returning.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>40<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</td>
<td><a href="/wiki/Simplified_Chinese_characters" title="Simplified Chinese characters">simplified Chinese</a>&#58; <span lang="zh-Hans">刘备借荆州——有借无还</span>; <a href="/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters" title="Traditional Chinese characters">traditional Chinese</a>&#58; <span lang="zh-Hant">劉備借荆州——有借無還</span> <br /> <a href="/wiki/Simplified_Chinese_characters" title="Simplified Chinese characters">simplified Chinese</a>&#58; <span lang="zh-Hans">刘备借荆州，一借无回头</span>; <a href="/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters" title="Traditional Chinese characters">traditional Chinese</a>&#58; <span lang="zh-Hant">劉備借荆州，一借無回頭</span>
</td>
<td>This proverb describes the situation of a person borrowing something without the intention of returning it.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Speak of Cao Cao and Cao Cao arrives.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>41<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</td>
<td><a href="/wiki/Simplified_Chinese_characters" title="Simplified Chinese characters">simplified Chinese</a>&#58; <span lang="zh-Hans">说曹操，曹操到</span>; <a href="/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters" title="Traditional Chinese characters">traditional Chinese</a>&#58; <span lang="zh-Hant">說曹操，曹操到</span> <br /> <a href="/wiki/Simplified_Chinese_characters" title="Simplified Chinese characters">simplified Chinese</a>&#58; <span lang="zh-Hans">说曹操曹操就到</span>; <a href="/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters" title="Traditional Chinese characters">traditional Chinese</a>&#58; <span lang="zh-Hant">說曹操曹操就到</span>
</td>
<td>Equivalent to <a href="/wiki/Speak_of_the_devil" title="Speak of the devil">speak of the devil</a>. Describes the situation of a person appearing precisely when being spoken about.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Three reeking tanners [or cobblers] (are enough to) overcome one Zhuge Liang.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>42<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</td>
<td><a href="/wiki/Simplified_Chinese_characters" title="Simplified Chinese characters">simplified Chinese</a>&#58; <span lang="zh-Hans">三个臭皮匠，胜过一个诸葛亮</span>; <a href="/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters" title="Traditional Chinese characters">traditional Chinese</a>&#58; <span lang="zh-Hant">三個臭皮匠，勝過一個諸葛亮</span> <br /> <a href="/wiki/Simplified_Chinese_characters" title="Simplified Chinese characters">simplified Chinese</a>&#58; <span lang="zh-Hans">三个臭皮匠，赛过一个诸葛亮</span>; <a href="/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters" title="Traditional Chinese characters">traditional Chinese</a>&#58; <span lang="zh-Hant">三個臭皮匠，賽過一個諸葛亮</span> <br /> <a href="/wiki/Simplified_Chinese_characters" title="Simplified Chinese characters">simplified Chinese</a>&#58; <span lang="zh-Hans">三个臭裨将，顶个诸葛亮</span>; <a href="/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters" title="Traditional Chinese characters">traditional Chinese</a>&#58; <span lang="zh-Hant">三个臭裨将，頂個諸葛亮</span>
</td>
<td>This proverb expresses the idea that the collaboration of people working together maybe more effective than one intelligent person working alone. One variation is "subordinate generals" (<a href="/wiki/Simplified_Chinese_characters" title="Simplified Chinese characters">simplified Chinese</a>&#58; <span lang="zh-Hans">裨将</span>; <a href="/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters" title="Traditional Chinese characters">traditional Chinese</a>&#58; <span lang="zh-Hant">裨將</span>; <i>píjiàng</i>) instead of "tanners" (皮匠; <i>píjiàng</i>).
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Eastern Wu arranges a false marriage that turns into a real one.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>43<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</td>
<td><a href="/wiki/Simplified_Chinese_characters" title="Simplified Chinese characters">simplified Chinese</a>&#58; <span lang="zh-Hans">东吴招亲——弄假成真</span>; <a href="/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters" title="Traditional Chinese characters">traditional Chinese</a>&#58; <span lang="zh-Hant">東吳招親——弄假成真</span>
</td>
<td>When a plan to falsely offer something backfires with the result that the thing originally offered is appropriated by the intended victim of the hoax.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Losing the lady and crippling the army.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>44<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</td>
<td><a href="/wiki/Simplified_Chinese_characters" title="Simplified Chinese characters">simplified Chinese</a>&#58; <span lang="zh-Hans">周郎妙计安天下，赔了夫人又折兵</span>; <a href="/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters" title="Traditional Chinese characters">traditional Chinese</a>&#58; <span lang="zh-Hant">周郎妙計安天下，賠了夫人又折兵</span>
</td>
<td>The "lady" lost here was actually <a href="/wiki/Sun_Quan" title="Sun Quan">Sun Quan</a>'s sister <a href="/wiki/Lady_Sun" title="Lady Sun">Lady Sun</a>. <a href="/wiki/Zhou_Yu" title="Zhou Yu">Zhou Yu</a>'s plan to capture Liu Bei by means of a false marriage proposal failed and Lady Sun really became Liu's wife (see above). Zhou Yu later led his troops in an attempt to attack Liu Bei but fell into an ambush and suffered a crushing defeat. This saying is now used to describe situations where schemers makes a fools of themselves and suffer double losses.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Every person on the street knows what is in <a href="/wiki/Sima_Zhao" title="Sima Zhao">Sima Zhao</a>'s mind.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>45<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</td>
<td><a href="/wiki/Simplified_Chinese_characters" title="Simplified Chinese characters">simplified Chinese</a>&#58; <span lang="zh-Hans">司马昭之心，路人皆知</span>; <a href="/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters" title="Traditional Chinese characters">traditional Chinese</a>&#58; <span lang="zh-Hant">司馬昭之心，路人皆知</span>
</td>
<td>As <a href="/wiki/Sima_Zhao" title="Sima Zhao">Sima Zhao</a> gradually rose to power in Wei, his intention to usurp state power became more obvious. The young Wei emperor <a href="/wiki/Cao_Mao" title="Cao Mao">Cao Mao</a> once lamented to his loyal ministers, "Every person on the street knows what is in Sima Zhao's mind (that he wanted to usurp the throne)." This saying is now used to describe a situation where a person's ill-intention is obvious.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>The young should not read <i><a href="/wiki/Water_Margin" title="Water Margin">Water Margin</a>,</i> and the old should not read <i>Three Kingdoms.</i><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Kwon&#95;thesis&#95;46-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kwon_thesis-46"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>46<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 218">&#58;&#8202;218&#8202;</span></sup>
</td>
<td><a href="/wiki/Simplified_Chinese_characters" title="Simplified Chinese characters">simplified Chinese</a>&#58; <span lang="zh-Hans">少不读水浒, 老不读三国</span>; <a href="/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters" title="Traditional Chinese characters">traditional Chinese</a>&#58; <span lang="zh-Hant">少不讀水滸, 老不讀三國</span>
</td>
<td>The former depicts the lives of heroic outlaws and their defiance of the corrupted government system but results in bittersweet tragedy. The latter presents dynasties that came and go which reminds the old that nothing is permanent.
</td></tr>
</tbody></table>
<p>The writing style adopted by <i>Romance of the Three Kingdoms</i> was part of the emergence of written vernacular during the Ming period, as part of the so-called "Four Masterworks" (<i>si da qishu</i>).<sup id="cite&#95;ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>47<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Buddhist_aspects">Buddhist aspects</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_of_the_Three_Kingdoms&amp;action=edit&amp;section=20" title="Edit section: Buddhist aspects"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:%E6%96%B0%E5%88%8A%E6%A0%A1%E6%AD%A3%E5%8F%A4%E6%9C%AC%E5%A4%A7%E5%AD%97%E9%9F%B3%E9%87%8A%E4%B8%89%E5%9B%BD%E5%BF%97%E9%80%9A%E4%BF%97%E6%BC%94%E4%B9%89_%E6%98%8E%E4%B8%87%E5%8E%86%E5%8D%81%E4%B9%9D%E5%B9%B4%E4%B9%A6%E6%9E%97%E5%91%A8%E6%9B%B0%E6%A0%A1%E5%88%8A%E6%9C%AC_155.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/%E6%96%B0%E5%88%8A%E6%A0%A1%E6%AD%A3%E5%8F%A4%E6%9C%AC%E5%A4%A7%E5%AD%97%E9%9F%B3%E9%87%8A%E4%B8%89%E5%9B%BD%E5%BF%97%E9%80%9A%E4%BF%97%E6%BC%94%E4%B9%89_%E6%98%8E%E4%B8%87%E5%8E%86%E5%8D%81%E4%B9%9D%E5%B9%B4%E4%B9%A6%E6%9E%97%E5%91%A8%E6%9B%B0%E6%A0%A1%E5%88%8A%E6%9C%AC_155.jpg/250px-%E6%96%B0%E5%88%8A%E6%A0%A1%E6%AD%A3%E5%8F%A4%E6%9C%AC%E5%A4%A7%E5%AD%97%E9%9F%B3%E9%87%8A%E4%B8%89%E5%9B%BD%E5%BF%97%E9%80%9A%E4%BF%97%E6%BC%94%E4%B9%89_%E6%98%8E%E4%B8%87%E5%8E%86%E5%8D%81%E4%B9%9D%E5%B9%B4%E4%B9%A6%E6%9E%97%E5%91%A8%E6%9B%B0%E6%A0%A1%E5%88%8A%E6%9C%AC_155.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="232" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/%E6%96%B0%E5%88%8A%E6%A0%A1%E6%AD%A3%E5%8F%A4%E6%9C%AC%E5%A4%A7%E5%AD%97%E9%9F%B3%E9%87%8A%E4%B8%89%E5%9B%BD%E5%BF%97%E9%80%9A%E4%BF%97%E6%BC%94%E4%B9%89_%E6%98%8E%E4%B8%87%E5%8E%86%E5%8D%81%E4%B9%9D%E5%B9%B4%E4%B9%A6%E6%9E%97%E5%91%A8%E6%9B%B0%E6%A0%A1%E5%88%8A%E6%9C%AC_155.jpg/500px-%E6%96%B0%E5%88%8A%E6%A0%A1%E6%AD%A3%E5%8F%A4%E6%9C%AC%E5%A4%A7%E5%AD%97%E9%9F%B3%E9%87%8A%E4%B8%89%E5%9B%BD%E5%BF%97%E9%80%9A%E4%BF%97%E6%BC%94%E4%B9%89_%E6%98%8E%E4%B8%87%E5%8E%86%E5%8D%81%E4%B9%9D%E5%B9%B4%E4%B9%A6%E6%9E%97%E5%91%A8%E6%9B%B0%E6%A0%A1%E5%88%8A%E6%9C%AC_155.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="3200" data-file-height="2970" /></a><figcaption>Illustration from a 1591 edition of the novel: "On Jade Spring Mountain, Lord Guan reveals his sanctity" which depicts the apparition of Lord Guan [left, mounted on Red Hare] appearing to Monk Pujing [with deer tail whisk].</figcaption></figure>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Buddhism#Han_Dynasty_(206_BCE–220_CE)" title="Chinese Buddhism">Chinese Buddhism §&#160;Han Dynasty (206 BCE–220 CE)</a></div>
<p>The famous <a href="/wiki/Tiantai" title="Tiantai">Tiantai</a> monk <a href="/wiki/Zhiyi" title="Zhiyi">Zhiyi</a>, established a monastery at Jade Spring Mountain in Hubei, in the sixth century. "Historical" records claimed that he had to overcome a local dragon deity before it could be built. Fortuitously, the monastery was located near the burial place of Guan Yu, where there was a local cult that held him as a deity. Over time interactions with the local people led the monks to elevate Guan Yu as a supernatural being, referring to him as Lord Guan. A story was developed that he had aided in construction of the monastery. In <i>Romance of the Three Kingdoms</i> the association of Guan Yu and the monastery was included in the narrative. In the novel, Guan Yu, was beheaded on orders from Sun Quan. His spirit appears to the Monk Pujing and asks him to return his head. Pujing reminds him of the generals he had beheaded. Guan Yu's sprit comprehends and disappears (chapter 77). The popularity of the novel then caused the original story of the dragon to be "largely pushed out of sight".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Ter&#95;Haar&#95;48-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ter_Haar-48"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>48<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Pages: 26–34">&#58;&#8202;26–34&#8202;</span></sup>
Lord Guan is still reverenced today as a Bodhisattva in Buddhist tradition.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>49<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Adaptations">Adaptations</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_of_the_Three_Kingdoms&amp;action=edit&amp;section=21" title="Edit section: Adaptations"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">For a more comprehensive list, see <a href="/wiki/List_of_media_adaptations_of_Romance_of_the_Three_Kingdoms" title="List of media adaptations of Romance of the Three Kingdoms">List of media adaptations of Romance of the Three Kingdoms</a>.</div>
<p>The story of the <i>Romance of the Three Kingdoms</i> has been retold in numerous forms including television series, manga, video games and fan fiction.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Fan_fiction">Fan fiction</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_of_the_Three_Kingdoms&amp;action=edit&amp;section=22" title="Edit section: Fan fiction"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>Fan fiction about <i>Romance of the Three Kingdoms</i> is a form of online cultural adaptation of the novel of the same name. As with many fan fiction works, the main producers and consumers are young women, and in this case, young Chinese women.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-:2&#95;50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:2-50"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>50<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Scholars argue that the emergence of this type of adaptation was motivated by the marginalization and heavily stereotyped female characters as well as unexplored plotlines in the original text.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-:2&#95;50-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:2-50"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>50<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The Battle of the Red Cliff and Liu Bei’s answer after Guan Yu and Zhang Fei complained about his growing intimacy with Zhuge Liang are two scenes containing such plotlines.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-:2&#95;50-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:2-50"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>50<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Common couples derived from <i>Romance of the Three Kingdoms</i> include Liu Bei/Zhuge Liang, often referred to as Xuan/Liang, and Cao Cao/Guan Yu, or Cao/Guan.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-:2&#95;50-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:2-50"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>50<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Both follow the dominant/submissive structure typical of Japanese "<a href="/wiki/Boys%27_love" title="Boys&#39; love">boys' love</a>" (BL), are closely tied to the original story and often require the reader to be familiar with the work the fan fiction is derived from.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>51<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>52<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>53<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Liu Bei's tendency to share his bed with good friends like Guan Yu, Zhang Fei and Zhao Yun popularized the trope in which one character watches another male's body in sleep.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-:3&#95;54-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:3-54"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>54<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The vulnerability associated with this trope goes hand in hand with the use of adjectives associated with female beauty to physically describe submissive characters like Zhuge Liang. According to scholars, this practice was popularized by the idea of "soft-masculinity" in contemporary China and now reinforces this same “soft-masculinity”.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>55<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Finally, the progressiveness of <i>Romance of the Three Kingdoms</i> fan fiction comes from the transformation of the political discourse into a sexual discourse and from the pleasure derived from producing and consuming fan fiction.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-:2&#95;50-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:2-50"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>50<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Translations">Translations</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_of_the_Three_Kingdoms&amp;action=edit&amp;section=23" title="Edit section: Translations"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Manchu">Manchu</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_of_the_Three_Kingdoms&amp;action=edit&amp;section=24" title="Edit section: Manchu"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Jurchen_people" title="Jurchen people">Jurchen</a> chieftain <a href="/wiki/Nurhaci" title="Nurhaci">Nurhaci</a> was an avid reader of the <i>Romance of the Three Kingdoms</i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Water_Margin" title="Water Margin">Water Margin</a></i>, learning all he knew about Chinese military and political strategies from them.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>56<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>57<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>58<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Thus, when his descendants founded the Qing dynasty and became the rulers of China, the book was one of the first Chinese books to be translated into their <a href="/wiki/Manchu_language" title="Manchu language">Manchu language</a> along with military manuals.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>59<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>60<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-babelstone.co.uk&#95;61-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-babelstone.co.uk-61"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>61<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-jstor.org&#95;62-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-jstor.org-62"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>62<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>  Indeed, it is one of only two Chinese novels that had a Manchu translation put into print during the Qing dynasty (the other being <i><a href="/wiki/Jin_Ping_Mei" title="Jin Ping Mei">Jin Ping Mei</a></i>).<sup id="cite&#95;ref-babelstone.co.uk&#95;61-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-babelstone.co.uk-61"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>61<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>A Manchu translation of the <i>Romance</i>, known in Manchu as <i>Ilan gurun-i bithe</i> (<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1237794275">.mw-parser-output .font-mong{font-family:"Menk Hawang Tig","Menk Qagan Tig","Menk Garqag Tig","Menk Har_a Tig","Menk Scnin Tig","Oyun Gurban Ulus Tig","Oyun Qagan Tig","Oyun Garqag Tig","Oyun Har_a Tig","Oyun Scnin Tig","Oyun Agula Tig","Mongolian Baiti","Noto Sans Mongolian","Mongolian Universal White","Mongol Usug","Mongolian White","MongolianScript","Code2000","Menksoft Qagan"}.mw-parser-output .font-mong-mnc,.mw-parser-output .font-mong:lang(mnc-Mong),.mw-parser-output .font-mong:lang(dta-Mong),.mw-parser-output .font-mong:lang(sjo-Mong){font-family:"Abkai Xanyan","Abkai Xanyan LA","Abkai Xanyan VT","Abkai Xanyan XX","Abkai Xanyan SC","Abkai Buleku","Daicing White","Mongolian Baiti","Noto Sans Mongolian","Mongolian Universal White"}</style><span class="font-mong" style="display:inline-block; font-weight:normal; font-size: 1.25em; line-height: 1.2em; -webkit-writing-mode: vertical-lr; -o-writing-mode: vertical-lr; -ms-writing-mode: tb-lr; writing-mode: tb-lr; writing-mode: vertical-lr;; text-orientation: sideways; vertical-align:text-top;">ᡳᠯᠠᠨ<br />ᡤᡠᡵᡠᠨ ᡳ<br />ᠪᡳᡨᡥᡝ</span>), was first attempted in 1631 by the eminent scholar <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dahai&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dahai (page does not exist)">Dahai</a> (<span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh">達海</span></span>; 1595–1632), but he died the following year before it could be finished. A complete translation based on the 1522 edition of the novel was done in 1647 and published in 1650 by a team of high-ranking officials including <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kicungge&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kicungge (page does not exist)">Kicungge</a> (<span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh">祁充格</span></span>; d.&#160;1651) and <a href="/wiki/Fan_Wencheng" title="Fan Wencheng">Fan Wencheng</a> (1597–1666), commissioned by the prince-regent <a href="/wiki/Dorgon" title="Dorgon">Dorgon</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-babelstone.co.uk&#95;61-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-babelstone.co.uk-61"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>61<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>63<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> This is the first translation of the <i>Romance</i> that could be dated with certainty in any language.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>64<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The Manchu translation was itself translated into a number of languages including <a href="/wiki/Xibe_language" title="Xibe language">Xibe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mongolian_language" title="Mongolian language">Mongolian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Korean_language" title="Korean language">Korean</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tibetan_script" title="Tibetan script">Tibetan</a> and <a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">French</a>. It was also back-translated into Chinese in a bilingual Manchu-Chinese edition during the <a href="/wiki/Yongzheng_Emperor" title="Yongzheng Emperor">Yongzheng</a> period (1723–1735).<sup id="cite&#95;ref-babelstone.co.uk&#95;61-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-babelstone.co.uk-61"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>61<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The French translation, <i>San-koué-tchy (Ilan kouroun-i pithé): Histoire des Trois Royaumes</i> (1845-1851), by <a href="/wiki/Th%C3%A9odore_Pavie" title="Théodore Pavie">Théodore Pavie</a> was initially intended to include the full novel. However, only two volumes of a planned multi-volume set were published.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Bramao-Ramos&#95;65-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bramao-Ramos-65"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>65<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 65,86">&#58;&#8202;65,86&#8202;</span></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Pavie&#95;v1&#95;66-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pavie_v1-66"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>66<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Pavie&#95;v2&#95;67-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pavie_v2-67"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>67<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Volume 2 ends with the preparation for the Battle of Fankou, corresponding to Chapter 35 in the Mao edition. Pavie also published one of the novel's stories, the execution of Yu Ji by <a href="/wiki/Sun_Ce#Literary_depictions" title="Sun Ce">Sun Ce</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Pavie&#95;68-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pavie-68"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>68<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> as a novella in 1851.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Korean">Korean</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_of_the_Three_Kingdoms&amp;action=edit&amp;section=25" title="Edit section: Korean"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>The <i>Romance of the Three Kingdoms</i> has achieved the utmost "canonical status" in Korea, Japan, and Vietnam.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Kwon&#95;book&#95;69-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kwon_book-69"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>69<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 1">&#58;&#8202;1&#8202;</span></sup> It was and is to this day massively popular in Korea where it has been modified and re-created to reflect cultural agendas.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Kwon&#95;book&#95;69-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kwon_book-69"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>69<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 1 note 1">&#58;&#8202;1 note 1&#8202;</span></sup> It has even been called "the national novel of Korea", and author Hyuk-chan Kwon adopted that designation in his 2023 book, <i>How Three Kingdoms Became a National Novel of Korea: From Sanguozhi Yanyi to Samgukchi</i> [i.e. from the Chinese to the Korean].<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Kwon&#95;book&#95;69-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kwon_book-69"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>69<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 6">&#58;&#8202;6&#8202;</span></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Rental_copy_Romance_of_Three_Kingdoms-Vol_1-1906-cover_binding_%26_1st_page.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Rental_copy_Romance_of_Three_Kingdoms-Vol_1-1906-cover_binding_%26_1st_page.jpg/250px-Rental_copy_Romance_of_Three_Kingdoms-Vol_1-1906-cover_binding_%26_1st_page.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="140" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Rental_copy_Romance_of_Three_Kingdoms-Vol_1-1906-cover_binding_%26_1st_page.jpg/500px-Rental_copy_Romance_of_Three_Kingdoms-Vol_1-1906-cover_binding_%26_1st_page.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="2292" data-file-height="1288" /></a><figcaption>Rental copy of <i>Romance of the Three Kingdoms</i>, Vol. 1, 1906: cover with binding and first page. Handwritten in vernacular Korean.</figcaption></figure>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Zhang_Fei_and_Ma_Chao-Korean-1919-cover_%26_first_page.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Zhang_Fei_and_Ma_Chao-Korean-1919-cover_%26_first_page.jpg/250px-Zhang_Fei_and_Ma_Chao-Korean-1919-cover_%26_first_page.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="189" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Zhang_Fei_and_Ma_Chao-Korean-1919-cover_%26_first_page.jpg/500px-Zhang_Fei_and_Ma_Chao-Korean-1919-cover_%26_first_page.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="1277" data-file-height="964" /></a><figcaption><i>The True Story of Zhang Fei and Ma Chao</i> Guangdong Bookstore, Beijing, 1919: cover and first page. Printed in vernacular Korean with metal type.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The <i>Records of the Three Kingdoms</i> (Chen Shou's original historical chronicle) was imported to Korean kingdoms of <a href="/wiki/Goguryeo" title="Goguryeo">Goguryeo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Goryeo" title="Goryeo">Goryeo</a>. A commentary by <a href="/wiki/Kim_Pusik" title="Kim Pusik">Kim Pusik</a> from 1145 CE praised the ruler-subject relationship of Liu Bei and Zhuge Liang.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Kwon&#95;book&#95;69-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kwon_book-69"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>69<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 40">&#58;&#8202;40&#8202;</span></sup> During the <a href="/wiki/Joseon" title="Joseon">Joseon</a> dynasty, the novel <i>Romance of the Three Kingdoms</i> became widespread as hand-written manuscripts and wooden block prints. Rental copies were affordable and popular. <a href="/wiki/Ttakchibon" title="Ttakchibon">Ttakchibon</a> editions (printed with metal type) loosely based on selected parts of the novel, also became available. <i>Chang Pa Ma Cho</i> [The True Story of Zhang Fei and Ma Chao], for example, is based on Chapters 27 to 73. It greatly overemphasizes their prowess by having them do feats originally carried out by Guan Yu and Zhao Zilong.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Kwon&#95;book&#95;69-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kwon_book-69"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>69<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Pages: 120–130">&#58;&#8202;120–130&#8202;</span></sup>
</p><p>However, there was resistance to the novel (and fiction in general) among the <a href="/wiki/Yangban" title="Yangban">yangban</a> [ruling class] literati for its historical inaccuracies and entertaining style. For example, Neo-Confucian scholar <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ki_Taes%C5%ADng&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ki Taesŭng (page does not exist)">Ki Taesŭng</a><span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;">&#160;&#40;<a href="https://ko.wikipedia.org/wiki/%EA%B8%B0%EB%8C%80%EC%8A%B9" class="extiw" title="ko:기대승">ko</a>&#41;</span> (1527–1572) admonished <a href="/wiki/Seonjo_of_Joseon" title="Seonjo of Joseon">King Seonjo</a> not to read it, calling it "a collection of trivial sayings edited by some rascals". He was particularly critical of stories of Zhang Fei making ten thousand soldiers flee by producing one shout, as well as the Diaochan and Red Cliffs stories.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Kwon&#95;book&#95;69-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kwon_book-69"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>69<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Pages: 14–15">&#58;&#8202;14–15&#8202;</span></sup>
</p><p>However, acceptance of the novel dramatically improved following the <a href="/wiki/Imjin_War" title="Imjin War">Imjin War</a> (when Joseon Korea was invaded by the Japanese) and the <a href="/wiki/Qing_invasion_of_Joseon" title="Qing invasion of Joseon">Qing invasion</a>. The invasions created a surge of nationalism, and the novel became popular among all literate classes.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Kwon&#95;book&#95;69-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kwon_book-69"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>69<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Pages: 40, 72">&#58;&#8202;40,&#8202;72&#8202;</span></sup>
</p><p>Modern translations of the novel were initiated during the Japanese colonial period when a translation by <a href="/wiki/Eiji_Yoshikawa" title="Eiji Yoshikawa">Eiji Yoshikawa</a> (first serialized in 1939) was circulated in Japan and Korea.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Kwon&#95;book&#95;69-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kwon_book-69"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>69<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Pages: 109, 132–133, 137">&#58;&#8202;109,&#8202;132–133,&#8202;137&#8202;</span></sup> <a href="/wiki/Yi_Munyeol" title="Yi Munyeol">Yi Mun-yol</a> published a version in Korean in 1988. As of 2023, his translation of the novel has sold over 20 million copies, making it Korea's number one best-selling novel of all time.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Kwon&#95;book&#95;69-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kwon_book-69"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>69<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 145">&#58;&#8202;145&#8202;</span></sup>
</p><p>The Eiji Yoshikawa and Yi Mun-yol versions were not mere simple translations. The Yoshikawa version has <a href="/wiki/Samurai" title="Samurai">samurai</a> overtones.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Kwon&#95;book&#95;69-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kwon_book-69"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>69<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 139">&#58;&#8202;139&#8202;</span></sup> For example, while Luo Guanzhong does not continue the story of Diaochan beyond the assassination of Dong Zhuo by Lü Bu (chapter 9), Yoshikawa extends the story and has her commit suicide to protect her honor."<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Kwon&#95;thesis&#95;46-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kwon_thesis-46"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>46<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 294">&#58;&#8202;294&#8202;</span></sup> On the other hand, an extension her story by Yi depicts her as "an earthy and licentious woman rather than a martyr who sacrifices her chastity for the greater good".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Kwon&#95;thesis&#95;46-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kwon_thesis-46"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>46<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 296">&#58;&#8202;296&#8202;</span></sup>
</p><p>In Korea, Guan Yu has become venerated in Buddhist tradition largely due to his representation in the <i>Romance of the Thee Kingdoms</i>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Kwon&#95;book&#95;69-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kwon_book-69"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>69<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 58">&#58;&#8202;58&#8202;</span></sup> This differs from the circumstance in China where Buddhists began veneration of Guan Yu centuries earlier. When a Chinese army was sent to Korea during the Imjin War to repel the Japanese invasion, the Ming generals insisted that the Koreans build a shrine to Guan Yu. The Korean leaders were opposed but forced to comply.
</p><p>Nevertheless, as the war continued, the Koreans began to look to Guan Yu for help on the battlefield. Folk stories about his help were compiled into the novel <i><a href="/wiki/Imjin_nok" title="Imjin nok">Imjin nok</a></i>. In one of the stories, a leader of the Japanese army has a dream in which Guan Yu appears. His speech to the <a href="/wiki/Daimyo" title="Daimyo">daimyo</a> includes the lines:
</p>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1244412712" /><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>I am Marquis of Shouting, Kuan Yunch’ang [Guan Yu], of the Three Kingdoms of the past. I am now entrusting myself to the state of Chosŏn [Joseon] to weather out the storm. Barbaric Japanese bandits, how dare you invade Chosŏn? When I beheaded the commanders of five passes, hundreds of thousands of heroes all died at my hands. … If you do not wish to meet sudden death, evacuate your position and retreat at once.</p></blockquote><div class="templatequotecite"><p style="display: inline; padding-left: 2.3em;">—&#8202;Hyuk-Chan Kwon (2023)<span style="display:none" data-plural="0"></span></p></div>
<p>The reference to the five passes is based on the story in the novel in which Guan Yu kills six of Cao Cao's generals guarding five passes (chapter 27) — not the historical record.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Kwon&#95;book&#95;69-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kwon_book-69"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>69<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 64">&#58;&#8202;64&#8202;</span></sup>
</p><p>After the war, the Ming Emperor required construction of a second, much grander temple. Construction of the second one, <a href="/wiki/Dongmyo" title="Dongmyo">Dongmyo</a> [the East Lord Guan temple] (still extant), was extraordinarily expensive and caused great hardship. Decades later, the Joseon rulers recognized the Guan Yu cult as a legitimate religion.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>70<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
Because of his heroic qualities, contemporary Koreans continue to accept Guan Yu as a "national hero".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Kwon&#95;book&#95;69-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kwon_book-69"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>69<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 66">&#58;&#8202;66&#8202;</span></sup>
</p>
<figure typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Sam_Kok_(in_Javaans_schrift_recto_zijde).JPG" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Sam_Kok_%28in_Javaans_schrift_recto_zijde%29.JPG/250px-Sam_Kok_%28in_Javaans_schrift_recto_zijde%29.JPG" decoding="async" width="200" height="266" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Sam_Kok_%28in_Javaans_schrift_recto_zijde%29.JPG/330px-Sam_Kok_%28in_Javaans_schrift_recto_zijde%29.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Sam_Kok_%28in_Javaans_schrift_recto_zijde%29.JPG/500px-Sam_Kok_%28in_Javaans_schrift_recto_zijde%29.JPG 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="1062" /></a><figcaption>A translated version of <i>Romance of the Three Kingdoms</i> in <a href="/wiki/Javanese_language" title="Javanese language">Javanese</a>, from early 20th-century Indonesia</figcaption></figure>
<figure typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Tamnan_Nangsue_Sam_Kok_(1928,_cover).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Tamnan_Nangsue_Sam_Kok_%281928%2C_cover%29.jpg/250px-Tamnan_Nangsue_Sam_Kok_%281928%2C_cover%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="314" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Tamnan_Nangsue_Sam_Kok_%281928%2C_cover%29.jpg/330px-Tamnan_Nangsue_Sam_Kok_%281928%2C_cover%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Tamnan_Nangsue_Sam_Kok_%281928%2C_cover%29.jpg/500px-Tamnan_Nangsue_Sam_Kok_%281928%2C_cover%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1500" data-file-height="2357" /></a><figcaption>The cover of a 1928 <a href="/wiki/Thai_language" title="Thai language">Thai language</a> appendix of the novel titled <i>History of the Romance of the Three Kingdoms</i>, with notes by Prince <a href="/wiki/Damrong_Rajanubhab" title="Damrong Rajanubhab">Damrong Rajanubhab</a>, from the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Society_of_Thailand" title="Royal Society of Thailand">Royal Society of Thailand</a>. <i>Romance of the Three Kingdoms</i> has been described as having "a tremendous impact on the Thai worldview".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>71<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></figcaption></figure>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="English">English</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_of_the_Three_Kingdoms&amp;action=edit&amp;section=26" title="Edit section: English"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>The <i>Romance of the Three Kingdoms</i> has been translated into English a number of times.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Excerpts">Excerpts</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_of_the_Three_Kingdoms&amp;action=edit&amp;section=27" title="Edit section: Excerpts"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>The first known translation was performed in 1907 by John G. Steele and consisted of a single chapter excerpt that was distributed in China to students learning English at Presbyterian missionary schools.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-taylor1998&#95;10-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-taylor1998-10"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>10<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Translations intended for British readers were published as journal articles. Jia Fang and Yanfang Hou list six journals with translations or introductions from 1816 to 1906.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>72<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The first of these to include a translation, <i>The Death of the Celebrated Minister Tung-cho</i> [Dong Zhuo], was published by Peter P. Thoms. It was serialized in <i><a href="/wiki/The_Asiatic_Journal_and_Monthly_Miscellany" class="mw-redirect" title="The Asiatic Journal and Monthly Miscellany">The Asiatic Journal and Monthly Miscellany</a></i> in three articles in 1920 and 1921, covering Chapters 8 and 9 of the novel.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Thoms&#95;part&#95;1&#95;73-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thoms_part_1-73"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>73<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Thoms&#95;part&#95;2&#95;74-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thoms_part_2-74"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>74<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Thoms&#95;part&#95;3&#95;75-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thoms_part_3-75"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>75<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Thoms, a self-taught printer for the East India Company, was stationed in Macau. He considered it his mission to be mediator and a teacher of Chinese culture for the English. He misunderstood the <i>Romance</i> as history instead of a fictional novel, and modified the text to make it more accessible and educational to his readers.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Sojung&#95;Kim&#95;76-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sojung_Kim-76"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>76<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Herbert_A._Giles" class="mw-redirect" title="Herbert A. Giles">Herbert A. Giles</a> included an excerpt in his 1923 <i>Gems of Chinese Literature</i>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>77<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Z. Q. Parker published a 1925 translation containing four episodes from the novel including the events of the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Red_Cliffs" title="Battle of Red Cliffs">Battle of Red Cliffs</a>, while Yang Xianyi and Gladys Yang published excerpts in 1981, including chapters 43–50.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-taylor1998&#95;10-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-taylor1998-10"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>10<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Abridged">Abridged</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_of_the_Three_Kingdoms&amp;action=edit&amp;section=28" title="Edit section: Abridged"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>In 1976, Moss Roberts published an abridged translation of the novel, presenting approximately one-fourth of the original text. This edition featured maps and over 40 woodblock illustrations derived from three Chinese versions of the work.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-taylor1998&#95;10-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-taylor1998-10"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>10<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Designed to be accessible to college students and general readers, Roberts’ abridgment employed a mixed approach: translating entire chapters, providing partial translations of others, and summarizing the remainder in italicized text.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-taylor1998&#95;10-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-taylor1998-10"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>10<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> This translation includes approximately 100 pages of endnotes, detailed maps, and an extensive essay by Roberts discussing the text and its context.
</p><p>In 2018, Penguin Classics released a new abridged translation by Martin Palmer, assisted by He Yun, Jay Ramsay, and Victoria Finlay. Palmer's version covers the full narrative by including at least portions of all 120 chapters, ensuring continuity without gaps in the story. Unlike Roberts' earlier approach, Palmer translated only the most significant episodes in full while summarizing the rest.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>78<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Unabridged">Unabridged</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_of_the_Three_Kingdoms&amp;action=edit&amp;section=29" title="Edit section: Unabridged"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>A complete and faithful translation of the novel was published in two volumes in 1925 by <a href="/wiki/Charles_Henry_Brewitt-Taylor" title="Charles Henry Brewitt-Taylor">Charles Henry Brewitt-Taylor</a>, a long time official of the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Maritime_Customs_Service" title="Chinese Maritime Customs Service">Chinese Maritime Customs Service</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-taylor1998&#95;10-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-taylor1998-10"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>10<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The translation was well written, but lacked any supplementary materials such as maps or character lists that would aid Western readers; a 1959 reprint was published that included maps and an introduction by Roy Andrew Miller to assist foreign readers.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-taylor1998&#95;10-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-taylor1998-10"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>10<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>After decades of work, Moss Roberts published a full translation in 1991 complete with an afterword, eleven maps, a list of characters, titles, terms, and offices, and almost 100 pages of notes from Mao Zonggang's commentaries and other scholarly sources.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-taylor1998&#95;10-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-taylor1998-10"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>10<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Roberts's complete translation remains faithful to the original; it is reliable yet still matches the tone and style of the classic text.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-taylor1998&#95;10-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-taylor1998-10"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>10<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Yang Ye, a professor in Chinese Literature at the <a href="/wiki/UC_Riverside" class="mw-redirect" title="UC Riverside">UC Riverside</a>, wrote in <i>Encyclopedia of Literary Translation into English</i> (1998) that Roberts's translation "supersedes Brewitt-Taylor's translation and will no doubt remain the definitive English version for many years to come".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-taylor1998&#95;10-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-taylor1998-10"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>10<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Roberts's translation was republished in 1995 by the Foreign Languages Press without the illustrations.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-ChineseBookshop&#95;79-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ChineseBookshop-79"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>79<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In 2014, Tuttle published a new, three-volume translation of the novel, translated by Yu Sumei and edited by Ronald C. Iverson. According to its publisher, this translation is an unabridged "dynamic translation" intended to be more readable than past English translations of the novel.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>80<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="See_also">See also</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_of_the_Three_Kingdoms&amp;action=edit&amp;section=30" title="Edit section: See also"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>

<li><a href="/wiki/List_of_fictional_people_of_the_Three_Kingdoms" title="List of fictional people of the Three Kingdoms">List of fictional people of the Three Kingdoms</a>, list of fictional people of the Three Kingdoms period (220–280)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/List_of_fictitious_stories_in_Romance_of_the_Three_Kingdoms" title="List of fictitious stories in Romance of the Three Kingdoms">List of fictitious stories in <i>Romance of the Three Kingdoms</i></a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Military_history_of_the_Three_Kingdoms" title="Military history of the Three Kingdoms">Military history of the Three Kingdoms</a></li>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Citations">Citations</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_of_the_Three_Kingdoms&amp;action=edit&amp;section=31" title="Edit section: Citations"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>

.cs1-kern-right{padding-right:0.2em}.mw-parser-output .citation .mw-selflink{font-weight:inherit}@media screen{.mw-parser-output .cs1-format{font-size:95%}html.skin-theme-clientpref-night .mw-parser-output .cs1-maint{color:#18911f}}@media screen and (prefers-color-scheme:dark){html.skin-theme-clientpref-os .mw-parser-output .cs1-maint{color:#18911f}}</style><cite id="CITEREFKim2008" class="citation web cs1 cs1-prop-unfit">Kim, Hyung-eun (11 July 2008). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20111225205804/http://koreajoongangdaily.joinsmsn.com/news/article/article.aspx?aid=2892148">"(Review) Historical China film lives up to expectations"</a>. <i>Korea JoongAng Daily</i>. Archived from the original on 25 December 2011. <q>The <i>Romance of the Three Kingdoms</i> is comparable to the Bible in East Asia. It's one of the most-read if not, the most-read classics in the region.</q></cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Korea+JoongAng+Daily&amp;rft.atitle=%28Review%29+Historical+China+film+lives+up+to+expectations&amp;rft.date=2008-07-11&amp;rft.aulast=Kim&amp;rft.aufirst=Hyung-eun&amp;rft&#95;id=http%3A%2F%2Fkoreajoongangdaily.joinsmsn.com%2Fnews%2Farticle%2Farticle.aspx%3Faid%3D2892148&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARomance+of+the+Three+Kingdoms" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-3">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite id="CITEREFShoji2008" class="citation web cs1">Shoji, Kaori (6 November 2008). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20210602215908/https://www.japantimes.co.jp/culture/2008/11/06/culture/war-as-wisdom-and-gore/">"War as wisdom and gore"</a>. <i>The Japan Times</i>. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.japantimes.co.jp/culture/2008/11/06/culture/war-as-wisdom-and-gore/">the original</a> on 2 June 2021<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">8 May</span> 2020</span>. <q>In East Asia, <i>Romance</i> is on par with the works of Shakespeare... in the same way that people in Britain grow up studying <i>Hamlet</i> and <i>Macbeth</i>.</q></cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Japan+Times&amp;rft.atitle=War+as+wisdom+and+gore&amp;rft.date=2008-11-06&amp;rft.aulast=Shoji&amp;rft.aufirst=Kaori&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.japantimes.co.jp%2Fculture%2F2008%2F11%2F06%2Fculture%2Fwar-as-wisdom-and-gore%2F&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARomance+of+the+Three+Kingdoms" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>

January 2011.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Digital+Taiwan&amp;rft.atitle=A+Thousand%2C+Thousand+Churning+Waves-+The+Legendary+Red+Cliff+Heritage&amp;rft.date=2011-01&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fculture.teldap.tw%2Fculture%2Findex.php%3Foption%3Dcom&#95;content%26view%3Darticle%26id%3D428&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARomance+of+the+Three+Kingdoms" class="Z3988"></span></span>

</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-42"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-42">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite class="citation web cs1 cs1-prop-foreign-lang-source"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.hanyucidian.org/dictionary/entry?dictionaryCode=hydcdcx&amp;entryName=%E4%B8%89%E4%B8%AA%E8%87%AD%E7%9A%AE%E5%8C%A0%EF%BC%8C%E6%8A%B5%E4%B8%AA%E8%AF%B8%E8%91%9B%E4%BA%AE">"Three cobblers are equal to one Zhuge Liang"</a>. <i>A Comprehensive Dictionary of Chinese Proverbs</i> (in Simplified Chinese)<span class="reference-accessdate">. </li>

</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-58"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-58">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite id="CITEREFMairChenWood2013" class="citation book cs1">Mair, Victor H.; Chen, Sanping; Wood, Frances (2013). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=agI7CwAAQBAJ&amp;q=three+kingdoms+nurhaci+romance&amp;pg=PT159"><i>Chinese Lives: The People Who Made a Civilization</i></a> (illustrated&#160;ed.). <li id="cite&#95;note-70"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-70">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite id="CITEREFVan&#95;Lieu2019" class="citation journal cs1">Van Lieu, Joshua (2019). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://oak.go.kr/repository/journal/23093/rks_2019_22_02_87.pdf">"The Guan Yu Cult and Joseon-Qing Visions of State Legitimacy, 1882-1894"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <i>The Review of Korean Studies</i>. <b>22</b> (2): <span class="nowrap">87–</span>122. <a href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.25024%2Freview.2019.22.2.005">10.25024/review.2019.22.2.005</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite&#95;note-71"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-71">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite id="CITEREFLee2013" class="citation book cs1">Lee, Khoon Choy (2013). <i>Golden Dragon and Purple Phoenix</i>. <a href="/wiki/World_Scientific" title="World Scientific">World Scientific</a>. p.&#160;16. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9789814518499" title="Special:BookSources/9789814518499"><bdi>9789814518499</bdi></a>. <q>The novel had a tremendous impact on the Thai worldview.</q></cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Golden+Dragon+and+Purple+Phoenix&amp;rft.pages=16&amp;rft.pub=World+Scientific&amp;rft.date=2013&amp;rft.isbn=9789814518499&amp;rft.aulast=Lee&amp;rft.aufirst=Khoon+Choy&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARomance+of+the+Three+Kingdoms" class="Z3988"></span></span>

Hegel. <a href="/wiki/Singapore" title="Singapore">Singapore</a>: Tuttle Publishing. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780804834681" title="Special:BookSources/9780804834681"><bdi>9780804834681</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Romance+of+the+Three+Kingdoms&amp;rft.place=Singapore&amp;rft.pub=Tuttle+Publishing&amp;rft.date=2002&amp;rft.isbn=9780804834681&amp;rft.aulast=Luo&amp;rft.aufirst=Guanzhong&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fdetails%2Frangsamkoktngcha00luog&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARomance+of+the+Three+Kingdoms" class="Z3988"></span></li>
<li><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite id="CITEREFLuo2006" class="citation book cs1">Luo, Guanzhong (2006). <i>Three Kingdoms</i>. English translation by Moss Roberts, Introduction by Shi Changyu. <a href="/wiki/Beijing" title="Beijing">Beijing</a>: Foreign Language Press. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/7-119-00590-1" title="Special:BookSources/7-119-00590-1"><bdi>7-119-00590-1</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Three+Kingdoms&amp;rft.place=Beijing&amp;rft.pub=Foreign+Language+Press&amp;rft.date=2006&amp;rft.isbn=7-119-00590-1&amp;rft.aulast=Luo&amp;rft.aufirst=Guanzhong&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARomance+of+the+Three+Kingdoms" class="Z3988"></span></li>
<li><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite id="CITEREFLuo2014" class="citation book cs1">Luo, Guanzhong (2014). <i>The Three Kingdoms</i>. Vol.&#160;1. English translation by Yu Sumei, Edited by Ronald C. Iverson. <a href="/wiki/Singapore" title="Singapore">Singapore</a>: Tuttle Publishing. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780804843935" title="Special:BookSources/9780804843935"><bdi>9780804843935</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Three+Kingdoms&amp;rft.place=Singapore&amp;rft.pub=Tuttle+Publishing&amp;rft.date=2014&amp;rft.isbn=9780804843935&amp;rft.aulast=Luo&amp;rft.aufirst=Guanzhong&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARomance+of+the+Three+Kingdoms" class="Z3988"></span></li>
<li><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite id="CITEREFLuo2014" class="citation book cs1">Luo, Guanzhong (2014). <i>The Three Kingdoms</i>. Vol.&#160;2. English translation by Yu Sumei, Edited by Ronald C. Iverson. <a href="/wiki/Singapore" title="Singapore">Singapore</a>: Tuttle Publishing. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780804843942" title="Special:BookSources/9780804843942"><bdi>9780804843942</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Three+Kingdoms&amp;rft.place=Singapore&amp;rft.pub=Tuttle+Publishing&amp;rft.date=2014&amp;rft.isbn=9780804843942&amp;rft.aulast=Luo&amp;rft.aufirst=Guanzhong&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARomance+of+the+Three+Kingdoms" class="Z3988"></span></li>
<li><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite id="CITEREFLuo2014" class="citation book cs1">Luo, Guanzhong (2014). <i>The Three Kingdoms</i>. Vol.&#160;3. English translation by Yu Sumei, Edited by Ronald C. Iverson. <a href="/wiki/Singapore" title="Singapore">Singapore</a>: Tuttle Publishing. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780804843959" title="Special:BookSources/9780804843959"><bdi>9780804843959</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Three+Kingdoms&amp;rft.place=Singapore&amp;rft.pub=Tuttle+Publishing&amp;rft.date=2014&amp;rft.isbn=9780804843959&amp;rft.aulast=Luo&amp;rft.aufirst=Guanzhong&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARomance+of+the+Three+Kingdoms" class="Z3988"></span></li>
<li><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite id="CITEREFMcLaren2012" class="citation journal cs1">McLaren, Anne E. (2012). <span class="id-lock-subscription" title="Paid subscription required"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1179/mon.2012.60.1.003">"Writing History, Writing Fiction: The Remaking of Cao Cao in Song Historiography"</a></span>. <i>Monumenta Serica</i>. <b>60</b> (1): <span class="nowrap">45–</span>69. <a href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1179%2Fmon.2012.60.1.003">10.1179/mon.2012.60.1.003</a>. <a href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://search.worldcat.org/issn/0254-9948">0254-9948</a>. <a href="/wiki/S2CID_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="S2CID (identifier)">S2CID</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://api.semanticscholar.org/CorpusID:193917398">193917398</a>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Monumenta+Serica&amp;rft.atitle=Writing+History%2C+Writing+Fiction%3A+The+Remaking+of+Cao+Cao+in+Song+Historiography&amp;rft.volume=60&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.pages=45-69&amp;rft.date=2012&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fapi.semanticscholar.org%2FCorpusID%3A193917398%23id-name%3DS2CID&amp;rft.issn=0254-9948&amp;rft&#95;id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1179%2Fmon.2012.60.1.003&amp;rft.aulast=McLaren&amp;rft.aufirst=Anne+E.&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fdoi.org%2F10.1179%2Fmon.2012.60.1.003&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARomance+of+the+Three+Kingdoms" class="Z3988"></span></li>
<li><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite id="CITEREFLuo2022" class="citation book cs1">Luo, Guanzhong (2022). <i>Il Romanzo dei Tre Regni, 3 vols</i>. title="Classic Chinese Novels">Classic Chinese Novels</a></div></th></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%">Four Classic Novels</th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-odd hlist" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em">
<ul><li><i><a href="/wiki/Water_Margin" title="Water Margin">Water Margin</a></i> (mid-14th century)</li>
<li><i><a class="mw-selflink selflink">Romance of the Three Kingdoms</a></i> (late 14th century)</li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/Journey_to_the_West" title="Journey to the West">Journey to the West</a></i> (c. 1592)</li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/Dream_of_the_Red_Chamber" title="Dream of the Red Chamber">Dream of the Red Chamber</a></i> (mid-18th century)</li></ul>
</div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%">Additional classics</th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-even hlist" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em">

</div></td></tr></tbody></table></div>

</div>

					<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading mw-first-heading"><i>The Prince</i></h1>
							
<div id="p-lang-btn" class="vector-dropdown mw-portlet mw-portlet-lang"  >
	<input type="checkbox" id="p-lang-btn-checkbox" role="button" aria-haspopup="true" data-event-name="ui.dropdown-p-lang-btn" class="vector-dropdown-checkbox mw-interlanguage-selector" aria-label="Go to an article in another language. Available in 76 languages"   >

			<li id="ca-more-view" class="selected vector-more-collapsible-item mw-list-item"><a href="/wiki/The_Prince"><span>Read</span></a></li><li id="ca-more-edit" class="vector-more-collapsible-item mw-list-item"><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Prince&amp;action=edit" title="Edit this page [e]" accesskey="e"><span>Edit</span></a></li><li id="ca-more-history" class="vector-more-collapsible-item mw-list-item"><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Prince&amp;action=history"><span>View history</span></a></li>
		</ul>
		
	</div>
</div>

<div id="p-tb" class="vector-menu mw-portlet mw-portlet-tb"  >
	<div class="vector-menu-heading">

	</div>

				<div id="bodyContent" class="vector-body" aria-labelledby="firstHeading" data-mw-ve-target-container>
					<div class="vector-body-before-content">
							<div class="mw-indicators">
		</div>

						<div id="siteSub" class="noprint">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
					</div>
					<div id="contentSub"><div id="mw-content-subtitle"></div></div>
					
					
					<div id="mw-content-text" class="mw-body-content"><div class="mw-subjectpageheader">
</div><div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" lang="en" dir="ltr"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">Political treatise by Niccolò Machiavelli</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1320445320">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}@media print{body.ns-0 .mw-parser-output .hatnote{display:none!important}}</style><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">This article is about the book by Niccolò Machiavelli. For other uses, see <a href="/wiki/Prince_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="Prince (disambiguation)">Prince (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1316064257">.mw-parser-output .infobox-subbox{padding:0;border:none;margin:-3px;width:auto;min-width:100%;font-size:100%;clear:none;float:none;background-color:transparent;color:inherit}.mw-parser-output .infobox-3cols-child{margin:-3px}.mw-parser-output .infobox .navbar{font-size:100%}@media screen{html.skin-theme-clientpref-night .mw-parser-output .infobox-full-data:not(.notheme)>div:not(.notheme)[style]{background:#1f1f23!important;color:#f8f9fa}}@media screen and (prefers-color-scheme:dark){html.skin-theme-clientpref-os .mw-parser-output .infobox-full-data:not(.notheme)>div:not(.notheme)[style]{background:#1f1f23!important;color:#f8f9fa}}@media(min-width:640px){body.skin--responsive .mw-parser-output .infobox-table{display:table!important}body.skin--responsive .mw-parser-output .infobox-table>caption{display:table-caption!important}body.skin--responsive .mw-parser-output .infobox-table>tbody{display:table-row-group}body.skin--responsive .mw-parser-output .infobox-table th,body.skin--responsive .mw-parser-output .infobox-table td{padding-left:inherit;padding-right:inherit}}</style><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1287740527">.mw-parser-output .ib-book .infobox-title{font-style:italic;padding-bottom:0.2em}.mw-parser-output .ib-book .Z3988{display:none}.mw-parser-output .ib-book .infobox-below{border-top:#aaa 1px solid}</style><table class="infobox ib-book vcard"><caption class="infobox-title">The Prince <span class="Z3988" title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Prince&amp;rft.author=%5B%5BNiccol%C3%B2+Machiavelli%5D%5D&amp;rft.date=1532&amp;rft.pub=Antonio+Blado+d%27Asola&amp;rft.place=Italy"></span></caption><tbody><tr><td colspan="2" class="infobox-image"><span class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Frameless"><a href="/wiki/File:Machiavelli_Principe_Cover_Page.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Machiavelli_Principe_Cover_Page.jpg/250px-Machiavelli_Principe_Cover_Page.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="352" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Machiavelli_Principe_Cover_Page.jpg/500px-Machiavelli_Principe_Cover_Page.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="601" data-file-height="847" /></a></span><div class="infobox-caption">Title page of a 1550 edition</div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">Author</th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/Niccol%C3%B2_Machiavelli" title="Niccolò Machiavelli">Niccolò Machiavelli</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">Original&#160;title</th><td class="infobox-data"><i>De Principatibus / Il Principe</i></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">Language</th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/Italian_language" title="Italian language">Italian</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">Subject</th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/Political_philosophy" title="Political philosophy">Political philosophy</a><br /><a href="/wiki/Political_science" title="Political science">Political science</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">Publisher</th><td class="infobox-data">Antonio Blado d'Asola</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label"><div style="display: inline-block; line-height: 1.2em; padding: .1em 0;">Publication date</div></th><td class="infobox-data">1532</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">Publication place</th><td class="infobox-data">Italy</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">Followed&#160;by</th><td class="infobox-data"><i><a href="/wiki/Discourses_on_Livy" title="Discourses on Livy">Discourses on Livy</a>&#160;</i></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">Text</th><td class="infobox-data"><i><a href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/The_Prince" class="extiw" title="s:The Prince">The Prince</a></i> at <a href="/wiki/Wikisource" title="Wikisource">Wikisource</a></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><i><b>The Prince</b></i> (<a href="/wiki/Italian_language" title="Italian language">Italian</a>: <i lang="it">Il Principe</i> <span class="IPA nowrap" lang="it-Latn-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Italian" title="Help:IPA/Italian">&#91;il<span class="wrap"> </span>ˈprintʃipe&#93;</a></span>; <a href="/wiki/Latin_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Latin language">Latin</a>: <i lang="la">De Principatibus</i>) is a 16th-century political <a href="/wiki/Treatise" title="Treatise">treatise</a> written by the Italian diplomat, philosopher, and <a href="/wiki/Political_philosophy" title="Political philosophy">political theorist</a> <a href="/wiki/Niccol%C3%B2_Machiavelli" title="Niccolò Machiavelli">Niccolò Machiavelli</a> in the form of a realistic instruction guide for new <a href="/wiki/Prince#Prince_as_generic_for_ruler" title="Prince">princes</a>. Many commentators have viewed that one of the main themes of <i>The Prince</i> is that immoral acts are sometimes necessary to achieve political glory.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-:0&#95;1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-1"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>1<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>2<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>From Machiavelli's correspondence, a version was apparently being written in 1513, using a Latin title, <i>De Principatibus</i> (<i>Of Principalities</i>).<sup id="cite&#95;ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>3<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> However, the printed version was not published until 1532, five years after Machiavelli's death. This was carried out with the permission of the <a href="/wiki/Medici" class="mw-redirect" title="Medici">Medici</a> pope <a href="/wiki/Clement_VII" class="mw-redirect" title="Clement VII">Clement VII</a>, but "long before then, in fact since the first appearance of <i>The Prince</i> in manuscript, controversy had swirled about his writings".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>4<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Although <i>The Prince</i> was written as if it were a traditional work in the <i><a href="/wiki/Mirrors_for_princes" title="Mirrors for princes">mirrors for princes</a></i> style, it was generally agreed as being especially innovative.
