These were the English cardinal <a href="/wiki/Reginald_Pole" title="Reginald Pole">Reginald Pole</a> and the Portuguese bishop <a href="/wiki/Jer%C3%B3nimo_Os%C3%B3rio" title="Jerónimo Osório">Jerónimo Osório</a>, both of whom lived for many years in Italy, and the Italian humanist and later bishop, <a href="/wiki/Lancelotto_Politi" title="Lancelotto Politi">Ambrogio Caterino Politi</a>.</p></blockquote>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Emperor_charles_v.png" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/Emperor_charles_v.png/250px-Emperor_charles_v.png" decoding="async" width="250" height="254" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/Emperor_charles_v.png/500px-Emperor_charles_v.png 1.5x" data-file-width="1794" data-file-height="1823" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Emperor_Charles_V" class="mw-redirect" title="Emperor Charles V">Emperor Charles V</a>, or Charles I of Spain. A Catholic king in the first generation to read <i>The Prince</i>.</figcaption></figure>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Henry-VIII-kingofengland_1491-1547.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Henry-VIII-kingofengland_1491-1547.jpg/250px-Henry-VIII-kingofengland_1491-1547.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="431" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Henry-VIII-kingofengland_1491-1547.jpg/500px-Henry-VIII-kingofengland_1491-1547.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="813" data-file-height="1400" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Henry_VIII_of_England" class="mw-redirect" title="Henry VIII of England">Henry VIII of England</a>. A king who eventually split with the Catholic Church, and supported some <a href="/wiki/Protestant" class="mw-redirect" title="Protestant">Protestant</a> ideas in the first generation to read <i>The Prince</i>.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Machiavelli's ideas on how to accrue honor and power as a leader had a profound impact on political leaders throughout the modern West, helped by the new technology of the printing press. Pole reported that it was spoken of highly by his enemy <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Cromwell" title="Thomas Cromwell">Thomas Cromwell</a> in England, and had influenced <a href="/wiki/Henry_VIII" title="Henry VIII">Henry VIII</a> in his turn towards <a href="/wiki/Protestantism" title="Protestantism">Protestantism</a>, and in his tactics, for example during the <a href="/wiki/Pilgrimage_of_Grace" title="Pilgrimage of Grace">Pilgrimage of Grace</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-BireleyP15&#95;50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BireleyP15-50"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>50<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> A copy was also possessed by the Catholic king and emperor <a href="/wiki/Charles_V,_Holy_Roman_Emperor" title="Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor">Charles V</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>51<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In France, after an initially mixed reaction, Machiavelli came to be associated with <a href="/wiki/Catherine_de_Medici" class="mw-redirect" title="Catherine de Medici">Catherine de Medici</a> and the <a href="/wiki/St_Bartholomew%27s_Day_Massacre" class="mw-redirect" title="St Bartholomew&#39;s Day Massacre">St Bartholomew's Day Massacre</a>. As <a href="#CITEREFBireley1990">Bireley (1990</a>:17) reports, in the 16th century, Catholic writers "associated Machiavelli with the Protestants, whereas Protestant authors saw him as Italian and Catholic". In fact, he was apparently influencing both Catholic and Protestant kings.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>52<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>One of the most important early works dedicated to criticism of Machiavelli, especially <i>The Prince</i>, was that of the <a href="/wiki/Huguenot" class="mw-redirect" title="Huguenot">Huguenot</a>, <a href="/wiki/Innocent_Gentillet" title="Innocent Gentillet">Innocent Gentillet</a>, <i>Discourse against Machiavelli</i>, commonly also referred to as <i>Anti Machiavel</i>, published in <a href="/wiki/Geneva" title="Geneva">Geneva</a> in 1576.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>53<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> He accused Machiavelli of being an atheist and accused politicians of his time by saying that they treated his works as the "<a href="/wiki/Koran" class="mw-redirect" title="Koran">Koran</a> of the courtiers".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>54<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Another theme of Gentillet was more in the spirit of Machiavelli himself: he questioned the effectiveness of immoral strategies (just as Machiavelli had himself done, despite also explaining how they could sometimes work). This became the theme of much future political discourse in Europe during the 17th century. This includes the Catholic <a href="/wiki/Counter_Reformation" class="mw-redirect" title="Counter Reformation">Counter Reformation</a> writers summarised by Bireley: <a href="/wiki/Giovanni_Botero" title="Giovanni Botero">Giovanni Botero</a>, <a href="/wiki/Justus_Lipsius" title="Justus Lipsius">Justus Lipsius</a>, Carlo Scribani, <a href="/wiki/Adam_Contzen" title="Adam Contzen">Adam Contzen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pedro_de_Ribadeneira" title="Pedro de Ribadeneira">Pedro de Ribadeneira</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Diego_de_Saavedra_Fajardo" title="Diego de Saavedra Fajardo">Diego de Saavedra Fajardo</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>55<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> These authors criticized Machiavelli, but also followed him in many ways. They accepted the need for a prince to be concerned with reputation, and even a need for cunning and deceit, but compared to Machiavelli, and like later modernist writers, they emphasized <a href="/wiki/Economic_growth" title="Economic growth">economic progress</a> much more than the riskier ventures of war. These authors tended to cite <a href="/wiki/Tacitus" title="Tacitus">Tacitus</a> as their source for realist political advice, rather than Machiavelli, and this pretense came to be known as "<a href="/wiki/Tacitean_studies" title="Tacitean studies">Tacitism</a>".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>56<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Cardinal <a href="/wiki/Reginald_Pole" title="Reginald Pole">Reginald Pole</a> read <i>Il Principe</i> while he was in Italy, and on which he commented: "I found this type of book to be written by an enemy of the human race. It explains every means whereby religion, justice and any inclination toward virtue could be destroyed".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>57<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Modern <a href="/wiki/Materialism" title="Materialism">materialist</a> philosophy developed in the 16th, 17th and 18th century, starting in the generations after Machiavelli. The importance of Machiavelli's realism was noted by many important figures in this endeavor, for example <a href="/wiki/Jean_Bodin" title="Jean Bodin">Jean Bodin</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>58<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Francis_Bacon" title="Francis Bacon">Francis Bacon</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>59<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/James_Harrington_(author)" title="James Harrington (author)">Harrington</a>, <a href="/wiki/John_Milton" title="John Milton">John Milton</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>60<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Baruch_Spinoza" title="Baruch Spinoza">Spinoza</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>61<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Jean-Jacques_Rousseau" title="Jean-Jacques Rousseau">Rousseau</a>, <a href="/wiki/David_Hume" title="David Hume">Hume</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>62<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Edward_Gibbon" title="Edward Gibbon">Edward Gibbon</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Adam_Smith" title="Adam Smith">Adam Smith</a>. Although he was not always mentioned by name as an inspiration, due to his controversy, he is also thought to have been an influence for other major philosophers, such as <a href="/wiki/Michel_de_Montaigne" title="Michel de Montaigne">Montaigne</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>63<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ren%C3%A9_Descartes" title="René Descartes">Descartes</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>64<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Hobbes" title="Thomas Hobbes">Hobbes</a>, <a href="/wiki/John_Locke" title="John Locke">Locke</a><sup id="cite&#95;ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>65<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Montesquieu" title="Montesquieu">Montesquieu</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>66<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Due to the fame (or infamy) of his works, Machiavelli soon became a figure in the <a href="/wiki/Machiavelli_in_popular_culture" title="Machiavelli in popular culture">popular culture</a> of the English stage. Machiavelli is featured as a character in the <a href="/wiki/Prologue" title="Prologue">prologue</a> of <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Marlowe" title="Christopher Marlowe">Christopher Marlowe</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/The_Jew_of_Malta" title="The Jew of Malta">The Jew of Malta</a></i>, and in <a href="/wiki/William_Shakespeare" title="William Shakespeare">William Shakespeare</a>'s tragic plays, such as <i><a href="/wiki/Othello" title="Othello">Othello</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Macbeth" title="Macbeth">Macbeth</a></i>, and <a href="/wiki/Richard_III_(play)" title="Richard III (play)"><i>Richard III</i></a>, feature characters whom are an example of the stage Machiavel, a type of character whom advances themselves politically via devious means.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>67<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> 
</p><p>The republicanism in seventeenth-century England which led to the <a href="/wiki/English_Civil_War" title="English Civil War">English Civil War</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Glorious_Revolution" title="Glorious Revolution">Glorious Revolution</a> and subsequent development of the English Constitution was strongly influenced by Machiavelli's political thought.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>68<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Most of the <a href="/wiki/Founding_Fathers_of_the_United_States" title="Founding Fathers of the United States">Founding Fathers</a> of the <a href="/wiki/American_Revolution" title="American Revolution">American Revolution</a> are known or often proposed to have been strongly influenced by Machiavelli's political works, including <a href="/wiki/Benjamin_Franklin" title="Benjamin Franklin">Benjamin Franklin</a>, <a href="/wiki/James_Madison" title="James Madison">James Madison</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Jefferson" title="Thomas Jefferson">Thomas Jefferson</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Hamilton" title="Alexander Hamilton">Alexander Hamilton</a> and <a href="/wiki/John_Adams" title="John Adams">John Adams</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>69<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>70<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Also, under the guidance of <a href="/wiki/Voltaire" title="Voltaire">Voltaire</a>, <a href="/wiki/Frederick_the_Great" title="Frederick the Great">Frederick the Great</a> of <a href="/wiki/Prussia" title="Prussia">Prussia</a> criticised Machiavelli's conclusions in his "<a href="/wiki/Anti-Machiavel" title="Anti-Machiavel">Anti-Machiavel</a>", published in 1740. At different stages in his life, <a href="/wiki/Napoleon" title="Napoleon">Napoleon I of France</a> wrote extensive comments to <i>The Prince</i>. After his defeat at <a href="/wiki/Waterloo,_Belgium" title="Waterloo, Belgium">Waterloo</a>, these comments were found in the emperor's coach and taken by the Prussian military.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>71<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> 20th century leaders also were influenced by Machiavelli. For example, <a href="/wiki/Italians" title="Italians">Italian</a> dictator <a href="/wiki/Benito_Mussolini" title="Benito Mussolini">Benito Mussolini</a> wrote a discourse on <i>The Prince</i>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>72<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet</a> leader <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Stalin" title="Joseph Stalin">Joseph Stalin</a> read <i>The Prince</i> and annotated his own copy.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>73<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Interpretations">Interpretations</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Prince&amp;action=edit&amp;section=34" title="Edit section: Interpretations"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Timeline_of_composition">Timeline of composition</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Prince&amp;action=edit&amp;section=35" title="Edit section: Timeline of composition"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>There has been much debate of when Machiavelli actually composed The Prince (and his other works).<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Connell&#95;74-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Connell-74"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>74<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Commentators have viewed this question to be of great importance, as some interpreters believe that Machiavelli changed his views between the composition of The Prince, and the composition of <i>The Discourses</i>. Hans Baron is one of such commentators who argued that Machiavelli must have changed his mind dramatically in favor of free republics, after having written <i>The Prince</i>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTEBaron1961&#95;75-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBaron1961-75"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>75<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Harvey Mansfield and Nathan Tarcov, in the introduction to their translation of The Discourses on Livy, state that there are no discrepancies between The Prince and his later works, and that it "seems the safest" to see them "as a pair of works, not much different, if at all, in time of composition."<sup id="cite&#95;ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>76<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Scholar William Connell views that the composition and development of The Prince was a lengthy process with his ideas being revised from 1513 to 1515.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Connell&#95;74-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Connell-74"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>74<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Other_interpretations">Other interpretations</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Prince&amp;action=edit&amp;section=36" title="Edit section: Other interpretations"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p><b>Satire</b>
</p><p>This interpretation was famously put forth by scholar Garrett Mattingly (1958), who stated that "In some ways, Machiavelli's little treatise was just like all the other 'Mirrors of Princes', in other ways it was a diabolical burlesque of all of them, like a political Black Mass."<sup id="cite&#95;ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>77<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>
This position was taken up previously by some of the more prominent <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Enlightenment" title="Age of Enlightenment">Enlightenment</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Philosophes" title="Philosophes">philosophes</a></i>. <a href="/wiki/Diderot" class="mw-redirect" title="Diderot">Diderot</a> speculated that it was a work designed not to mock, but to secretly expose corrupt princely rule. And in his <i><a href="/wiki/Social_Contract_(Rousseau)" class="mw-redirect" title="Social Contract (Rousseau)">The Social Contract</a></i>, the French philosopher <a href="/wiki/Jean-Jacques_Rousseau" title="Jean-Jacques Rousseau">Jean-Jacques Rousseau</a> said: <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1244412712" /></p><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>Machiavelli was a proper man and a good citizen; but, being attached to the court of the Medici, he could not help veiling his love of liberty in the midst of his country's oppression. The choice of his detestable hero, <a href="/wiki/Cesare_Borgia" title="Cesare Borgia">Cesare Borgia</a>, clearly enough shows his hidden aim; and the contradiction between the teaching of the <i>Prince</i> and that of the <i>Discourses on Livy</i> and the <i>History of Florence</i> shows that this profound political thinker has so far been studied only by superficial or corrupt readers. The Court of Rome sternly prohibited his book. I can well believe it; for it is that Court it most clearly portrays.</p></blockquote><div class="templatequotecite"><p style="display: inline; padding-left: 2.3em;">—&#8202;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://constitution.org/2-Authors/jjr/socon_03.htm#23"><i>Social Contract</i>, Book 3, note to Chapter 6</a>.<span style="display:none" data-plural="0"></span></p></div>
<p>However, this line of interpretation is often refuted by those who study Machiavelli's works.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>78<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> For example <a href="/wiki/Isaiah_Berlin" title="Isaiah Berlin">Isaiah Berlin</a> states that he cannot find anything other than Machiavelli's work that "reads less" like a satirical piece.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>79<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Maurizio Viroli writes: "In my opinion, none of these defenses of Machiavelli is valid. The view that The Prince is the "book of Republicans" comes from Rousseau's desire to rescue its author's bad reputation and make The Prince consistent with the Discourses on Livy, the text in which Machiavelli developed a comprehensive republican theory of liberty and government" and added that the claim "misrepresents the meaning of the text."<sup id="cite&#95;ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>80<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p><b>Deceit</b>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Mary_G._Dietz" title="Mary G. Dietz">Mary Dietz</a>, in her essay "Trapping The Prince", writes that Machiavelli's agenda was not to be satirical, as Rousseau had argued, but instead was "offering carefully crafted advice (such as arming the people) designed to undo the ruler if taken seriously and followed."<sup id="cite&#95;ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>81<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> By this account, the aim was to reestablish the republic in Florence. She focuses on three categories in which Machiavelli gives paradoxical advice:
</p>
<ul><li>He discourages liberality and favors deceit to guarantee support from the people. Yet Machiavelli is keenly aware of the fact that an earlier pro-republican coup had been thwarted by the people's inaction that itself stemmed from the prince's liberality.</li>
<li>He supports arming the people despite the fact that he knows the Florentines are decidedly pro-democratic and would oppose the prince.</li>
<li>He encourages the prince to live in the city he conquers. This opposes the Medici's habitual policy of living outside the city. It also makes it easier for rebels or a civilian militia to attack and overthrow the prince.</li></ul>
<p>According to Dietz, the trap never succeeded because Lorenzo – "a suspicious prince" – apparently never read the work of the "former republican."<sup id="cite&#95;ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>82<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Translations">Translations</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Prince&amp;action=edit&amp;section=37" title="Edit section: Translations"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Other_works_by_Machiavelli">Other works by Machiavelli</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Prince&amp;action=edit&amp;section=38" title="Edit section: Other works by Machiavelli"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<ul><li><i><a href="/wiki/Andria_(Machiavelli)" title="Andria (Machiavelli)">The Girl from Andros</a></i></li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/Discourses_on_Livy" title="Discourses on Livy">Discourses on Livy</a></i></li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Art_of_War_(Machiavelli)" class="mw-redirect" title="The Art of War (Machiavelli)">The Art of War</a></i></li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Mandrake" title="The Mandrake">The Mandrake</a></i></li></ul>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="See_also">See also</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Prince&amp;action=edit&amp;section=39" title="Edit section: See also"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Mirrors_for_princes" title="Mirrors for princes">Mirrors for princes</a>, the genre</li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/Secretum_Secretorum" title="Secretum Secretorum">Secretum Secretorum</a></i>, a medieval treatise also known as "Book of the science of government: on the good ordering of statecraft"</li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/Leviathan_(Hobbes_book)" title="Leviathan (Hobbes book)">Leviathan</a></i>, a book on political realism by Thomas Hobbes</li></ul>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="References">References</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Prince&amp;action=edit&amp;section=40" title="Edit section: References"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1327269900">.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}body.skin-vector-2022 .mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:27em}body.skin-vector-2022 .mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:22.5em}.mw-parser-output .references[data-mw-group=upper-alpha]{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .references[data-mw-group=upper-roman]{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .references[data-mw-group=lower-alpha]{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .references[data-mw-group=lower-greek]{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .references[data-mw-group=lower-roman]{list-style-type:lower-roman}.mw-parser-output div.reflist-liststyle-upper-alpha .references{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output div.reflist-liststyle-upper-roman .references{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output div.reflist-liststyle-lower-alpha .references{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output div.reflist-liststyle-lower-greek .references{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output div.reflist-liststyle-lower-roman .references{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style><div class="mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns" style="column-width: calc( 0.9 * 30em );"><ol class="references">
<li id="cite&#95;note-:0-1"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-:0_1-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFStrauss1987">Strauss (1987</a>:297): "Machiavelli is the only political thinker whose name has come into common use for designating a kind of politics, which exists and will continue to exist independently of his influence, a politics guided exclusively by considerations of expediency, which uses all means, fair or foul, iron or poison, for achieving its ends – its end being the aggrandizement of one's country or fatherland – but also using the fatherland in the service of the self-aggrandizement of the politician or statesman or one's party".</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-2"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-2">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite id="CITEREFMansfield1998" class="citation book cs1">Mansfield, Harvey C. (25 February 1998). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=Q4EULB2IM50C&amp;q=half+hearted&amp;pg=PA178"><i>Machiavelli's Virtue</i></a>. University of Chicago Press. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-226-50372-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-226-50372-1"><bdi>978-0-226-50372-1</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Machiavelli%27s+Virtue&amp;rft.pub=University+of+Chicago+Press&amp;rft.date=1998-02-25&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-226-50372-1&amp;rft.aulast=Mansfield&amp;rft.aufirst=Harvey+C.&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DQ4EULB2IM50C%26q%3Dhalf%2Bhearted%26pg%3DPA178&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AThe+Prince" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-3">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">He wrote about a short study he was making by this Latin name in his letter to <a href="/wiki/Francesco_Vettori" title="Francesco Vettori">Francesco Vettori</a>, written 10 Dec 1513. This is letter 224 in the translated correspondence edition of James B. Atkinson and David Sices: <a href="#CITEREFMachiavelli1996">Machiavelli (1996</a>:264).</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-4"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-4">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFBireley1990">Bireley (1990)</a> p. 14.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-ITALIAN&#95;VERNACULAR-5"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-ITALIAN_VERNACULAR_5-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20120327162456/http://vlib.iue.it/carrie/texts/carrie_books/gilbert/06.html">"Italian Vernacular Literature"</a>. <i>Vlib.iue.it</i>. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://vlib.iue.it/carrie/texts/carrie_books/gilbert/06.html">the original</a> on 2012-03-27<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">2012-01-09</span></span>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Vlib.iue.it&amp;rft.atitle=Italian+Vernacular+Literature&amp;rft&#95;id=http%3A%2F%2Fvlib.iue.it%2Fcarrie%2Ftexts%2Fcarrie&#95;books%2Fgilbert%2F06.html&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AThe+Prince" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-6"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-6">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFGilbert1938">Gilbert (1938)</a> emphasizes similarities between <i>The Prince</i> and its forerunners, but still sees the same innovations as other commentators. Machiavelli's writings continue to be a provocative examination of leadership and government that poses age-old issues regarding the nature of power and the decisions that rulers must make to preserve it.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-7"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-7">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite id="CITEREFPangleBurns2015" class="citation book cs1">Pangle, Thomas L.; Burns, Timothy W. (2015). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=M3pxBAAAQBAJ&amp;dq=Borgia%20%2C%20who%20superficially%20seems%20the%20hero%20of%20the%20work%20%E2%80%93%20the%20contemporary%20whom%20Machiavelli%20seems%20most%20to%20admire%20.%20We%20note%20from%20the%20start%20%2C%20however%20%2C%20what%20a%20qualification%20this%20implies%20.%20Cesare%20appears%20as%20the%20best%20of%20contemporary%20leaders%20...&amp;pg=PA209"><i>The Key Texts of Political Philosophy</i></a>. Cambridge University Press. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-107-00607-2" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-107-00607-2"><bdi>978-1-107-00607-2</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Key+Texts+of+Political+Philosophy&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2015&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-107-00607-2&amp;rft.aulast=Pangle&amp;rft.aufirst=Thomas+L.&amp;rft.au=Burns%2C+Timothy+W.&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DM3pxBAAAQBAJ%26dq%3DBorgia%2520%252C%2520who%2520superficially%2520seems%2520the%2520hero%2520of%2520the%2520work%2520%25E2%2580%2593%2520the%2520contemporary%2520whom%2520Machiavelli%2520seems%2520most%2520to%2520admire%2520.%2520We%2520note%2520from%2520the%2520start%2520%252C%2520however%2520%252C%2520what%2520a%2520qualification%2520this%2520implies%2520.%2520Cesare%2520appears%2520as%2520the%2520best%2520of%2520contemporary%2520leaders%2520...%26pg%3DPA209&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AThe+Prince" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-counter-8"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-counter_8-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFBireley1990">Bireley (1990)</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-9"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-9">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Although Machiavelli makes many references to classical sources, these do not include the customary deference to <a href="/wiki/Aristotle" title="Aristotle">Aristotle</a>, which was to some extent approved by the church in his time. <a href="#CITEREFStrauss1958">Strauss (1958</a>:222) says, "Machiavelli indicates his fundamental disagreement with Aristotle's doctrine of the whole by substituting "<a href="/wiki/Chance_(Ancient_Greek_concept)" class="mw-redirect" title="Chance (Ancient Greek concept)">chance</a>" (<i>caso</i>) for "<a href="/wiki/Nature_(philosophy)" title="Nature (philosophy)">nature</a>" in the only context in which he speaks of "the beginning of the world." Strauss gives evidence that Machiavelli was knowingly influenced by <a href="/wiki/Democritus" title="Democritus">Democritus</a>, whose philosophy of nature was, like that of <a href="/wiki/Modern_science" class="mw-redirect" title="Modern science">modern science</a>, <a href="/wiki/Materialism" title="Materialism">materialist</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-10"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-10">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFBireley1990">Bireley (1990</a>:241)</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-11"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-11">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">See for example <a href="#CITEREFde_Alvarez1999">de Alvarez (1999)</a> p. viii; and <a href="#CITEREFStrauss1958">Strauss (1958</a>:55)</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-12"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-12">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFGuarini1999">Guarini (1999</a>:30)</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-13"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-13">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite id="CITEREFHexter1957" class="citation journal cs1">Hexter, J. H. <li id="cite&#95;note-23"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-23">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite id="CITEREFMachiavelli2010" class="citation book cs1">Machiavelli, Niccolò (2010-05-15). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=ehzOd8DVlNkC&amp;q=harvey+mansfield"><i>The Prince: Second Edition</i></a>. University of Chicago Press. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780226500508" title="Special:BookSources/9780226500508"><bdi>9780226500508</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Prince%3A+Second+Edition&amp;rft.pub=University+of+Chicago+Press&amp;rft.date=2010-05-15&amp;rft.isbn=9780226500508&amp;rft.aulast=Machiavelli&amp;rft.aufirst=Niccol%C3%B2&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DehzOd8DVlNkC%26q%3Dharvey%2Bmansfield&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AThe+Prince" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-24"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-24">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Gilbert. <i>Machiavelli's Prince and Its Forerunners</i>. pg 39</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-25"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-25">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite class="citation news cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.constitution.org/mac/prince07.htm">"Machiavelli: The Prince: Chapter VII"</a>. <i>www.constitution.org</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">2019-02-26</span></span>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=www.constitution.org&amp;rft.atitle=Machiavelli%3A+The+Prince%3A+Chapter+VII&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.constitution.org%2Fmac%2Fprince07.htm&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AThe+Prince" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-26"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-26">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Gilbert. <i>Machiavelli's Prince and Its Forerunners</i>. pg 48</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-Ch12-27"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Ch12_27-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite id="CITEREFMachiavelli" class="citation cs2">Machiavelli, <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20161112143208/https://ebooks.adelaide.edu.au/m/machiavelli/niccolo/m149p/chapter12.html">"Chapter 12"</a>, <i>The Prince</i>, Constitution.org, archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://ebooks.adelaide.edu.au/m/machiavelli/niccolo/m149p/chapter12.html">the original</a> on 2016-11-12<span class="reference-accessdate">, retrieved <span class="nowrap">2010-01-01</span></span></cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Chapter+12&amp;rft.btitle=The+Prince&amp;rft.pub=Constitution.org&amp;rft.au=Machiavelli&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Febooks.adelaide.edu.au%2Fm%2Fmachiavelli%2Fniccolo%2Fm149p%2Fchapter12.html&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AThe+Prince" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-28"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-28">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite id="CITEREFMachiavelli" class="citation book cs1">Machiavelli. <a class="external text" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/The_Prince_(Hill_Thomson)/Chapter_XV">"Chapter 15"</a>. <i>The Prince</i>. <a href="/wiki/Wikisource" title="Wikisource">Wikisource</a>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Chapter+15&amp;rft.btitle=The+Prince&amp;rft.pub=Wikisource&amp;rft.au=Machiavelli&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fen.wikisource.org%2Fwiki%2FThe&#95;Prince&#95;%28Hill&#95;Thomson%29%2FChapter&#95;XV&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AThe+Prince" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-29"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-29">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite id="CITEREFMachiavelli2010" class="citation book cs1">Machiavelli, Niccolò (2010-05-15). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=ehzOd8DVlNkC&amp;q=the+prince+mansfield"><i>The Prince: Second Edition</i></a>. University of Chicago Press. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780226500508" title="Special:BookSources/9780226500508"><bdi>9780226500508</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Prince%3A+Second+Edition&amp;rft.pub=University+of+Chicago+Press&amp;rft.date=2010-05-15&amp;rft.isbn=9780226500508&amp;rft.aulast=Machiavelli&amp;rft.aufirst=Niccol%C3%B2&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DehzOd8DVlNkC%26q%3Dthe%2Bprince%2Bmansfield&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AThe+Prince" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-30"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-30">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.iep.utm.edu/machiave/#SH2a">Niccolò Machiavelli (1469—1527)</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-31"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-31">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite id="CITEREFStrauss2014" class="citation book cs1">Strauss, Leo (2014-07-04). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=oi2GDwAAQBAJ&amp;q=leo+strauss+thoughts+on+machiavelli"><i>Thoughts on Machiavelli</i></a>. University of Chicago Press. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780226230979" title="Special:BookSources/9780226230979"><bdi>9780226230979</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Thoughts+on+Machiavelli&amp;rft.pub=University+of+Chicago+Press&amp;rft.date=2014-07-04&amp;rft.isbn=9780226230979&amp;rft.aulast=Strauss&amp;rft.aufirst=Leo&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3Doi2GDwAAQBAJ%26q%3Dleo%2Bstrauss%2Bthoughts%2Bon%2Bmachiavelli&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AThe+Prince" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-32"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-32">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite id="CITEREFBarlow1999" class="citation journal cs1">Barlow, J.J. (Winter 1999). "The Fox and the Lion: Machiavelli Replies to Cicero". <i>History of Political Thought</i>. <b>20</b> (4): <span class="nowrap">627–</span>645. <a href="/wiki/JSTOR_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="JSTOR (identifier)">JSTOR</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.jstor.org/stable/26219664">26219664</a>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=History+of+Political+Thought&amp;rft.atitle=The+Fox+and+the+Lion%3A+Machiavelli+Replies+to+Cicero&amp;rft.ssn=winter&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.pages=627-645&amp;rft.date=1999&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.jstor.org%2Fstable%2F26219664%23id-name%3DJSTOR&amp;rft.aulast=Barlow&amp;rft.aufirst=J.J.&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AThe+Prince" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-Ch25-33"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Ch25_33-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite id="CITEREFMachiavelli" class="citation cs2">Machiavelli, <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20091008190035/http://ebooks.adelaide.edu.au/m/machiavelli/niccolo/m149p/chapter25.html">"Chapter 25"</a>, <i>The Prince</i>, Constitution.org, archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://ebooks.adelaide.edu.au/m/machiavelli/niccolo/m149p/chapter25.html">the original</a> on 2009-10-08<span class="reference-accessdate">, retrieved <span class="nowrap">2010-01-01</span></span></cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Chapter+25&amp;rft.btitle=The+Prince&amp;rft.pub=Constitution.org&amp;rft.au=Machiavelli&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Febooks.adelaide.edu.au%2Fm%2Fmachiavelli%2Fniccolo%2Fm149p%2Fchapter25.html&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AThe+Prince" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-34"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-34">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">As <a href="/wiki/Francis_Bacon" title="Francis Bacon">Francis Bacon</a> wrote in his 13th essay, quoted at <a href="#CITEREFStrauss1958">Strauss (1958</a>:176), that "one of the doctors of Italy, Nicholas Machiavel, had the confidence to put in writing, almost in plain terms, <i>That the Christian faith had given up good men in prey to those who are tyrannical and unjust</i>".</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-35"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-35">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFNajemy1993">Najemy (1993)</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-36"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-36">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFDent1995">Dent (1995)</a> p. xvii</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-Let-37"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Let_37-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite id="CITEREFMachiavelli" class="citation cs2">Machiavelli, <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://ebooks.adelaide.edu.au/m/machiavelli/niccolo/m149p/complete.html">"Dedication"</a>, <i>The Prince</i>, Constitution.org, <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20160115095852/https://ebooks.adelaide.edu.au/m/machiavelli/niccolo/m149p/">archived</a> from the original on 2016-01-15<span class="reference-accessdate">, retrieved <span class="nowrap">2010-01-01</span></span></cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Dedication&amp;rft.btitle=The+Prince&amp;rft.pub=Constitution.org&amp;rft.au=Machiavelli&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Febooks.adelaide.edu.au%2Fm%2Fmachiavelli%2Fniccolo%2Fm149p%2Fcomplete.html&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AThe+Prince" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-38"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-38">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFFischer2000">Fischer (2000</a>, p.&#160;181) says that some people "might hold Machiavelli to some extent responsible for the crimes of a <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Lenin" title="Vladimir Lenin">Lenin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Adolf_Hitler" title="Adolf Hitler">Hitler</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mao_Zedong" title="Mao Zedong">Mao</a>, or <a href="/wiki/Pol_Pot" title="Pol Pot">Pol Pot</a>, who had learned from him to excuse the murder of innocents by its supposed benefits for humanity." <a href="#CITEREFStrauss1958">Strauss (1958</a>, p.&#160;12) writes that "We shall not hesitate to assert, as very many have asserted before us, and we shall later on try to prove, that Machiavelli's teaching is immoral and irreligious."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-39"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-39">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">For example <a href="#CITEREFStrauss1958">Strauss (1958</a>, p.&#160;182): "Machiavelli's book on principalities and his book on republics are both republican."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-40"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-40">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFFischer2000">Fischer (2000</a>, p.&#160;181)</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-41"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-41">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Concerning being a scientist, <a href="#CITEREFStrauss1958">Strauss (1958</a>:54–55) says that this description of Machiavelli as a scientist "is defensible and even helpful provided it is properly meant" because <i>The Prince</i> "conveys a general teaching" and only uses specific historical facts and experience as a basis for such generalizing. On the other hand <a href="#CITEREFStrauss1958">Strauss (1958</a>, p.&#160;11): "Machiavelli's works abound with "value-judgments". Concerning patriotism <a href="#CITEREFStrauss1958">Strauss (1958</a>:10–11) writes that "Machiavelli understood it as collective selfishness." It is Machiavelli's indifferent "comprehensive reflection" about right and wrong, which is "the core of Machiavelli's thought," not love of the fatherland as such.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-42"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-42">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Much of Machiavelli's personal correspondence with other Florentines is preserved, including some of the most famous letters in Italian. Of particular interest for example, are some of his letters to <a href="/wiki/Francesco_Vettori" title="Francesco Vettori">Francesco Vettori</a> and <a href="/wiki/Francesco_Guicciardini" title="Francesco Guicciardini">Francesco Guicciardini</a>, two men who had managed to stay in public service under the Medici, unlike Machiavelli. To Guicciardini for example he wrote concerning the selection of a preacher for Florence, that he would like a hypocritical one, and "I believe that the following would be the true way to go to Paradise: learn the way to Hell in order to steer clear of it." (Letter 270 in <a href="#CITEREFMachiavelli1996">Machiavelli (1996)</a>)</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-43"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-43">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite id="CITEREFMachiavelli2010" class="citation book cs1">Machiavelli, Niccolò (2010-05-15). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=ehzOd8DVlNkC&amp;q=harvey+mansfield"><i>The Prince: Second Edition</i></a>. University of Chicago Press. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780226500508" title="Special:BookSources/9780226500508"><bdi>9780226500508</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Prince%3A+Second+Edition&amp;rft.pub=University+of+Chicago+Press&amp;rft.date=2010-05-15&amp;rft.isbn=9780226500508&amp;rft.aulast=Machiavelli&amp;rft.aufirst=Niccol%C3%B2&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DehzOd8DVlNkC%26q%3Dharvey%2Bmansfield&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AThe+Prince" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-44"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-44">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFGilbert1938">Gilbert (1938)</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-45"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-45">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">While pride is a sin in the Bible, "<a href="/wiki/Fortune_favours_the_bold" title="Fortune favours the bold">Fortune favours the bold</a>", used for example by <a href="#CITEREFDent1995">Dent (1995)</a> p. xxii to summarize Machiavelli's stance concerning fortune, was a classical saying. That the desire for glory of spirited young men can and should be allowed or even encouraged, because it is how the best rulers come to be, is a theory expressed most famously by Plato in his <i><a href="/wiki/Republic_(Plato)" title="Republic (Plato)">Republic</a></i>. (See <a href="#CITEREFStrauss1958">Strauss (1958</a>:289).) But as Strauss points out, Plato asserts that there is a higher type of life, and Machiavelli does not seem to accept this.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-46"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-46">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">See for example <a href="#CITEREFGuarini1999">Guarini (1999)</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-47"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-47">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFStrauss1987">Strauss (1987</a>:302)</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-48"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-48">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite id="CITEREFMansfield2017" class="citation book cs1">Mansfield, Harvey (2017-03-15). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=BgMaDgAAQBAJ&amp;q=machiavelli+on+necessity+mansfield&amp;pg=PA39"><i>"Machiavelli on Necessity" in Machiavelli on Liberty and Conflict</i></a>. University of Chicago Press. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780226429441" title="Special:BookSources/9780226429441"><bdi>9780226429441</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=%22Machiavelli+on+Necessity%22+in+Machiavelli+on+Liberty+and+Conflict&amp;rft.pub=University+of+Chicago+Press&amp;rft.date=2017-03-15&amp;rft.isbn=9780226429441&amp;rft.aulast=Mansfield&amp;rft.aufirst=Harvey&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DBgMaDgAAQBAJ%26q%3Dmachiavelli%2Bon%2Bnecessity%2Bmansfield%26pg%3DPA39&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AThe+Prince" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-49"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-49">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">See for example <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite id="CITEREFCammett1967" class="citation book cs1">Cammett, John McKay (1967). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=YTCsAAAAIAAJ&amp;pg=PA210."><i>Antonio Gramsci and the Origins of Italian Communism</i></a>. Stanford University Press. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780804701419" title="Special:BookSources/9780804701419"><bdi>9780804701419</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Antonio+Gramsci+and+the+Origins+of+Italian+Communism&amp;rft.pub=Stanford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=1967&amp;rft.isbn=9780804701419&amp;rft.aulast=Cammett&amp;rft.aufirst=John+McKay&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DYTCsAAAAIAAJ%26pg%3DPA210.&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AThe+Prince" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-BireleyP15-50"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-BireleyP15_50-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFBireley1990">Bireley (1990</a>:15)</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-51"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-51">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFHaitsma_Mulier1999">Haitsma Mulier (1999</a>:248)</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-52"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-52">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">While Bireley focuses on writers in the Catholic countries, <a href="#CITEREFHaitsma_Mulier1999">Haitsma Mulier (1999)</a> makes the same observation, writing with more of a focus upon the Protestant <a href="/wiki/Dutch_Republic" title="Dutch Republic">Netherlands</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-53"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-53">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Gentillet, <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=nCB0DwAAQBAJ&amp;dq=innocent%20gentillet%20anti-machiavel&amp;pg=PA1">Anti-Machiavel: A Discourse Upon the Means of Well Governing</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-54"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-54">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFBireley1990">Bireley (1990</a>:17)</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-55"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-55">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFBireley1990">Bireley (1990</a>:18)</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-56"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-56">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFBireley1990">Bireley (1990</a>:223–30)</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-57"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-57">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite id="CITEREFBenner2013" class="citation book cs1">Benner, Erica (28 November 2013). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=Ip1oAgAAQBAJ&amp;dq=found+this+type+of+book+to+be+written+by+an+enemy+of+the+human+race.+It+explains+every+means+whereby+religion,+justice+and+any+inclination+toward+virtue+could+be+destroyed%22&amp;pg=PR20"><i>Machiavelli's Prince: A New Reading</i></a>. Oxford University Press. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-100392-9" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-100392-9"><bdi>978-0-19-100392-9</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Machiavelli%27s+Prince%3A+A+New+Reading&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2013-11-28&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-100392-9&amp;rft.aulast=Benner&amp;rft.aufirst=Erica&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DIp1oAgAAQBAJ%26dq%3Dfound%2Bthis%2Btype%2Bof%2Bbook%2Bto%2Bbe%2Bwritten%2Bby%2Ban%2Benemy%2Bof%2Bthe%2Bhuman%2Brace.%2BIt%2Bexplains%2Bevery%2Bmeans%2Bwhereby%2Breligion%2C%2Bjustice%2Band%2Bany%2Binclination%2Btoward%2Bvirtue%2Bcould%2Bbe%2Bdestroyed%2522%26pg%3DPR20&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AThe+Prince" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-58"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-58">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFBireley1990">Bireley (1990</a>:17): "Jean Bodin's first comments, found in his <i>Method for the Easy Comprehension of History</i>, published in 1566, were positive."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-59"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-59">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Bacon wrote: "We are much beholden to Machiavelli and other writers of that class who openly and unfeignedly declare or describe what men do, and not what they ought to do." <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite class="citation cs2">"II.21.9", <i>Of the Advancement of Learning</i></cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=II.21.9&amp;rft.btitle=Of+the+Advancement+of+Learning&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AThe+Prince" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>

</ol></div>

					<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading mw-first-heading"><i>On War</i></h1>

						<div id="siteSub" class="noprint">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>

					<div id="contentSub"><div id="mw-content-subtitle"></div></div>
					
					
					<div id="mw-content-text" class="mw-body-content"><div class="mw-subjectpageheader">
</div><div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" lang="en" dir="ltr"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">1832 treatise on war by von Clausewitz</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1320445320">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}@media print{body.ns-0 .mw-parser-output .hatnote{display:none!important}}</style><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">This article is about the treatise on military strategy. For the manga series, see <a href="/wiki/Neo_G%C5%8Dmanism_Manifesto_Special_%E2%80%93_On_War" title="Neo Gōmanism Manifesto Special – On War">Neo Gōmanism Manifesto Special – On War</a>. For the 2008 film, see <a href="/wiki/On_War_(film)" title="On War (film)">On War (film)</a>.</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Vomkriege.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Vomkriege.jpg/250px-Vomkriege.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="372" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Vomkriege.jpg/500px-Vomkriege.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="720" data-file-height="1072" /></a><figcaption>Title page of the original German edition <i>Vom Kriege</i>, published in 1832</figcaption></figure>

</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content">

<div class="sidebar-list mw-collapsible mw-collapsed"><div class="sidebar-list-title" style="background:transparent;border-top:1px solid #aaa;;color: var(--color-base)">Books</div><div class="sidebar-list-content mw-collapsible-content">

</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content">
